HANSON, MAYOR.
FIRST SESSION, HELD NOVEMBER 22ND, 1886.
MINUTES OF EVIDENCE,
TAKEN IN SHORT-HAND, BY
JAMES DROVER BARNETT
AND
ALEXANDER BUCKLER,
Short-hand Writers to the Court,
ROLLS CHAMBERS, No. 89, CHANCERY LANE.
THE POINTS OF LAW AND PRACTICE
REVISED AND EDITED BY
EDWARD T. E. BESLEY, ESQ.,
OF THE MIDDLE TEMPLE, BARRISTER-AT-LAW.
VOL. CV.
SESSIONS I. TO VI.
LONDON:
STEVENS AND SONS, 119, CHANCERY LANE,
Law Booksellers and Publishers.
THE
WHOLE PROCEEDINGS
On the Queen's Commission of
OYER AND TERMINER AND GAOL DELIVERY
FOR
The City of London,
AND GAOL DELIVERY FOR THE
COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX, AND PARTS OF THE COUNTIES OF ESSEX, KENT, AND SURREY, WITHIN THE JURISDICTION
OF THE
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT,
Including cases committed to this Court under Order in Council pursuant to the Winter Assize Act of 1879,
Held on Monday, November 22nd, 1886, and following days.

BEFORE the RIGHT HON. SIR
REGINALD HANSON, LORD MAYOR of the City of London; Hon. Sir
ALFRED WILLS , Knt., one of the Justices of Her Majesty's High Court of Justice; Sir
ROBERT WALTER CARDEN , Knt., Sir
JAMES CLARKE LAWRENCE , Bart., Sir
THOMAS GABRIEL , Bart., and Sir
WILLIAM McARTHUR , Knt., Aldermen of the said City; Sir
THOMAS CHAMBERS , Knt., Q.C., Recorder of the said City; POLYDORE DE KEYSER, Esq.,
EDWARD JAMES GRAY , Esq., and
STUART KNILL , Esq., other of the Aldermen of the said City; Sir,
WILLIAM THOMAS CHARLEY , Knt., Q.C., D.C.L., Common Serjeant of the said City; and
ROBERT MALCOLM KERR , Esq., LL.D., Judge of the Sheriffs' Court; Her Majesty's Justices of Oyer and Terminer, and General Gaol Delivery, holden for the said City, and Judges of the Central Criminal Court.
HENRY AARON ISAACS , Esq., Alderman,
LIEUTENANT-COLONEL KIRBY,
ALGERNON EDWARD SYDNEY , Esq.,
GEORGE ROSE INNES . Junior, Esq.,
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
HANSON, MAYOR. FIRST SESSION.

A star (*) denotes that prisoner's have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

1.
RICHARD STEPHEN LA DELL was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. PURCELL

ERNEST EDWARD WICKHAM . I am one of the Registrars of the Shore-ditch County Courtâ€”on 11th March a plaint was heard of Levestque against Hudsonâ€”I produce this judgmentâ€”under that a judgment sum-mons was issued, but it was not served personallyâ€”I know the defendant as very often being a witness in the Court during the five months I have been thereâ€”he is not an official process-server, but issues process for parties. (The summons was read, and was for 1 l . 0 s. 9 d ., the balance of a debt, and the prisoner alleged that he had personally served it.) Personal service is requiredâ€”I administered the oath to the defendant, who said that he had made personal serviceâ€”it was not signed in my presence that was done before it was broughtâ€”the defendant did not appear upon that, and an order of commitment was made, dated 1st Juneâ€”on 7th June a notice was served by the defendant's father for the purpose of setting aside the judgmentâ€”that name on before the Judge on 10th Juneâ€”I then heard the defendant's father say that his son had not had the summonsâ€”the Judge then put a question to La Dell, and he then admitted that he had not served it personallyâ€”the Judge then rescinded the order of commitment, and sent the matter on to the Public Prosecutor.

Cross-examined. The defendant acts as process-server for plaintiffs for small sumsâ€”I administered the oath to him in my officeâ€”I cannot tell from the papers here whether the debtor has paid the moneyâ€”the de
fendant made no secret that he had not served it personally after the
Judge's questionâ€”I have no recollection that he told the Judge that he had called at Hudson's place time after time, and that Hudson knew the summons was to be served and kept out of the way.
Re-examined. The defendant's father before the Judge produced the registered letter with the summons in it, to prove it was sent by letter.

GEORGE HUDSON . I live at 73, Bishop's Road, Victoria Parkâ€”I have a son named William Hudson, he was the defendant in this suit at the County Courtâ€”the prisoner called twice at my house before I received the registered letter, and I saw him on both occasions, but he never saw my sonâ€”about 21st May I received this registered letter. (Addressed "Wm. Hudson, 73, Bishop's Road, Victoria Park, E." containing a summons.) My son was not at home at the time, he was travelling in the countryâ€”finding it was a registered letter I opened it, I open all his letters, and found it contained this judgment summons, but I never gave it to my son, and he never saw itâ€”my son being from London, I went on 7th June to the County Court for the purpose of setting aside the proceedings, and on 10th June I attended before the learned Judge, Mr. Prenticeâ€”the prisoner I think was thereâ€”I explained to the Judge that my son had never received the summons, and produced the letter to show it had been sent by post; then the prisoner admitted he had not personally served itâ€”up to that time my son had not seen it.

Cross-examined. My son is not here to-dayâ€”I have not seen him for the last six months; probably he has not paid this moneyâ€”when the prisoner first came to me I told him my son was not at homeâ€”he was in London on the first day I thinkâ€”he called again a day or two afterwards and asked again if my son was at homeâ€”I think he was in London at the timeâ€”I did not know what he came for, or whether he came for a debt of my son'sâ€”I had seen him besides the two occasions, and before the registered letter arrived, and he told me that there was a judgment summons against my son, and if he didn't pay he would have to go to Hollowayâ€”I also met him in the Hackney Road before the letter arrivedâ€”I knew that he was acting for the plaintiff against my son, but knew nothing about him being in danger of being committed to Hollowayâ€”the prisoner said "You had better give your son the summons," and I said "You had better give it to him yourself."
HORACE ERLE . I am one of the Registrars of the Shoreditch County Courtâ€”I have known the defendant some eight or nine years as an agent for serving processes for parties suing in our Courts.
Cross-examined. He has always borne the character of an honest, straightforward man.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character from several witnesses

div1.p:
GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury. â€”
One Month's Hard Labour.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner for a like offence.

div1.p:
2.
WALTER NUTT (23) and
GEORGE HALL (47)
, Unlawfully conspiring to procure Nutt a situation in the business of
John Turner and others.
MR. BESLEY Prosecuted; MR. TICKELL defended Nutt, and MR. GRAIN appeared for Hall.
SAMUEL GRAY . I am a member of the firm of Baker and Gray, drapers, of 446, Holloway Roadâ€”Nutt was in my service about March,

1885, and left about December 21st or 22nd in the same yearâ€”I had no character with him when he cameâ€”he was a traveller for my agencyâ€”I discharged him, he did not leave of his own accordâ€”I did not give him a character.

Cross-examined by MR. TICKELL I discharged him partly because I was doing no business in that line, and partly on account of his dis
honestyâ€”I don't remember saying before the Magistrate "I did not dis
charge him on the ground of dishonesty," if it is on that paper, I said itâ€”I have not been speaking to Mr. Bushell about this case since I was before the Magistrateâ€”Nutt has brought an action against me for slander; that was before this case was institutedâ€”it is not alleged that that slander got him out of a situationâ€”I told Nutt that he had partly given me satisfaction while he was in my service; but not without using the word "partly," I will swear thatâ€”if it is taken down that I said "I may have told him he had given me satisfaction while in our service/" I must have said it.

Re-examined. I have nothing to do with this prosecution, I never sub
scribed to it or had anything to do with itâ€”a Mr. Norman I think cross-examined me at the police-court, he asked me if I would have given Nutt a character if he had appliedâ€”I said "No;" he then put the question "Had he given me satisfaction while he was in my service?" and I said I discharged him partly from dishonestyâ€”this action was brought in September, and the solicitor conducting it is the same as cross-ex
amined me.

By MR. TICKELL. I said before the Magistrate "We represented Messrs. Ward, of Paris, while Nutt was with us; after he left we lost that agency," it went to Mr. Bushell, his employersâ€”I lost that through Nutt.

JULIUS BUSHELL I carried on business at this time as a silk mercer at 58, Maddox Streetâ€”Nutt came into my service at the end of January this year as a travellerâ€”I got no character with himâ€”it was through a friend knowing him previously that I took himâ€”he remained with me till 24th May, and when he left I gave him in custody and charged him at the Middlesex Sessions with stealing silkâ€”he was kept in custody without bail and was tried about 23rd June, and was acquittedâ€”I gave him no character.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN While he was in my service I had some goods put in a back roomâ€”no other name was put over the doorâ€”they were put in there to make room for other goods, not to avoid process by the Sheriffâ€”I expected them to come down on meâ€”I did not tell Nutt to get the things out of the way of the process-serverâ€”I did not tell you at the Middlesex Sessions that they were put in there for that purposeâ€”I was being sued by a Sewing Machine Company for 1,000l.; judgment was signed against me, and as soon as I received it I sent it on to my solicitor, and I have not heard of it sinceâ€”it was at that time that I put a large quantity of goods in the back room and put the name of Node over the doorâ€”the name of Bushell was over the front of the premises; there was not room to put Node as wellâ€”I swear that those goods were not put in that room to avoid process of lawâ€”Nutt did not bring an action against me for malicious prosecution, he brought an action against me after his acquittal for commission and salary, and it is now impendingâ€”I had under Order 14 to bring money into Court before I could defend

â€”I have never communicated with Baldwin and Co., or Spencer and Co., and have never told any one else to communicate with themâ€”this is true what I said before, "I took him," meaning Nutt, "into my employment partly that he might get me Node's business; when he was in my employ I had Node's name painted on my door some time afterwards; I was not in difficulties at the time"â€”at the time I put Node's name on the door I had two or three County Court judgments against me, one was for 11s. and the other between 2l. and 3l.â€”I was informed that Nutt lived at Marshall and Snellgrove's years agoâ€”I am not the least vin
dictive in this matterâ€”I also heard he lived at Peter Robinson's and Allison's.

Cross-examined by MR. TICKELL I did not say after Nutt's acquittal at the Middlesex Sessions that I would be revenged upon him, that I swear: I never threatened himâ€”I did not say I would do him any injuryâ€”I know a man named Robert Stokes, of Grantham, but only by his falsely entering a piece of silk in my book and sending it down thereâ€”I did not ask him where Nutt was, or say "I shall find him when I want him, and wherever he is I will have him out of it; "nor did I say "He may thank his counsel for his escape, but I will fasten him next time."

Re-examined. Nutt sent a piece of silk down to Corby, near Grantham, to Stokes, under the pretence that he was a small draper, and when I went there I found him living in the smallest cottage in the village, and he had been out of work for two or three yearsâ€”the goods in the back room had nothing to do with Nuttâ€”they were not put there to avoid process, but because I wanted the roomâ€”Nutt knew about these County Court judgments, I kept nothing from himâ€”Mr. Grain defended him at the Middlesex Sessionsâ€”I have nothing to do with this prosecution, I was subpoenaed here as a witness to prove the time he was with me.

By MR. GRAIN. This is not true, "A Sewing Machine Company threatened to come down on me, and I suggested that I should make over some of my goods to a certain person, in order to protect a lady from whom I had borrowed moneyâ€”I cannot say whether I or the prisoner made the suggestion that goods should be made over to the prisoner in view of a certain contingency"â€”I don't believe you are reading it rightâ€”I consulted my solicitor at the time, and no more was thought of it.

By MR. BESLEY. I was sued for commission and salary, and I think they said 45l. would settle itâ€”Mr. Norman was the solicitor, the same as cross-examined me before the Magistrateâ€”I paid 15l. into Courtâ€”the value of the property I alleged he had stolen was from 100l. to 150l.â€”the putting up of Node's name had nothing to do with the goods in the room, it was put up two or three days after he came in my employâ€”it had nothing whatever to do with this charge.

ROBERT CLEMENSON . I am a member of the firm of Allison and Co., 238, Regent Streetâ€”Nutt was in our employment from 23rd April to 25th October, 1884â€”I considered I was giving the reference to Mr. Bisnard; that is a Paris houseâ€”I gave Hall a character to get the situa
tionâ€”Hall wrote this letter on Mr. Bisnard's paper: "Gentlemen, Mr. Walter Nutt having applied for a situation which I have vacant, tell me what was his character while in your employ"â€”I answered satisfactorily, and I know that he went there, and he came back to me five or six weeks afterwards and said he had leftâ€”I got his character from Marshall and Snellgrove.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. While he was in my service he was steady and industrious and honest, and left of his own accordâ€”I know nothing of his employment after he left us; he never applied for any references, except for Hall's.

ATHUR RUSSELL I am chief clerk to Messrs. Spence and Co., silk mercers, of St. Paul's Churchyardâ€”an application was made by Nutt to be taken into their employment, and he was given this form to fill up; he then filled it up, and left it. (This stated that his last situation was with Hall for four months.) That was sent to Hall with a printed letter form asking for a verification of the statementâ€”I believed at that time that his last situation was with Hallâ€”he said nothing to me with regard to Baker and Gray, or Bushellâ€”I got this back from Hall with this letter accompanying it. (This stated that Nutt had been with him four months, and that he had received a good character with him from Allison's.) I believed that he had left Hall in June, 1886, instead of June, 1885â€”he came into our service on July 12, and I discharged him on the 26thâ€”we always expect the last employer to give a characterâ€”I should not have taken him without further inquiries if I had known that the character in the letter was in respect of four months ending February, 1885â€”I am in no way connected with the prosecution, except to give evidenceâ€”Messrs. Spencer, Turner, and Co. prosecute.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I believed he had left Hall's service in June, 1886, by the form being sent back by with character, and that he had left Allison's on February 1stâ€”I knew he had been at Marshall and Snelgrove'sâ€”I discharged him from information I received from our traveller that he had been tried and acquitted at the Middlesex Sessions, but I made no inquiry as to whether they had been rightly or wrongly acquittedâ€”I did not tell him that was the reason of my discharging himâ€”I gave him a printed letter, stating it was in consequence of alterations in that department that I discharged himâ€”we keep those printed forms in stock, because we don't want the trouble of writing themâ€”beyond hearing that he was tried and acquitted I say nothing against him.

Cross-examined by MR. TICKELL I do not know a Mr. Berwick or a Mr. Borwickâ€”I did not say to anybody "I am not aware that I told him he was discharged on account of information received from Messrs. Baker and Gray"â€”Is wear that.

Re-examined. This is the notice that was produced at the police-courtâ€”I believed his name was William Peek Nutt, as he has signed it thereâ€”Hall sent these particulars back by the same post, or soon afterâ€”I had no doubt that the time referred to there was June, 1886â€”I did not know until at the police-court that instead of his having left Allison's in 1886 he had only been there from April to October, 1884â€”I did not write in the form that I had heard he had been tried and acquitted, but directly I found out the truth I turned him awayâ€”I sent a copy of this form with Nutt's statement in writing to Hall.

By MR. GRAIN. I did up the letter to Hall myselfâ€”I never saw the document again; it did not come backâ€”I did not post it, but I know he got it, because the fly-sheet came back from Hallâ€”part of the enclosure was returnedâ€”I have not a word to say against his honesty, sobriety, or that he was not of good business habitsâ€”other than the fact that he was tried and acquitted at the Middlesex Sessions I know of no single fact of
my own knowledge that would have rendered it undesirable for my firm to engage him.
By MR. BESLEY. If I had known he was with Allison in 1884 when it was represented as 1886 I should not have engaged him, nor if I had known he had left Hall's in 1885.

HENRY JOHN TURNER . I am a member of the firm of Spencer, Turner, and Co., drapers, of Lisson Groveâ€”we are the sole prosecutors in this case, and have undertaken it upon our own responsibilityâ€”on 12th August Nutt called on me, and filled up this form. (In which he called himself Walter Nutt, of 15, Great Chesterfield Street, aged 26, single, and stated that he was last employed at Halls, of 22, Brixton Road, from 27th February to 5th July; that he left there by his resignation, as he wished to relinquish travelling, and that his previous employers were Allison and Co. of Regent Street.) As the result of that form being filled up by him I sent the paper to Hall, saying on the fly-leaf that we had been referred to him for a character, asking him to say if it was correct, and to sign it and return itâ€”Hall had nothing to do but to confirm Nutt's statement, and send it back if it was correctâ€”he sent this letter, dated August 12, 1886, 22, Brixton Road. (Stating that he had received from Allison a good character of Nutt, and that during the time he was with him he found him as described, and was satisfied with him; that he left him of his own accord saying he wished to give up travelling.) That was accompanied with the written document which Nutt had filled up, stating he had been with Hall from 27th February to July, 1886â€”I believed that was the last situation he had filledâ€”I heard nothing about Spence and Co., or Bushell, or Gray and Bakerâ€”I knew nothing about his being tried and acquittedâ€”he entered our service, and was with us from August 12 till the summons was taken out on 18th September, when he was dischargedâ€”I made a complaint to him about 14 days or three weeks after he entered our employâ€”I made further inquiries, and in the result I took out a summons and Nutt went before a Magistrateâ€”I did not know he was married, nor that he had been William Peek Nutt a month before.

Cross-examined by MR. TICKELL. I have no reason for saying that he committed any act of dishonesty while in Hall's serviceâ€”I said I knew of no act of dishonesty committed by him, but I knew of something improperâ€”I placed the matter in Mr. Wontner's hands and the prisoner was arrested.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I took Hall on a summons by Mr. Wontner's adviceâ€”I had not heard of Hall up to that time except from this letterâ€”I have not a word to say against himâ€”I charged him because I was advised to by Mr. Wontner; I did not intend to do so before thatâ€”I believe I arrested Nutt and summoned Hall at the same timeâ€”the character Hall received from Allison's was correctâ€”I did not hear about the trial at Middlesex Sessionsâ€”I was sent for by a pawnbroker in the neighbourhoodâ€”I saw Messrs. James Spence and Co. on the day I went to Messrs. Wontner'sâ€”they did not decline to take proceedingsâ€”they have nothing to do with it, I am the prosecutor.

Re-examined. Hall had not been at Allison's in 1886â€”I did not want his character in 1884â€”I believed Nutt's statements were correct when I filled up the formâ€”mine was the last place he got a situation atâ€”after the prisoner had been with me three weeks a pawnbroker asked me whether I was aware he had pawned large quantities of silk goods with
him; I made inquiries and then consulted Mr. Wontnerâ€”the Magistrate granted a warrant against the two prisoners at the same time and on the same information.

WILLIAM RECORD (Police Sergeant D). A warrant was placed in my Lands for the apprehension of Nuttâ€”I found him in Great Chesterfield Street about half-past 5 on 18th Septemberâ€”I read the warrant to him; he said "If you go to Mr. Hall, Brixton Road, you will find it is not false, I was in his employ four or five months, since February last."

GUILTY .â€”
[Guilty] The Jury recommended Hall to mercyâ€”
The prisoners were dis
charged on recognisances.

3.
CHARLES SHARPE (20) and
WILLIAM WADE (20)
PLEADED GUILTY
to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Charles Abrams and stealing 2s. 6d., his property.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour each. And

4.
THOMAS IVORY (12)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Grant, and stealing twelve postage stamps and 2l. 12s., after a conviction of felony in November, 1886.â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]
Judgment respited.

5.
WILLIAM BURTON (18)
, Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession, with intent to utter it.

JOHN CALEB (Police Sergeant D). On 30th October, between 1 and 2 in the day, I was with Pudsley at the Five Dials, Soho, watching a house, to detect a man in making base coinâ€”I saw the prisoner outside the house, and left him there, finding I was observedâ€”I saw him again 20 minutes or half an hour afterwards in Oxford Street, and said "l am a police officer; what have you got about you?"â€”he said "Nothing"â€”I searched him, and found in his trousers pocket 12 bad shillings in a match-box, separately wrapped, with this paper between each, which is marked; also a good sixpence and two passes for the Colonial Exhibi
tionâ€”I said "Where did you get this from?"â€”he said "I found it at the corner of a street"â€”I took him to the stationâ€”he gave his address, 18, Hereford Street, Marylebone; his father and mother live thereâ€”I went there and saw his mother.
WILLIAM PUDSLEY (Police Sergeant D). I was with Calebâ€”I have heard his evidence; it is correct.

ROBBERT APLEY . I am a tobacconist, of 49, Lion Street, Lisson Groveâ€”I have seen the prisoner at my shop nearly every day since I have had the shopâ€”he frequently came in without making any purchase, and about six weeks or two months before this I refused to take a shilling of him because it did not sound good, and he gave me anotherâ€”he said that he got it in a shop in changeâ€”I gave it back to him because I knew him, and I once allowed him to stay two or three nightsâ€”I saw him in my shop about 12 o'clock on the day he was arrested.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to Her Majesty's Mintâ€”these shillings are all counterfeit, and from several mouldsâ€”they were given to me wrapped up; they are rubbed over with lamp black
and put between paper, to keep them from rubbing, and that is rubbed off one by one as they want them.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the match-box, found it was heavy, and put it in my pocket; there was a cover on the box then.
JOHN CALEB (Re-examined). There was no cover to the box.

GUILTY .â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

6.
ALICE HOMES (27)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice to the same person.
MESSERS. WILKINSON and COOKE Prosecuted; MR. PURCELL Defended.

JULIA SEAR . My husband manages a dairy business at 3, Well street, Hackneyâ€”on 12th October I served the prisoner with two Neville's loaves, price sixpenceâ€”she gave me a shilling, and I gave her sixpence changeâ€”as soon as she left I found the shilling was badâ€”I put it on the fire, and it melted very quicklyâ€”on 28th October she came again for two Neville's loavesâ€”I knew her againâ€”she gave me a shillingâ€”I bit it, and my teeth sank in itâ€”I said "This is a bad shilling"â€”she said "If it is I will give you another," which she did, and I gave her sixpence change and gave her in charge with the bad coin.

Cross-examined. I told her she had been there on the 12thâ€”she said "It was not me; you have made a mistake"â€”it was on October 4th or 5th that she came firstâ€”I told the Magistrate that it was three weeks beforeâ€”I do not remember telling the policeman on the night she was arrested, that it was a fortnight previousâ€”the woman who bought the bread on what I now say was October 4th or 5th was a perfect stranger to meâ€”I knew her on the 28th October by her face and her dress and the fall she was wearingâ€”she had the same bonnet on each timeâ€”I am quite certain she is the woman; I have not the slightest doubt.
Re-examined. The hearing before the Magistrate was on the 29th, and the next on November 2nd, and it was then that I spoke of it being three weeks before.

RICHARD COOPER (Policeman 487 l). I was called to Mr. Sears's shop, and found the prisoner thereâ€”Mrs. Sears said "This woman has passed a bad shilling," and handed it to me, and said that she had passed one a fortnight previouslyâ€”I said "Are you sure she is the same woman?"â€”she said "Yes; I could swear to her from a hundred"â€”I told her she was charged with uttering a bad shilling, and said "Have you any more about you?"â€”she said "No"â€”I said "Have you got a purse?"â€”she said "Yes," and handed it to meâ€”it contained a shilling and two sixpences, goodâ€”she said "I did not know it was the"â€”she was taken to the station, where Mrs. Sears said that she had passed one there a fortnight previousâ€”the inspector asked her if she had got it by herâ€”she said "No, I threw it behind the fire"â€”the prisoner said nothing; she gave her address, 12, Glentho Road, Clapton Park; that is a mile and three-quarters from Mr. Sears'sâ€”I have been thereâ€”she does lodge there.

Cross-examined. I have ascertained nothing against herâ€”Mrs. Sears mentioned in her presence that she had been there a fortnight before, but she said nothingâ€”Mrs. Sears did not tell me that she had denied it before I cameâ€”there is a dyer and glover in Mare Street.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTETR . I am Inspector of Coin to Her Majesty's
Mintâ€”this shilling is counterfeitâ€”a coin melting and running through the fire rapidly would be the sign of a bad piece.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I did not know it was bad; I was never in the shop before."
NOT GUILTY .

7.
WILLIAM TRUDGETT (53) and
FREDERICK GROVE (25)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MSSRS. WILKINSON . and COOKE Prosecuted.

LYDIA SCOTT . I manage a confectioner's shop at 118, Theobald's Roadâ€”on November 1st, about 4.30 p.m., I served Trudgett with two-pennyworth of sweetsâ€”he tendered a florinâ€”I bounced it on the counter, put it in the tester, bent it, and said "Do you know this is bad?"â€”he said "No, I have just been to a public-house and asked for two half-pints of stout and mild; I gave them a half-sovereign, and they gave me the two-shilling piece in the change"â€”I saw Grove out
side, and Trudgett went to the door and called him in, and said "Did we not go to the public-house and have some stout and mild, and did not they give us this two-shilling piece bad in the change for the half-sovereign?"â€”Grove made no replyâ€”I gave the florin back to Trudgett, who gave me two penceâ€”they left, and I went to the door and saw them go to the Harper's Armsâ€”I called the potman, and made a communication to him.
The prisoner Grove. There were three of us in it.

JAMES PASSMORE . I serve in the bar of the Harper's Arms, Theo
bald's Roadâ€”on November 1st, about 4.30, the prisoners came in together, and Trudgett asked for two halves of four ale, and put down a florinâ€”I took it up, looked at it, bent it on the till, and found it was badâ€”I said nothing to them, but spoke to Mrs. Holl, and the prisoners were going out without their change; they had drank the aleâ€”the pot-man stopped themâ€”I afterwards gave the florin to Lloydâ€”this is it (produced).
Cross-examined by Trudgett. You told me to call a policeman if I likedâ€”the potman followed you out.

PETER LLOYD (Policeman E 51). On November 1st, about 4.40, the potman called my attention to the prisoners about 100 yards from the Harper's Arms, and said in their hearing, "These men have been in my master's house and called for two halves of ale and tendered a bad florin in payment"â€”Trudgett said, "It was not me"â€”I said, "You must go back"â€”we all went to the Harper's Arms and saw the and lady and Passmoreâ€”Trudgett said that it was a man who was in there at the same time, who put the money downâ€”I searched Grove and found a bad half-crown in his coat pocket, and a shilling, a sixpence, and 4 1/2 d. and a bad florin in his trousers pocketâ€”he gave his address, 28, Gee Street, which is correctâ€”Trudgett gave his address, 87, Cow Cross Street, Clerkenwell, which is correct.
Cross-examined by Trudgett. You came to me with the potman.

JOHN DAMIERRE (Policeman E 274). I was called and took Trudgettâ€”I searched him and found 1s. 6d. in silver and eight penceâ€”I asked him whether he had attempted to change a 2s. piece anywhereâ€”he said, "No"â€”on the way to the station he said, "I know the 2s. piece is bad for I tried to pass it at the sweetstuff shop."
Cross-examined by Trudgett. You were not the worse for drink.

HENRY WILLIAMS . I am potman at the Harper's Armsâ€”on November 1st, between 4 and 5 p.m., Miss Scott spoke to me and I went inside the bar and saw Passmore trying a florinâ€”he spoke to the mistress and she sent me for a policemanâ€”the prisoners followed me out and I walked with them into Lamb's Conduit Street till I found a policeman.
Cross-examined by Trudgett. You did not attempt to run awayâ€”I walked between you bothâ€”I said that I was going for a policeman.

ALFRED HANSON (Police Inspector E). I took the charge at the station, and received from Dampierre some money in a packet, which I opened as one of the prisoners asked for refreshments, and among other money I found this bad florin (produced)â€”it was the only florin thereâ€”I then went to Grove's cell and said, "The florin which is among the money found on you is a bad one"â€”he said, "I know nothing about it"â€”I should say that both prisoners were three parts drunk.
WILIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These two florins and this half-crown are bad.

Trudgett produced a written defence, stating that a man met him in the street and gave him a florin and sent him in to get the sweets, and when he found it was bad he paid with his own money and told the man it was bad, who said he wished he had a sack full of them, and afterwards walked away.â€”(The prisoners received good characters.)

GUILTY .â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour each.

8.
ELIZA CULLUM (18)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice in the same day.

SUSANNAH DENMAN . I am barmaid at the Bull's Head, Hyde Street, New Oxford Streetâ€”on 18th October, about 7.30 p.m., I served the pri
soner with half a quartern of gin in a bottle, price 7 1/2 d.â€”she gave me a half-crown and I gave her two shillings change and 2 1/2 d., and after she left I bent the coin, which I had placed by itself, in the testerâ€”about 20 minutes afterwards she came again for half a quartern of gin and gave me a bad florinâ€”I went to the landlady, a constable was brought, and she was chargedâ€”she said, "All right"â€”she also said that some woman gave her the coin in Short's Gardensâ€”I gave the two coins to the con
stable; these are them (produced).

EDWARD PACE (Policeman V 797). On 18th October, about 8.6 p.m., I was called to the Bull's Head and saw the prisoner thereâ€”she was charged with passing a bad half-crown and then a florinâ€”I asked her if she had any moreâ€”she said "No," and that a female in Short's Gardens gave it to her, but at the station she said that a young man gave it to her, a short, stout, dark man with brass buttonsâ€”she was searched, but no money was found.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to the Mintâ€”this florin and half-crown are bad.
Prisoner's Defence. "I was in Short's Gardens and had the half-crown given to me, and I went back and gave the young man the money.
NOT GUILTY .

9.
ARTHUR LEOPOLD GRESHAM (20)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing, whilst employed in the Post Office, a post parcel containing a brooch, a pair of earrings, and 12 stamps;
also a post parcel containing a half-crown, a silk handkerchief, a purse, and six stamps, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General.â€”
Twenty Months' Hard Labour.

10.
THOMAS DONELLY (39)
to uttering a forged warrant for the pay
ment of 4l. 15s. 6d., with intent to defraud.
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]â€”(See New Court Wednesday). And

11.
RICHARD HUBBARD
to stealing, while employed in the Post Office, a post letter containing the half of a 10l. note and the half of a 20l. note, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

12.
LEO HECKSHERE was indicted
for a rape on
Catherine Wheeler,
also for an indecent assault upon the same person.
MR. HUTTON, for the prosecution, offered no evidence on either indictment.
NOT GUILTY .

13.
ALFRED BARKER (42)
, Feloniously receiving six bales of goats' skins, the property of
Henry Wrightson, well knowing the same to have been stolen.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLAMS Prosecuted; MESSERS. GEOGHEGAN and HUTTON Defended.

THOMAS HAWKINS . I am a foreman lighterman in the employ of Mr. Wrightson, of 90, Lower Thames Streetâ€”on 17th August I had orders from Messrs. Hicks, Nash, and Co. to lighter 44 bales of goats' skins from the ship Cameo in Millwall Docks to Pickled Herring Wharf, and I gave directions to a man named McCabe to do soâ€”Simmonds afterwards reported at the wharf that six bales were shortâ€”the value of those would be about 120l.

HENRYT MCCABE . I am a waterman in the employ of Hicks, Nash, and Co., of Thames Streetâ€”on Tuesday, 17th August, I loaded the barge Thomas in the Millwall Docks with 44 bales of goats' skins from the steamship Cameoâ€”they were put up in bales and tied round with a piece of ropeâ€”having done that the barge was ready to be taken out of the docksâ€”on the 19th a man named Willett took charge of itâ€”the Millwall Docks is on the Middlesex side, and Pickled Herring Wharf is on the Surrey side.

Cross-examined. Nobody took charge of the barge before Willett cameâ€”people could not get through the gates without the constable seeing themâ€”sometimes there are five or six constables on duty thereâ€”I do not know how the skins disappearedâ€”they were all right about 1 p.m. on the 19thâ€”when I took off the covers the bulk did not seem to have been disturbed.

THOMAS WILLETT . I am a lighterman in the employ of the Union Lighterage Co.â€”on 19th August I went to the Millwall Docks and there saw the barge Thomas, and took charge of it and navigated it to Pickled Herring Wharfâ€”I saw she was laden with skins, but I didn't know how manyâ€”I then left the barge in the care of a man named Simmonds, who is in the employ of Mr. Wrightsonâ€”I did not leave the barge from the time I took charge of it until I delivered it up to himâ€”I was not present when she was unloaded.
GEORGE SIMMONDS . I live at Horselydown, and am a watchman in the

employ of Mr. Wrightsonâ€”on Thursday, 19th August, about half-past 3 in the afternoon, Willett handed the barge Thomas over into my charge, she was then about two or three barges from the wharf, and I was either in the craft or alongside the wharfâ€”I went away from it about 8 to go to the office, and was away about two hours, and then went back and stopped with her till she grounded at 12 o'clockâ€”I was on duty during the night, and next morning about 8 o'clock they started unloading herâ€”I don't know how these six packages went away, but I noticed how badly stacked she was, as if the stacking had been disturbedâ€”Hocking, a clerk of Messrs. Hicks and Co., takes a tally of them as they are landed.

THOMAS HOCKING . I am clerk to Messrs. Hicks, Nash, and Co., wharf
ingers, of Tooley Streetâ€”on Friday, 20th August, I took the weights of the bales taken out of the barge Thomas, and found that there were only 38, six were missingâ€”they were each marked with a triangle and a bar at the top.

Cross-examined. I had no invoice; Nesbitt and Co. would have thatâ€”I simply took the weightsâ€”I was supposed by our entry to receive 44 balesâ€”I have not that entry here, it was copied from the books.

JOHN FITZER . I am a skin carter in the employ of Messrs. A. W. Nesbitt, of Mill Lane, Tooley Streetâ€”they had an assignment of 44 bales of Norwegian goats' skins by the Cameoâ€”there were 120 to a bale, and were tied up with ropeâ€”they had to be tanned afterwardsâ€”I received the bales afterwards, and found there were only 38 instead of 44â€”they had all to pass through my handsâ€”the police afterwards took me down to New Sun Sufferance Wharf, and there I saw 12 bundles of goats' skinsâ€”they were then packed in gunny bags instead of tied with ropeâ€”I counted them, and found there were 715 skins, or five short of 720 that there ought to have been in six balesâ€”they were of the same kind and character as part of the consignment by the Cameo, and I have no doubt they are part of the missing cargo.

Cross-examined. The number in the bales does not vary with this mark; they always contain one quantityâ€”the bales I saw at this wharf were differently branded to the bales I receivedâ€”those I saw were packed in a very clumsy way; a packer would know his businessâ€”I have no doubt they were Norwegian goat-skins.
Re-examined. I examined them and counted them one by one, and I have no doubt the twelve bundles are part of the forty-four bales.

GEORGE NESBITT . I live at 10, Fenchurch Street Avenueâ€”we had a consignment of 44 bales of goats' skins, only 38 arrived in my possessionâ€”I inspected some skins in the custody of the police and have com
pared them with the 38 balesâ€”I am of opinion they are exactly the same.
Cross-examined. A letter would show the exact number I should receive, and I have the letter hereâ€”I had to pay for 44 bales.

NATHANIEL CHITTENDON . I carry on business as a colonial merchant at 72, Mark Laneâ€”I have known the prisoner about five yearsâ€”on one occasion I took in one letter for him at that address, but he has nothing whatever to do with that addressâ€”he is a dealer in various kinds of goodsâ€”I knew he had a residence in New Oxford Street, but I don't know what business he hadâ€”he came to me by himself either on the 19th or 20th, and brought a sample goat skin with him, and asked me if I could sell seven bales of goats' skins; I said I dare say I could, and

asked him where they were to be seen, whether they were at a public wharfâ€”he said "No, they were not"â€”I said that I could not deal with him unless they were put at a public wharf and open to public inspection, because I couldn't buy them by seeing one skin, I wanted to see the bulkâ€”he then asked me if I knew of a public wharf to take them toâ€”I took him to the office of Messrs. Wright Brothers, the owners of the New Sun Sufferance Wharf, and introduced him to Mr. Wright, and I heard an arrangement made between them that these bales of goats' skins were to be sent to their wharfâ€”he wanted 2s. 8d. a skin for themâ€”I left him with Mr. Wright, and he shortly afterwards came to my office and asked me for a form of order, and wrote this out. (This was dated 20th August, 1886, and was from A. Barker, 72, Mark Lane, to Messrs. Wright Brothers, New Sufferance Wharf, Ratcliff Cross: "Gentlemen, Please receive from me 12 bales of goat skins.") When it was written out I think 7 was put there, it has now been altered to 12â€”I wrote it out at his requestâ€”I am quite sure I did not put in 12 balesâ€”the sample skin was left with meâ€”I never put my signature to that orderâ€”this dock warrant was afterwards left at my house. (This was from the New Sun Sufferance Wharf, and was the receipt for 12 bales of goats' skins imported by land carriage, and entered by A. Barker on 21st August.) I got this docu
ment from Wright's; it has been altered since and is now signed by Barker. (This was on one of Messrs. Wright's forms, New Sun Wharf, to A. Barker, 72, Mark Lane, and stated: "Received on warrant number 469 for 12 bales of goats' skins.") I declined to buy themâ€”I offered them for him, and was unable to get his price, and I then suggested they should go into a public saleâ€”the sample he brought to me was taken awayâ€”I am the only person the prisoner saw in this transactionâ€”he did not tell me at any time where he got them from or what ship they came by.

Cross-examined. He left it in my discretion as to where or how I should sell themâ€”I could have gone to any houseâ€”he did everything quite openlyâ€”I knew him when he was with Skinner and Richardson's wharfingers, and I had dealings with them through him, and he has kept up the connection with me sinceâ€”the houses I went to thought the price per skin was too muchâ€”he didn't tell me to sell them for what I could getâ€”he fixed a price.

JOHN THORNHILL . I am a clerk to Mr. Chittendonâ€”I remember his signing the receipt to the dock warrant, and I erased it because he signed it in mistake for some other letters I put before himâ€”I then got the prisoner to sign it, and sent it to Mr. Wright.

THOMAS WRIGHT . I am in partnership with my brother at 24, Mark Lane, and are the proprietors of New Sun Sufferance Wharf, Ratcliffâ€”on Thursday, 19th August, Mr. Chittendon came and introduced the prisoner to me, who represented he had some bales of goats' skins, and wanted to put them in my wharfâ€”he did not say where he had got them from, and I never knew him beforeâ€”I agreed that he should put them in the wharfâ€”on the following day, the 20th, he brought me this memo
randumâ€”I think the "12" was not on it then, I couldn't be positiveâ€”on the 21st they were delivered at my wharf in a vanâ€”I used this usual wharfinger's warrant for the 12 balesâ€”this receipt for the warrant was signed by the prisoner and afterwards delivered to meâ€”after the inquiry took place about this matter the police took charge of these bales, and
they were removed, that is all I know of the transactionâ€”I was not at the wharf when they were delivered.

ARTHUR FOX . I am a member of the firm of Pearce and Co., morocco leather manufacturers, of Bloomsbury Streetâ€”on 31st August a man named Dalby, whom I saw at the police-court, brought a sample goat skin, and I had a conversation with him about purchasing them, and I finally agreed to purchase them under the instructions of the police for 2s. a skinâ€”on 7th September Dalby brought the delivery-warrant; I communicated with the police at onceâ€”I knew they were trying to trace these goods which Dalby was endeavouring to sell to me.
Cross-examined. Dalby said the skins were consigned to him.

SAMUEL DALBY . I carry on business at 10, Chequer Street, St. Luke's, as a colonial merchantâ€”I formerly carried on business at 5, Leadenhall Street, in the boot and shoe tradeâ€”on 31st August Barker, who I had never seen before, was introduced to me by Mr. Drummond, and spoke to me about the sale of some goat skins; he said he had 1,700, and there was a sample of them in George Yard; that is in Fenchurch Street, and belongs to Mr. Drummondâ€”I went and looked at it, and took possession of it, and afterwards arranged to sell these goats' skins for Barkerâ€”ultimately I went to Messrs. Pearce and Co., of Bloomsbury Street, and the skins were sold to them, subject to their approving of themâ€”afterwards Barker said there were not 1,700, only 710, and I wrote this letter to Messrs. Pearce correcting itâ€”I was to have 2s. a skin for themâ€”Barker after-wards brought the dock warrant so that I might deliver; I only acted for himâ€”immediately on my receiving the warrant I took it to Messrs. Pearce, so that they might inspect the skinsâ€”I was afterwards taken in custody, and I then told the police what I have stated to-day, and I was taken before the Magistrate and explained the matter to him, and I was dischargedâ€”I was to give the prisoner 1s. 9d. a skin, and Messrs. Pearce were to give me 2s. a skin, and then they wanted 2 1/2 per cent, discount.

Cross-examined. It was left in my discretion where I went to sell them, I had no restrictionsâ€”I don't recollect Barker telling me the first time he came that he was selling the skins on behalf of a man named Green; I presumed they were his own propertyâ€”it is not true that I told Messrs. Fox that these skins were consigned to me.

GEORGE WRIGHT (Detective Sergeant). On 8th September I took Dalby in custody, and had a conversation with him, in consequence of which I saw the prisoner at Fenchurch Street Station, and said "Mr. Barker, I am a police officer"â€”he said "Yes, I know you are; you were pointed out to me the other day"â€”I said "I" want to speak to you; we had a heavy robbery of goats' skins from a barge either in the dock or on the river between the 17th and 20th of last month, and, if it is true what comes to my knowledge, that you received them"â€”he said "I know nothing about any goats' skins"â€”I said "I am told you know all about them"â€”he said "Well, I don't"â€”I said "Dalby is in custody, and he says that he received the warrant for the release from you"â€”he said "If that is so I will tell you all about it"â€”I said "You can please yourself"â€”he said "I had them of a man named Green"â€”I said "Do you know where Green lives?"â€”he said "No, but he can be found in Leadenhall Street"â€”I said "I have traced them to a wharf in your name the same day they were reported to us stolen"â€”he said "I was speaking to Harry Baldwin when Green came up with

them in a van, and asked me if I could do with them; I said "I will see," and made arrangements with Mr. Wright to have them put in Sun Wharfâ€”I said "Did you ask Green where he got them from?"â€”he said "No, I did not"â€”I said "I have seen the invoice in Mr. Wright's possession; it has been altered from 6 to 12"â€”he said "I don't know anything about that"â€”at the station when he was charged he said he was going to sell them for a man named Green for 1s. 7 1/2 d. each.

Cross-examined. I am the detective in charge of this case, but there are five or six other police officersâ€”I have had to partially collect the evidence in this caseâ€”I do not know a man named Morganâ€”I have taken two witnesses to the Treasury, and one of them named Carr has not been calledâ€”Morgan has not been to the Treasury to my knowledgeâ€”I believe the prisoner gave a description of Greenâ€”Carr is a witness from 5, Leadenhall Streetâ€”the prisoner did not mention the Sussex Tavernâ€”I did not know him before thisâ€”this conversation took place at a railway station about half-past 5 in the afternoonâ€”I made a note of it directly afterwards, which I have here.
DAVID FRANCIS (Police Sergeant). On 9th September I arrested Dalby at his premises, 10, Chequer Street, Burkhill Roadâ€”I produce a goat's skin which has been spoken to in this case.
GEORGE CARR . I am a boat salesman, working for Mr. Robinson, of 5, Leadenhall Streetâ€”he occupies the shop and the back roomâ€”nobody of the name of Green lives there and never did.
Cross-examined. There is only one No. 5 in Leadenhall Streetâ€”the Sussex Tavern is farther down, but the proprietor does not deal in skins; it is a public-house.

DAVID FRANCIS (Re-examined). After Barker was in custody I went to his cell, and the name of Green was mentioned by him, and he gave me a descriptionâ€”I did not say to him "You had better not mention that in Court for fear he should bolt"â€”I took down the description; he gave me no address, nor yet any Christian name, and he gave me no information how I could find Greenâ€”he gave me the height of the man and the colour of his whiskers, and I have endeavoured to find him.

JAMES JOSEPH BALDWIN . I live at 31, Dixon Street, and have known the prisoner five or six years, and have had several dealings with him, and also with a man named Greenâ€”I sometimes go by the name of Harry Baldwinâ€”about the 20th or 21st August I was standing talking to Barker outside Horseferry Wharf, and Green came up with a van with some ropeâ€”my foreman, Johnson, was at the scales at the time; since then he has diedâ€”it was old rope, about 84 lb. of it, and came to 7s.â€”Green then asked me if I was a buyer of skinsâ€”I said I didn't know how the market was going or else I would have speculated in them, but I said "Here is a gentleman knows a lot of City people," meaning "Barker, "and no doubt he will be able to sell them for you"â€”Green then asked me whether Barker was a trustworthy man, and I said "Yes"â€”he said "Was he worth trusting 100l.?"â€”I said "Yes"â€”with that I believe Barker took a sample of the skins off the van and went away with itâ€”he came back in about two hours, and said he had been up to the City, and there was a market for themâ€”Green was present thenâ€”he had waited for Barker to come backâ€”he said "You will have to put these goods on a public wharf and get a warrant for them," and

Green said "Very well, do so"â€”as far as I can remember Green said to Barker "You get the warrant out in your name, and I will allow you 1 1/2 d. a piece commission;" he also said "You can take the proceeds, and I will call on you in a week or two and settle it up."

Cross-examined. Barker lives about a quarter of a mile from where we were standing talkingâ€”he also has a wood and stone yard at Bow Commonâ€”he pulls down old houses and gets the materialsâ€”I cannot tell whether it was a one-horse or a two-horse van, or what name was on the vanâ€”I had had one transaction with Green before this; that was 8 cwt. of rope, and came to 8l. 13s. 9d.â€”I understood Green lived at 5, Leadenhall Streetâ€”he had skins and other goods in the vanâ€”the transaction between Green and Barker took place in the open streetâ€”it is not a suspicious thing for a van to stay outside my place with old ropes; sometimes there are 20 or 30 outsideâ€”the first transaction I had with Green was about two months before thisâ€”I can't tell where Green has gone toâ€”I have not seen him sinceâ€”I am manager to my brother.
Re-examined. The two transactions I had with Green were for ready cashâ€”he usually came with the van.

p.hi: The prisoner received an excellent character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

14.
WILLIAM HICKEY (24)
(a soldier), Burglary in the dwelling-house of
James Chuter, with intent to steal.

JAMES CHUTER . I am a bricklayer, of 3, Brazil Mill Cottages, Hounslowâ€”on 29th October I fastened up the house at 10.30 p.m.â€”I came down at ten minutes to sevenâ€”I found an entry had been made by the washhouse window being broken and the door opened, and a bundle of linen had been opened and strewn about the floor.

ALFRED STEELE (Policeman T 143). About 7 a.m on 30th October I met the prisoner coming in the direction of the barracks without hat or beltâ€”I stopped him and asked if he had lost his hatâ€”he said "Yes," but it did not matter, he had two more indoorsâ€”I let him go on, and followed him to the turning leading to the barracksâ€”later on in the evening I was called to the station, where I saw him with several other soldiers and identified himâ€”he was about a mile and a quarter from the prosecutor's when I met himâ€”he was sober.

JOHN ELLIS (Police Inspector T). About 10 a.m. on 30th October I was called to the prosecutor'sâ€”I found how the premises had been enteredâ€”this soldier's cap was handed to me in the kitchen; I went with it to the barracks and said to the prisoner, "Is this your cap?"â€”he said "No, it was lent to me by Private Murphy about three weeks ago, and I have not returned it to him since"â€”I said, "Is this the cap you wore last night?"â€”he said, "Yes, I wore it down the town"â€”I said, "Did you lose it?"â€”he said, "Yes, I went fighting with another man at the Rose and Crown public-house and lost my cap"â€”I told him I should charge him with committing a burglary at the address given between 10 and 6 on the 29th and 30thâ€”he said, "I went down Hounslow town last night and got fighting with another man. I lost my cap during the fight and loft Hounslow about 9.40, returned to the barracks about 10.10, passed the sentry at the gate without my cap, went to my room, and did not leave the barracks again that night."

JOHN BRACKENBURY (Policeman T 133). I went with the inspector to the prosecutor's and examined the premisesâ€”a nuisance had been com
mitted in the coal shedâ€”I found marks on the gate of the next premises, which was smeared with coal dustâ€”when the prisoner was arrested I saw that hid coat was smeared with coal dust in several placesâ€”I asked him how his tunic came in such a state; he made no replyâ€”his hands were also smeared with coal dust; he said he had been carrying coalsâ€”he had a recent cut between two of his fingers and on the tip of his nose.
RICHARD RAY . I am a private in the Royal Engineersâ€”on 29th October I was in barracks from 10 to 12; the prisoner did not pass me in that time.
Witnesses for the Defence,
WILLIAM LEGROBE . I am a sergeant in the depotâ€”on 29th October, about 10.10, the prisoner answered to his name as I called the roll, and I sent him to his room.
Cross-examined. He might have left the barracks after that, there was nothing to prevent himâ€”he was sober; I could not say whether he had on his cap or not.

WILLIAM SOUTHEY I am a privateâ€”about a quarter to 10 on this night I and the prisoner had a quarrel and I knocked his cap offâ€”I saw him in the barrack room next morning about a quarter past seven, up and dressed.
Cross-examined. I slept in the next cotâ€”I could not swear to the time; when I let myself in the lights were out.
Prisoner's Defence. As to breaking into this house, it is net likely I should put my cap on a shelf six feet high; I might as well have stopped there myself.
NOT GUILTY .

15.
WILLIAM HADE (32)
, Feloniously wounding
William Brown, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM BROWN . On 3rd November I was in the tramp ward of the Uxbridge Union; the prisoner was there alsoâ€”on the night of the 2nd we had some words and I struck him twice; he did nothing to me thenâ€”I left the Union next morning; on the road I overtook him and asked him which was the right road to Watfordâ€”he said I was to come on, and he turned round and struck me on the top of the head with a razorâ€”my eyes were blinded with blood; I caught hold of him and threw him downâ€”I got up again and he knocked me down again and got on the top of me; he had the razor in his hand, and he attempted to cut my throatâ€”I tried to knock his hand away; I received a cut across my faceâ€”no one else was there at the timeâ€”two others came to my assistance; the pri
soner got up and ran away, and they ran after him and caught himâ€”I returned with them to the workhouse, and have been attended by the medical officer ever since up to last Sundayâ€”I had not offered any pro
vocation to the prisoner that morningâ€”I struck him on the Tuesday night because of the violence he used to me on Mondayâ€”he then struck me and threatened to do for me with the razorâ€”he said it was a bâ€”good job he had not the razor in his hand then or I should have been a dead man.
JAMES SMITH . I was in the tramp ward at the Uxbridge Union, and left on the morning of 3rd Novemberâ€”I saw the prisoner and Brown

struggling in the roadâ€”when I got up to them Brown was on the ground and the prisoner on top of him with a razor in his handâ€”I put my foot on his wrist to keep the razor down on the groundâ€”Brown got up and told him to go away or he would be murdering himâ€”the prisoner then got up and ran away; I called Trinder to come and helpâ€”I ran after the prisoner and caught him, and took him back to the Unionâ€”I saw blood coming down Brown's face.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not see Brown strike you when in the Union; I heard a dispute between you the night before.

THOMAS TRINDER . On the morning of 3rd November I left the Unionâ€”when I got outside I saw the two men on the ground strugglingâ€”I stopped a moment or two, when Smith sang out, "Help, here is a man cutting another with a razor"â€”I saw streams of blood running down Brown's faceâ€”I ran after the prisoner; he said, "It's no use running after me"â€”I caught him and took him to the Unionâ€”he said, "What is it to do with you?"â€”I said, "A great deal, seeing a poor man served in that way"â€”I asked him for the razor; he put it in his pocket and it was taken out of his pocket at the workhouse.
Prisoner. You gave me a kick in the head.
Witness. I did not.

WILLIAM RAYNER, M.R.C.S . I am medical officer of the Uxbridge Unionâ€”on 3rd November I was summoned to the workhouse to see Brownâ€”he had three cuts; one on the top of the head, about 3 inches long; one across the face, cutting through the edge of the nose, about 4 inches long; and a third on the buttock, about 1 1/2 inches longâ€”they were inflicted by some sharp instrument, such as a razorâ€”they were not in themselves dangerous unless erysipelas had come onâ€”they are healed now, and he is well.

CHARLES HAWKINS . I am master of the Uxbridge Unionâ€”on the morning of 3rd November, about 5 minutes to 3, I heard a disturbance, went to the front door, and saw the prisoner in custody of Trinderâ€”I also saw Brown bleeding very much from wounds in the faceâ€”I at once ordered his removal to the infirmaryâ€”I asked the prisoner if he had inflicted the woundsâ€”he said, "Yes, and so would you if you had been attacked the same as I have been"â€”I asked him for the razorâ€”he said, "It is in my waistcoat pocket"â€”I searched his right-hand pocket and found the razor without the caseâ€”I examined it, and found spots of wet bloodâ€”I sent for the police, and gave the prisoner into custodyâ€”I saw that the prisoner's face was slightly discoloured under the eye, as if there had been a blow thereâ€”nothing was reported to me of any occurrence in the casual ward the night before.

MICHAEL PENNYFOLD (Policeman X 359). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said, "I don't deny it, and if you had seven or eight set on you the same as I had you would have done the same; if I had been armed with a revolver I would have shot the lot."

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I plead guilty. I con
sider, having a body of men starting on me, I was quite justified in law in defending myself. I was knocked down and kicked by one of the witnesses while I was fighting with the prosecutor, and I felt justified in using the razor in self-defence."

GUILTY
of unlawfully wounding. â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

16.
MOSES ROCKMAN (36) and
CHARLES DAVIS (34)
, Stealing four overcoats, a waistcoat, and two pieces of cloth of
Samuel Steletoke and another, the masters of Rockman.

ROCKMAN
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.
MR. GOODRICH Prosecuted; MR. GEOGHEGAN defended Davis.

HENRY BIRD (City Policeman 899). On 23rd October, about 5.30 p.m., I was on duty in Houndsditchâ€”I saw Rockman carrying three brown-paper parcelsâ€”he went into the Sir John Falstaff public-houseâ€”a few minutes afterwards Davis came out of Cutler Street into Houndsditchâ€”he stopped and addressed me, and said, "Halloa, young Joe, how do you get on?"â€”I said, "All right"â€”I saw Rockman look out of one of the compartments of the public-house; Davis nodded his head at the same time, saying to me, "Come up, old buffalo, I will treat you"â€”Rockman returned into the public-houseâ€”I went and looked through an aperture into the compartment where the two prisoners wereâ€”I saw Rockman undo a brown-paper parcel and take out four overcoats and hand them to Davis, who put them into a sack that he was carrying when I first saw himâ€”I heard no conversationâ€”I went away for assistance, and com
municated with another constable, and when Davis came out I pointed him out, and he stopped him, and I took Rockman into custodyâ€”at the station, after Davis gave an explanation, Rockman said, "It is true, I let him have them to sell for me"â€”I afterwards searched Davis's house, and found a sheet of brown paper resembling the sheet that I took possession of at the public-house.

Cross-examined. I mean that one sheet of brown paper looked like anotherâ€”there is an old clothes exchange about 50 yards from the public-house; some dealers use the public-houseâ€”Davis knows me; I was in uniform.

JOSEPH PHIPPS (City Policeman 882). Bird called me and made a communication to me, in consequence of which I watched the Sir John Falstaff public-houseâ€”I saw Davis leave the house with a sack on his shoulderâ€”I said, "Davis, what have you got in that sack?"â€”he said, "Some old clothes"â€”I said, "I believe you have got some new ones there which you have just received from a man in the public-house across the road, you will have to stop here a few minutes," and when I saw Bird with Rockman I said, "You will have to come on to the station with me and be charged with unlawful possession"â€”he said, "Jesus Christ, Joe, you don't mean to say that? I have got a wife just confined at home"â€”on the way to the station he said, "A man over at the public-house gave them to me to sell for him"â€”they were both charged at the stationâ€”Davis said that Rockman had given him the coats to sell for himâ€”Rockman said that he made the coats and bought the pieces in the Lane, and gave them to Davis to sell.

SAMUEL STELETOKE . I am a wholesale clothier, 20, Newcastle Street, Whitechapelâ€”Rockman was in my employment as a sorterâ€”these four overcoats are mine, and were stolen from my place on 23rd October.

FREDERICK RYDER ADAMS . I am manager of the Bell Tavern, Middle sex Streetâ€”I know the prisoners as customers; Rockman has frequently been there, and Davis on two or three occasions; I have seen them there together.
Cross-examined. The Clothes Exchange is about 200 yards from my houseâ€”Rockman has left parcels at my house.

DAVISâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

17.
ARTHUR REYNOLDS SCHIRGES
PLEADED GUILTY
to forging and uttering a cheque for the payment of 200l.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude ,

18.
WILLIAM TABB (54)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, having other counterfeit coin in his possession.

WILLIAM STEAD . I am a barman at the London Coffee House, 42, Ludgate Hillâ€”on November 3rd, about 7.30 p.m., I served the prisoner with some soda-water, price 2d.â€”he put down a shilling; it was very light, and I broke it in two with my teeth and said "Do you know what you have given me?"â€”he said "No; did I give you that?"â€”I said "Yes"â€”he said "I will give you another"â€”I had thrown the pieces on the counter; he took them up, put them into his mouth, and gave me a shilling, which was also badâ€”I called Mr. Jones, the land
lord, and handed him the coinâ€”I waited outside about two minutes and no policeman passedâ€”the prisoner came out and said that he was going awayâ€”I said that he would have to stop; another barman came out and we held him; he struggled violently, and said "Give me one chance "â€”he spoke distinctlyâ€”we gave him in custody.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I had to take the first shilling to the desk to get change, but not out of your sightâ€”you appeared to have been drinking, but you walked straight enoughâ€”I saw mud on your hatâ€”you did not pick out the second coin, you put your hand in your pocket and threw it down without hesitation.

ALFRED JONES . I keep the London Coffee House, Ludgate Hillâ€”on 3rd November, about 7.30, Stead showed me this coin (produced); I put it in my pocket and marked it at the police-station, where I saw this other counterfeit shilling found on the prisonerâ€”I marked both with a cross.
Cross-examined. I thought you had been drinking; you were only served with soda-water.

BURTH COWSTIN (City Policeman 514). I saw the prisoner on Ludgate Hill struggling with Mr. Jones and the barman, in the road, near the London Coffee Houseâ€”he was given into my custody; I took him to the station, searched him, and found a bad shilling in his trousers pocketâ€”I put a "B"; on it, and marked the other "A," and saw Mr. Jones mark them both with a crossâ€”I also found a half-crown, a shilling, five sixpences, a three penny piece, and 15 1/2 d. in bronze, all good; also a pawn-ticket for a silver watchâ€”he gave his address 25, Tyson Place, Dalston Lane.
Cross-examined. You wore struggling with Mr. Jones as well as the barman and potman.
LFREDJONES (Re-examined). I struggled with the prisoner in the street; my barman had then gone back.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector to Her Majesty's Mintâ€”these coins are bad, and from different moulds.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence, stated that he changed a half-sovereign, and was tossing coins with some coster-mongers

in Covent Garden Market, and contended that if he had known that the first coin was bad he would not have been likely to have put down another, and he did not know whether he got the money in his change or from the men with whom he tossed.

div1.p:
GUILTY â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

19.
ARTHUR CHAMBERS (24)
, Unlawfully uttering a medal resembling a sovereign, but of less value, with intent to defraud. Two other Counts calling it a piece of mixed metal. Fourth Count for unlaw
fully obtaining 19s. 8 1/2 d. by false pretences.
MESSRS. WILKONSON and COOKE Prosecuted; MR. GILL Defended.

ANNIE BEAL . I am barmaid at the Clock public-house, Brompton Roadâ€”on 4th November, about 8.30 p.m., the prisoner came in with another man and asked for some ale and a lemon, which came to 3 1/2 d., and handed me this coin, which I supposed to be a sovereign; I put it on the shelf where we keep silver, and gave him 19s. 8 1/2 d. changeâ€”they drank their drink and left, and in about two minutes Mr. Price, the manager, made a communication to me, and went out and brought the prisoner back with a constable in about five minutesâ€”I have known him live weeks as a customer.

Cross-examined. I have only been there five weeksâ€”I knew both the men as customers, seeing them nearly every dayâ€”when the prisoner came back he did not deny that he was the person who had been thereâ€”he put the coin on the counter after he was served, and I put it where the silver was, to replace the change.

GEORGE PRICE . I am manager to Albert Price, landlord of the Clock House, Brompton Roadâ€”on November 4th, about 8.15 p.m., I was in the bar, and the prisoner came in with another man; they were there two or three minutes, and I saw the prisoner leave but not the otherâ€”about three or four minutes afterwards I looked at the money which had been taken and found this coin on the shelf where silver is kept; there was no other gold coin thereâ€”I examined it and found it was a Hanover medalâ€”I spoke to Miss Beal and went out and found the prisoner at the Fulham Bridge public-house, 150 yards off, talking with other menâ€”I did not notice whether he was drinkingâ€”I said I want you back at the Clock"â€”he said "What for?" and came outâ€”as we went back he said "Look here, George, I have done it for a joke 'â€”as I had said nothing to him about the charge I said "Done what in a joke?"â€”I do not know what answer he madeâ€”we met Policeman Price who went with us, and I asked Miss Beal whether the prisoner was man who gave her the coinâ€”she said "Yes," and the prisoner told the landlord that he did it for a larkâ€”I gave him in custody with the coinâ€”I have known him as a customer during the four months I have been there.

Cross-examined. Mr. Pearce is my uncleâ€”the prisoner has used the house for I think he says, nine yearsâ€”he lives nearâ€”knew him as Arthur: I did not know his surnameâ€”I said "I want you to come backâ€”he said "What for?â€”I said "You know what is for," and he said "I only did it for a joke, George"â€”he did not deny it in the barmaid's presence.

WILLIAM PRICE (Policeman B 428). The prisoner was given into my custody, and I searched him, and found a half-sovereign, a half-crown, three florins, a shilling, and fourpence, and Mr. Price handed me this

Hanoverian medalâ€”on the way to the station he said "I did it for a joke," and afterwards he said that he did it for a betâ€”I marked the coin with a cross with my knifeâ€”he gave his correct address, 33, Cadogan Placeâ€”this is the coin; it is the colour of a sovereign, but very light.
Cross-examined. I have known him 10 or 12 yearsâ€”I knew him when he was working for Mr. Pring as shop porter, and he worked for a carpet plannerâ€”I never knew anything against him.

GUILTY. on the fourth Count only .â€”
Judgment respited.

20.
CHARLES SMITH (18)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice within 10 days.

GEORGE CLARKE . I keep a coffee-house at 11, Spring Street, Maryle boneâ€”the prisoner came in on a Saturday, about the last week in September, for a cup of tea, price 1 1/2 d.â€”he gave me a shilling; I took it to the back, and bit it nearly in twoâ€”I then went back, and said "How many more have you?"â€”he seemed surprised, and said "What do you mean?"â€”I said "You know what I mean; I have had some more of your gang in, and we have already taken one bad shilling"â€”he said "I did not know it was bad,' and gave me three halfpenceâ€”I threw the coin on the tableâ€”he took it up, and took it awayâ€”I went out to look for a policeman, and he left his tea, and was out almost as soon as I wasâ€”I picked him out last Thursday from other men at the police-court.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not walk by you before I picked you out; there were other men round the cornerâ€”it was at an angle, but I did not go round, it was not necessaryâ€”I walked straight up to you, and said "That is the man."

MARTHA REEVES . My husband keeps an eel-pie shop at 57, Padding
ton Streetâ€”on, I think, Monday fortnight I was in the kitchen under the shop, and my little girl who was serving in the shop called out to me, and asked me for change for a half-crownâ€”I had not got it, and told her where to go for it.
Cross-examined. I did not see you that day, but I have seen you there before.

KATE REEVES . The last witness is my motherâ€”on 8th November I was in the shop, and the prisoner came in for two penny pies, and put down a half-crownâ€”I asked him if he had smaller change, and he said noâ€”I called out to my mother, and asked her if she had got changeâ€”she said no, and was coming up from the kitchenâ€”I told the prisoner I would go and get changeâ€”he picked up the half-crown and ran awayâ€”I had not picked it up.

ELIZABETH WILLINGALE . My husband keeps a general shop at 10, Union Street, Lisson Groveâ€”on the night of 13th November the prisoner came in for twopenny worth of bread and cheese, and gave me a shillingâ€”I put it in the till, where there was no other shilling, and gave him a sixpence and fourpenceâ€”two or three minutes afterwards I found it was bad, and gave it to a detectiveâ€”this is it.
Cross-examined. You did not give me a sixpence; it was a shilling, and I gave you the only sixpence I had.

HENRY DARBY (Policeman D 85). I saw the prisoner enter Mr. Willin
gale's shopâ€”he came out eating some bread and cheeseâ€”I said "I shall arrest you for uttering a counterfeit coin at Mr. Priest's, 11, Circus

Street, on Friday, the 12thâ€”he said "All right"â€”I took him to the station, where Mrs. Willingale's daughter and Kate Reeves picked him out from among other menâ€”I found on him a sixpence and fourpenceâ€”he gave his address, 46, East Street, which I found correctâ€”that is in the same neighbourhood.
CLARA WILLINGALE . I live with my motherâ€”I went into the shop behind the prisonerâ€”I went to the station with my mother and identified him.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector to Her Majesty's Mintâ€”this is a bad shilling.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I do not know the shop, and was never in the shop in my life. I gave sixpence to Mrs. Willin
gale, and she gave me fourpence change."

GUILTY
on the third and fourth Counts. â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

21.
WILLIAM MURRAY (50) and
HARRY JACKSON (32)
, Un
lawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

JAMES HANKAN . I am a news agent and tobacconist, of 8, Forest Row, Dalstonâ€”in November, at 3 p.m., Murray came in for half an ounce of shagâ€”my mother served him, and I saw a shilling on the counterâ€”I told him it was badâ€”he said "I have been at work cabinet making this morning, and received 2s. in payment"â€”he put the shilling back in a tin box from which he had taken itâ€”I gave him the changeâ€”I saw Jackson looking in at the window, and a third party was watching on the other side of the roadâ€”the two prisoners went into the Hope Tavern and the other man followedâ€”I went to the police-station and gave informationâ€”I went with Buckle into the Queen's Road, and was present when the prisoner was' arrestedâ€”I marked the shilling with a crossâ€”this is it.

Cross-examined by Murray. You had a tin box in your handâ€”I did not pull the tobacco out of your handâ€”I said "Do you want the tobacco or not? perhaps you have no more money," and you said that you had another shilling in your box.
Cross-examined by Jackson. I have books and periodicals in my window, and you were looking between them.

CHARLES HEPBURN . My father keeps the Hope Tavernâ€”on 16th October the two prisoners came in, and Murray called for a pint of ale and tendered a shilling which looked suspicious, and I kept it in my hand, and gave him a sixpence and fourpenceâ€”I showed it to my father and then went back to Murray, threw it on the counter, and said "This is a bad shilling"â€”he said "I hope it is not, for I have only got 2s. in my possession for some work I have done, and it would be very hard for me"â€”I returned it to him and said "You will be able to get another for it"â€”he gave me a good oneâ€”I afterwards went to the station and heard Murray say, "We have not been into any public-house"â€”this is the same shilling (produced).

JAMES BUCKLE (Policeman J 441). I received information from Hankan, who went with me to Queen's Road, where we saw the prisonersâ€”I said "You have been to this man's shop and passed a bad shilling "â€”Murray said "What are you talking about?"â€”I said "You will both have to go with me to the station"â€”I took them there, searched them,

and found on Murray this tin box, a sixpence, fourpence, and this bad shilling (produced)â€”I only found a knife on Jacksonâ€”I charged them with passing a bad coinâ€”Murray said "I deny it myself"â€”Jackson said nothingâ€”Murray gave his address 4, Dunstan Street, and Jackson 4, London Place.
Cross-examined by Murray. The address you gave me was correctâ€”you went quietly.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling.

GEORGE MURRAY . I am a cabinet-maker, of 35, Boundary Street, Shoreditch, and work for myselfâ€”on the day you were arrested you had no employment, and I asked you to take a washstand and sell it for me, and you were to have all you got for it over 1l., and I received 1l. from you shortly after dinner time that dayâ€”you told me that you had gained 2s. out of itâ€”I advised you to go home, as you had had some drink.

MR. WHEATLEY (Secretary to St. Giles' Mission). I went to your employer, who told me he had no work for you that morningâ€”you had been at work for him continuously up to Saturday eveningâ€”he gave you a good character, and said that he had known you several years, working for him honestly and respectably, and had never known anything wrong of youâ€”a gentleman in Moorfields likewise gave you a character for many years as a respectable, hard-working man.

p.hi: Murray in his defence stated that he got the shilling in change for a florin which he got for selling the washstand for his cousin, and did not know it was bad.
Jackson stated that he went for a stroll with Murray, and saw him put down the shilling, but did not know it was bad.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

22.
WILLIAM ESTALL (24)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ELIZABETH LITTLECHILD . On 24th September I was serving at a bazaar in Cranbourne Street, Leicester Square, kept by Levy Barber, and about 9.30 p.m. the prisoner bought a purse, price 6d., and gave me a bad florinâ€”I said "This is bad"â€”he said "Well, what are you going to do with it?"â€”I said "I shall give you in custody for passing bad money"â€”he said "I had it given to me in Billingsgate Market for pushing a truck"â€”I gave him in custody with the florinâ€”this is it.

HENRY BLAKE (Policeman C 297) The prisoner was given into my charge with this florin (produced)â€”I said "Is this all you have?"â€”he said "Yes, I have no other money"â€”I searched him and found a good florin and a halfpennyâ€”he said he got the coin for pushing a barrow in Billingsgate Market that morningâ€”he was remanded till 30th December, and then discharged.

ALFRED WATERTON . I am barman at the Well and Bucket Tavern, Bethnal Green Roadâ€”on November 6th I served the prisoner with half a pint of ale; he gave me a bad half-crownâ€”I said "This is bad"â€”he said "Oh, is it?" and gave me a good florinâ€”I gave him a shilling, six
pence, and fivepenceâ€”I showed the coin to a man named Davis, who handed it back to the prisonerâ€”it was smooth to the touch and gritty to the teethâ€”my teeth sank in itâ€”it was very light.
WALTER YARDLEY . I am employed at the Buck's Head Tavern,

Bethnal Greenâ€”on 6th November, about 10.15, the prisoner gave me a bad half-crown for a twopenny cigarâ€”I was getting over the counter and he ran out; Jones and I followed him and brought him back, and he was given in charge.

JOSEPH JONES . I was at the Buck's Head and saw Mr. Yardley attempt to get over the counterâ€”I then saw the prisoner and chased him; he put his hand in his trousers-pocket and threw something which I did not see, but it jingled in the gutterâ€”I took him back to the houseâ€”the gutter was searched, but nothing was found, as there was so much water.
SAMUEL YARLEY . I keep the Buck's Headâ€”on November 6th my son showed me a bad half-crown after the prisoner was brought backâ€”I gave it to the constable with two others which I had taken.

CHARLES FARMER (Policeman). I took the prisoner, and Mr. Yardley marked the half-crown and gave it to meâ€”I searched him, and found a florin, 11 shillings, four sixpences, and 3s. 2 1/2 d. in bronze, all goodâ€”as soon as I got outside a man and woman attempted to get the prisoner from me.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This half-crown and florin are counterfeit.

GUILTY .â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

23.
JOHN JONES (60) and
THOMAS MARTIN (34)
, Stealing from the person of
William Hornsby a purse, a metal token, a quarter-anna, and 9s., his money.
