MR. CLUER Prosecuted; MR. KEITH FRITH defended Martin.

SAMUEL LYTHALL (City Detective Sergeant). On the evening of 22nd October I was in Bishopsgate Street with Outramâ€”we watched the prisoners and saw them turn into Clark's Passageâ€”Martin looked in all the five doors of the Magpie and Punch Bowl, Jones being immediately behind himâ€”they then entered by the second door in Bishopsgate Street, and in 10 minutes or a quarter of an hour Jones came out with Hornsby and turned into Clark's Placeâ€”immediately after this Martin came out and followed them into Camomile Street and joined them, and they went into a private compartment in the Saracen's Head, where they remained about half an hourâ€”on coming out they stood at the end of the court, and the prisoners appeared to have some difficulty in getting rid of the prosecutorâ€”they walked towards St. Mary Axe, Jones led the prosecutor across the road and against a carrier's cart-wheel standing stillâ€”they left him, Jones crossed underneath the horse's head and went along in the direction of Martin, who had gone back on the opposite side of the streetâ€”they turned into St. Mary Axe, which brought them into Hounds
ditchâ€”I had noticed the prosecutor was very drunkâ€”Sergeant Miles came up and took charge of the prosecutor, and after following them I arrested Jones, and Outram arrested Martinâ€”I brought Jones back to where Martin and Outram were struggling togetherâ€”I had hold of Jones by the left hand and caught hold of Martin by the right handâ€”his right hand was in his right-hand trousers pocketâ€”he endeavoured to get it out, but could not do soâ€”I got this knife out of his pocketâ€”directly I withdrew my hand he withdrew his, and I heard some money fall out on

the pavementâ€”Jones began to struggle with me; I left hold of Martin and Miles came to the assistance of Outramâ€”I conveyed Jones to the station, and the prosecutor came with meâ€”when charged at the station they were searched, and a small brass token and a quarter-anna were found on Martin and some moneyâ€”the prosecutor was unable to give us any
thing definite at all, he first said he had 50s. and then 5s.â€”it was about halt-past 7 when the prisoners were arrested.

Cross-examined by MR. FRITH. No money that could be identified by the prosecutor was found in Martin's possessionâ€”the token was sold in the streets a few weeks ago; it has the Lord's Prayer on itâ€”I do not know that two of the tokens were found on Martinâ€”I did not see the prisoner's hand in the prosecutor's pocketâ€”the inspector asked the prosecutor how much he had lost, and he at first said 18s., then 15s., and then 5s., and then he did not know how muchâ€”he knew he had lost his purse, but not where, or who had taken itâ€”he said he had seen it when he went into the public-houseâ€”the purse has not been found.

WALTER OUTRAM (City Detective). I was with Lythall watching the prisonersâ€”I arrested Martinâ€”I said "lama police officer, I shall take you into custody for being concerned with another man in robbing a young man who was drunk"â€”he struggled hard to get awayâ€”I pushed him into Houndsditchâ€”he said, "Who are you? do you want to rob me?"â€”I said "No"â€”I said, "I am a police officer"â€”Lythall caught hold of his right hand, and soon after I heard something fall on the groundâ€”I went with them to the stationâ€”I searched Martin, and found in his right-hand trousers pocket some moneyâ€”he said, "That is mine "â€”I said, "How much is there?"â€”he said, "About 11s."â€”I counted it, and found 7s. 9 1/2 d., this small anna, and a tokenâ€”he gave a correct addressâ€”on Jones was found 5d. bronze, but nothing relating to this chargeâ€”Jones gave the address of an empty houseâ€”Martin at the station said he did not know the other man, pointing to Jones.

WILLIAM HORNSBY . I am a clerk, and live at 30, Forest Lane, Stratfordâ€”on 22nd October I was very drunk in Bishopsgateâ€”the two prisoners came into the public-house after meâ€”I had a purse containing between 7s. and 9s. with a quarter-anna and a brass token with the Lord's Prayer written small on itâ€”I am sure this quarter-anna is mine, and that I had it with meâ€”one of the prisoners filled my pipeâ€”I had a watch and chain on, that was safeâ€”I told the inspector after I had had a pipe I came over queer, and do not recollect what occurred after that.

WILLIAM GALLOPN . I am barman at the Magpie and Punchbowl, Bishopsgateâ€”on 22nd October the prosecutor came in, perfectly soberâ€”Martin and Jones came in, and had a conversation with the prosecutor, and ordered drink all roundâ€”the prosecutor was perfectly sober when he left.
GUILTY .

24.
HENRY PRESS (34)
, Robbery with violence on
Michael Handel
chens, and stealing 5s. his money.

MICHAEL HANDELCHENS (Interpreted). I live at 35, Greek Street, and am a tailorâ€”on Friday afternoon, 5th November, I went into a public-house in Parker Street with the prisoner and another manâ€”I paid for beer for thornâ€”they asked me to go to the skittle-alley with them; I said I had no timeâ€”the man with the prisoner felt in my coat pocketâ€”

shortly after I went out of the house; they followed meâ€”the prisoner held me in the street, and the other man opened my overcoat and took 4s. or 5s. out of my trousers pocketâ€”the prisoner held me by the arms, so that I got blue marks on themâ€”on the following afternoon, Saturday, I went to the same public-house with two police officers, where we saw the prisoner, and I gave him in chargeâ€”I swear he is the man that held me while the other robbed me.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You followed me out of the public-house directly after the other.

MARY ANN WILSON . I am landlady of the King's Arms public-house, Parker Streetâ€”I saw the prosecutor, the prisoner, and another man in my house on this afternoon drinking togetherâ€”one of the men asked the prosecutor to go and play at skittlesâ€”I said we did not allow any one in there with drinkâ€”they were both the worse for drink.
Cross-examined. You followed out of my house directly after the other man.

JAMES ENRIGHT (Detective E). On Saturday afternoon, 6th November, I went to the King's Arms, Parker Street, with the prosecutorâ€”I saw the prisoner there, and took him into custodyâ€”I told him I was a police officer, and that he would be charged with being concerned with another in robbing the prosecutor on the previous afternoon, 5th Novemberâ€”he said, "I did have the money"â€”when the charge was read to the prisoner he said, "I will plead guilty"â€”he had been drinking, but was quite sober enough to understand what he said.
GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony in October, 1882.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

25.
CHARLES WILEY (24)
, Robbery with violence on
Peter Stoeri, and stealing a watch, his property.

PETR STEORI I live at 204, City Road, and am an agentâ€”about half-past 12 a.m. on 9th November I was in the City Road with my brother, going home, when I was attacked by a manâ€”I caught hold of him; he tried to throw me on the ground; we went to the ground togetherâ€”I tried to get up, and the prisoner kicked and then knocked me in the eyeâ€”my eye pained me, and I put both my hands up, and then I felt somebody was after my watch, and I looked and saw the prisoner taking it out of my pocketâ€”he gave it to a woman, who ran away with itâ€”I saw my brother run after the prisoner and bring him backâ€”I was quite sober.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You ran the opposite side to the Britannia Roadâ€”my eye pained me so much I did not see where the woman went.
Re-examined. The woman was charged at the police-court and fined 10s. or seven days for assault on the police.

BELTHASAR STOERI I am a brother of the last witnessâ€”on the morning of 9th November I saw him knocked down, and I saw the prisoner run awayâ€”I ran after himâ€”he knocked me down, but he was captured by the police directly after.
Cross-examined. I did not see you steal the watch, nor did I see the woman.
WILLIAM SPARROW (Policeman G R 35). On 9th November I saw the

prisoner in the City Roadâ€”he struck the prosecutor with his fistâ€”the prosecutor got up and made a complaint to me, and I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”the woman was also taken into custodyâ€”she was after-wards dealt with by the Magistrate.

Cross-examined. The struggle began on the other side of the City Road, and you struck him in the middle of the roadâ€”I came across as soon as I couldâ€”you tried to get awayâ€”you did not have a chance to run.

JOHN LODGE . (Policeman G 240). I saw a crowd and a struggle between the prisoner and the prosecutor in the City Roadâ€”I assisted to take the prisoner to the stationâ€”I searched him in the City Roadâ€”I did not find the watch on himâ€”he said a woman had it, he had not had it.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he was walking along with his wife when the man ran up and charged him with stealing his watch.

div1.p: PETER STOERI (Re-examined). I was wearing an overcoat; it was open, and my chain hung from my waistcoat so that everybody could see it.

GUILTY .â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

26.
GEORGE GOODY (28)
, Robbery with violence on
Henry Jackson, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.

HENRY THOMAS DE PLEDGE (Policeman D 451). I was in Queen Street at half-past 7 a.m. on 20th October, and saw the prisoner with four others speaking to Mr. Jacksonâ€”two out of the five caught hold of each side of his arm, and took him to Newton Streetâ€”I followed, and saw the prisoner strike him a blow behind the ear and knock him down, and immediately jump on the top of him, while another man not in custody snatched his watch and chain, and they immediately ran awayâ€”I followed the man who had taken the watch, but failed to catch himâ€”I returned and saw the prisoner picking the prosecutor upâ€”I was about three yards off when I saw the prisoner strike the prosecutorâ€”the prosecutor came to the station with me and signed the charge-sheet; I have made inquiries, but he gave a false name and address, and I cannot find him.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not take you into custody; I told another constable to do so.
By the JURY. I am perfectly certain the prisoner is the man I saw knock the prosecutor down.

EMMA NEAL . On the morning of 20th October I was at the corner of Newton and Parker Streets, and saw the man knocked down, and the prisoner held him while the other men robbed himâ€”I was going by to get a clean apron, and saw the prisoner then picking up the man that had been robbedâ€”I was close to themâ€”I said "Is it you?" and he kicked me.
Cross-examined. I saw the man robbedâ€”he was lying downâ€”you all knocked him down, and you held him by the shoulders while the others ran up King Streetâ€”I did not see you hit him.

JOHN BOVEY (Policeman E 359). I saw this scuffle in Parker Street, and went towards the peopleâ€”I saw two or three men run away and the prisoner lifting the prosecutor upâ€”I took him into custodyâ€”I was about 100 yards off when I saw the occurrenceâ€”I saw three or four men run away; they scattered in different partsâ€”I did not see the girl till I got to the station.

GEORGE SEABRIGHT (Policeman E 18). I was at Bow Street on the morn
ing of 20th October, when the prisoner was brought thereâ€”shortly after-wards a gentleman came in, who said in the prisoner's presence that he had been robbed of a watch and chain, value 7l. but that he did not want to have much to do with the affair, as he had been drinking with the prisonerâ€”the prisoner said he had been drinking with himâ€”I asked the prisoner his occupationâ€”he said a hopper.

p.hi:
The prisoner in his defence stated that he saw four men set on the prose
cutor and rob him, and that he shoved them off and picked him up.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

rs.hi:
He was further indicted with assaulting
Annie Neal.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

27.
HENRY WILLIAMS (18)
PLEADED GUILTY .
to attempting an abominable crime with a mare.â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour. And

28.
JOHN GOOLD (25)
to stealing a purse and fourpence, the goods and money of
Mary Ann Turner, from her person, after a conviction of felony in August, 1884, in the name of John Carley.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

29.
THOMAS JOYCE (53) and
JOHN THOMAS MCLOUGHLIN (33)
, Robbery with violence on
Edward Rutter, and stealing five shil
lings from his person.
MR. SAUNDERS Prosecuted,

EDWARD RUTTER . I live at 6, Alfred Place, Bedford Squareâ€”on 30th August last, between half-past 8 and 9 o'clock, I was passing through Russell Street, Covent Garden, and was tripped up from behind by somebody, and in falling my head was struck in some way, and I was rendered partially insensible for two or three secondsâ€”I then found myself lying on the pavement and a man's hands about my waistcoatâ€”I got on my feet and held McLoughlin by the collar, and called for assistanceâ€”Joyce then came up and helped McLoughlin to extricate himself from my graspâ€”I afterwards I found I had lost from five to seven shillings out of my waistcoat pocketâ€”I did not see Mr. Glennie till I was at the stationâ€”the prisoners succeeded in getting away from me, and I identified them at the police-court a few minutes afterwardsâ€”I do not know the Grapes public-house; I was not there that eveningâ€”I had not seen the prisoners before I was assaulted.
Cross-examined by McLoughlin. I did not come into the public-house with two other men and say to you "Have a drink."
Cross-examined by Joyce. You pulled McLoughlin away from me when I was holding him.

GEORGE ICHARD GLENNIE . I am a confectioner, of 290, Strandâ€”on 30th August, about 9 o'clock, I was in Russell Street and heard a cry of "Help! help!"â€”I went to the spot, and saw the prosecutor holding McLoughlin by the throat, and crying "Help! help!"â€”I asked him what was the matter, but he was in such an excited state he could not. answer me, and I found afterwards when he was at the station that he

had an impediment in his speechâ€”I was going to rescue him, only my friend who was with me said "Don't, there is such a lot of roughs about here"â€”I went to the station, and when I came back the prosecutor was lying on the ground with a mob round himâ€”Joyce had pulled McLough
lin away, and they were coming out of the crowdâ€”they dodged about behind the cabsâ€”my friend said "It is all right, it is Claney; it appears he is well known"â€”I went to Bow Street and described the prisoners, and pointed Joyce out as he was standing at the corner of the street as the man who had rescued McLoughlinâ€”I afterwards gave a description of McLoughlin, and he was taken in custody, and I recognised him.

JOSEPH KIRBY . I am a cab proprietor, of 8, Church Street, Clapham Roadâ€”on 30th August last I was the first on the rank in Russell Street, and I saw McLoughlin and the prosecutor running along Russell Streetâ€”they ran behind my cab and the prosecutor slipped upâ€”he got up and ran after the prisoner againâ€”I picked up this stick and ran after themâ€”some one in the crowd then said "Over with him," and they both fell to the groundâ€”the prosecutor held on to the prisoner's legs, but he shook them and ran awayâ€”the prosecutor appeared as if he was stunned for a minute or twoâ€”I saw nothing of Joyceâ€”I gave information to the police.

Cross-examined by McLoughlin. I asked you what you had got belong
ing to the gentleman, and you said "Nothing but a key."

HENRY HIGGINS (Policeman E 254). Mr. Glennie came to the station, and I went and saw the prosecutor outside Hart's public-houseâ€”he made a statement to me, and went back to the station with another constable, and Mr. Glennie gave a description of two men, and about 10 minutes afterwards I saw Joyce in Russell Streetâ€”I said "I shall take you in custody for being concerned with another man not in custody in knocking down a gentleman named Rutter in Russell Street, and robbing him of five shillings or thereabouts"â€”he said "I did not knock him down; I have none of his money"â€”he was searched, and fourpence was found on him.

JOHN IRELAND (Policeman E 183). On the night of 30th August I was sent to Russell Street, and there saw the prosecutor; he was almost insensibleâ€”I assisted the last witness to take Joyce to the stationâ€”I saw McLoughlin at a public-house, and told him I should take him in custody for being concerned with another man in custody in assaulting and rob
bing a man in Russell Streetâ€”he said "All right; I will go with you "â€”I searched him, and found a half-crown and a key on him.
EDWARD RUTTER (Re-examined). I have never seen this key before; it is not mine.

JOYCEâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

McLOUGHLINâ€”
GUILTY .*â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

30.
HENRY WALKER (22) and
THOMAS HENRY WILLIAMS (17)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing a cash-box and 6l. 10s. of
John Barnes Liberty and another.

WALKER also
PLEDED GUILTY
to another in
dictment for stealing a cash-box and 28l. of
Percy Hernon and another. There were five other indictments against the prisoner Walker.â€”WALKERâ€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
WILLIAMSâ€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: For Cases tried in Third Court, Wednesday, see Kent Cases.

div1.p:
31.
HANNAH CORDER (22)
was charged on the Coroner's Inquisi
tion only with the wilful murder of her infant child.
MR. SYMES. for the prosecution, offered no evidence, the Grand Jury having ignored the bill.
NOT GUILTY .

32.
WILLIAM CARTER (18),
WILLIAM HIGGINS (22), and
CHARLES RICHARD HARDING
, for a rape on
Sarah Ann King on 9th September.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. CORRIE GRANT defended Harding.
NOT GUILTY .

p.rs:
There was another indictment against the prisoners for a like offence on
13th September,

rs.hi:
also an indictment against Carter for a robbery with violence on the said
Sarah Ann King and stealing 17 s.

p.hi: Upon these charges no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

33.
ASHTON ARTHUR EDWARD FOLJAMBE BURROWS (33)
, Feloniously shooting at
Alfred Arthur Butcher, with intent to murder Second Count, to do grievous bodily harm.

MR. AUSTIN METCALFE
Prosecuted; MR. GEOGHEGAN Defended.

ALFRED ARTHUR BUTCHER . I am a commission agent, of 31, Senior Street, Harrow Roadâ€”on 19th November, between 9 and 9.30, I was in the Golden Cross bar at Charing Crossâ€”I did not see the prisoner come inâ€”the first thing that drew my attention to him was his placing a cartridge on the counter; he did not say anything when he did soâ€”I said I thought it a strange thing to put on the counter of a public-house, and I said "I think it is a revolver cartridge"â€”I was standing about a yard away from himâ€”he said "That would be enough to kill you"â€”I turned my head towards him, and saw something bright; he pulled it like from his pocketâ€”I drew back; just drew my head on one sideâ€”I saw the revolver in his hand; he pointed it at me, and it went "bang," and I heard a bottle smash at the back of meâ€”the prisoner was very drunk.

Cross-examined. The bar curves very slightlyâ€”the prisoner had on a great heavy Ulster; he had asked for drink, but was refusedâ€”I had never seen him beforeâ€”I was not struckâ€”directly he put up the revolver it went offâ€”the bottle that was broken was about two yards from my head; to the left of meâ€”the prisoner made no attempt to fire the other chambers of the revolver; he went quietly to the stationâ€”I did not feel the bullet whistle by meâ€”I had a headache.

JOSEPH WISE . I am barman at the Shades of the Golden Crossâ€”I was at the bar when the prisoner came inâ€”he called for something to drinkâ€”the manager refused to serve himâ€”he placed a cartridge on the counterâ€”the prosecutor picked it up, and said "I think that will fit a pistol"â€”a gentleman said "I think it is too large for a Colt's revolver"â€”the prisoner said to the prosecutor "It is large enough to kill you"â€”he then stepped back half-way down the partition, drew a revolver from his right-hand coat pocket, and firedâ€”he was pointing it at the prosecutor, who was standing against the counter; if he had not moved back I believe it

would have hit him; it struck a bottle behind the counterâ€”the prisoner was standing about a yard back from the counter, and about three yards from the bottle, and about a yard from the prosecutorâ€”the bottle was about a foot to the prosecutor's right.
Cross-examined. The prosecutor had his face sideways to the bottle at the time the shot was fired.

GEORGE HOOKER . I am manager to the Golden Cross Shadesâ€”I saw the prisoner come into the bar; I refused to serve himâ€”I then walked away to another part of the bar, while there I heard a report; I turned round and went towards the prisonerâ€”he was then in the hands of the prosecutor and a constableâ€”I afterwards saw the broken bottle; it had been standing on a shelf just above the counterâ€”the shelf was over six feet highâ€”I picked up a flattened bullet immediately under the shelf, and gave it to the inspectorâ€”this is it.
Cross-examined. The prisoner was very much too drunk for me to serve him.

JOHN SWAREY (Policeman E 462). I went to the Golden Cross on hearing the report of firearmsâ€”I saw the prisoner in the bar; he had his hand in his pocketâ€”I held his armsâ€”the prosecutor assisted me, and I took from his right-hand pocket this revolverâ€”it had six chambers; one was discharged, the other five were loadedâ€”the prosecutor said the prisoner had attempted to shoot himâ€”I took him to the station; he was drunk.

JAMES HAYNES (Police Inspector E). I was at the police-station when the prisoner was brought in; I took the charge and read it over to himâ€”he said "I can assure you I did not fire"â€”he was drunk at the time.
Cross-examined. He did not say "I did not fire intentionally," his words were "I assure you I did not fire"â€”this is not an easy trigger to move, I should call it rather hard.
NOT GUILTY .

rs.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner for assaulting the same person,

p.hi: upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

34.
HENRY DEVENISH (17)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice within ten days.
MR. COOKE. Prosecuted.

JOHN BECK . I am waiter at a cook's shop, 19 and 20, Aldgateâ€”on 19th October, between 8 and 9 p.m., the prisoner came in and had some tea and paid for itâ€”he then asked if I wanted change for a half-crownâ€”I said "Yes, if you have got it"â€”he gave me a shilling, a sixpence, and a shillings worth' of coppers, which I put in a bag I carry at my side, which only contained four florins, and gave him a half-crownâ€”as soon as he went outside I found the shilling was badâ€”I put it in my trousers pocket separate from other money, and on the 20th gave it to a constableâ€”this is it (produced).
PETER MATZONI . I am shopman at this cook's shopâ€”on October 20th, between 8 and 9 o'clock, the prisoner came in and asked for a
sausage and bread in a bag, which came to 2d.; he gave me a florinâ€”my governor said "Look at the money"â€”I did so, tried it with my teeth, and broke it, and a constable was sent for.

JOSEPH NANA . I keep this cook's shopâ€”on 20th October the prisoner came in and had a sausage and bread, and Matzoni put a florin between his teeth and broke it, and then showed it to meâ€”it was bad and I gave the prisoner in chargeâ€”he said nothing.

EDWARD MARRIOTT (City Policeman 913). I was called, and Mr. Nana said, "I will have this man locked up for passing this two-shilling bit; last Saturday he passed a bad shilling to one of my chaps"â€”I asked the prisoner what he had to sayâ€”he said "I carried a gentleman's parcel this morning, and he gave me that; I was not near the place on Saturday"â€”I took him to the station, and found on him a good shilling and four good sixpences, which he said belonged to his sisterâ€”the inspector asked him where he livedâ€”he said "In a turning out of Kingsland Road; I don't know the name of the street, it is the first turning on the left past Essex Street, going from Shoreditch Church, and the number is No. 6."â€”that is Fleming Streetâ€”he gave the name Harry Davisâ€”I received this florin and shilling from Mr. Nana.
WILLIAM GRANT . I live at 6, Fleming Street, Kingsland Roadâ€”the prisoner does not live there and never hasâ€”I do not know him.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to Her Majesty's Mintâ€”this florin and shilling are bad.

THOMAS DEVENISH . I am the prisoner's father, and live at 151, Shepperton Road, Islington; he lives with meâ€”on 16th October, about 5.3, he and his brother left home to go to the theatreâ€”they did not tell me, but they they generally go to the Britanniaâ€”they returned about midnight or a little laterâ€”I am a packing-case maker.

ALFRED DEVENISH . I work for my father, and live with himâ€”on October 16th the prisoner and I left home about 5.30 or 5.40, and went to the Britannia Theatre, which is a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes' walk from our placeâ€”we got there about 6.5, and left at 11.40.

Cross-examined. I am a painterâ€”my father asked me on the 20th if I could remember what took place on the 16thâ€”I was not at the police-court, because I went to get some work for my father, and got blocked going home with the barrow, or I should have been thereâ€”I do not go to the Britannia very often, but that is the theatre I generally go toâ€”I cannot tell you where I was on October 9th, the previous Saturdayâ€”no one was with me but my brother, nor did we meet anyone we knewâ€”the pit door opens at 6 o'clock, and the price is 6d.â€”I stayed in the pit from 6 30 to 12, and my brother was with me the whole time.

GUILTY of the second uttering .â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth.â€”
Judgment respited.

35.
GEORGE HODWAY (41)
PLEADED GUILTY
to three indictments for forging and uttering requests for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: highly commended the conduct of the officer Drew.

div1.p:
36.
THOMAS DONELLY (36)
, Fraudently obtaining the sums of 5l. and 10s. from.
Thomas Skelton, with intent to defraud.

p.hi: The prisoner having stated that he wished to withdraw his plea of not guilty, the Jury found him

div1.p:
GUILTY * ( There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)â€”
Twenty Months' Hard Labour.

37.
JOHN TASKER TOLER (70) and
WILLIAM BRYANT (45)
, Fraudulently obtaining 3l. 16s. 6d. and other sums by false pretences. Other Counts for conspiring to defraud divers persons.

FREDERICK WILLIAM BRETT . I am manager to Messrs. Hill and Son, bakers, of 3, Albert Mansions, Victoria Streetâ€”prior to Christmas last I had acustomer on my books named Tasker Tolerâ€”on 30th December the prisoner Bryant brought this letter containing a cheque for 4l.; at that time Toler owed me 3s. 6d. for goods supplied. (This was from Toler, and stated that he enclosed a cheque for 4l. and asked that the 3s. 6d., should be taken from it and the change handed to the bearer.) I believed the cheque was right and handed Bryant 3l. 16s. 6d.â€”the cheque passed through the bankers and was returned marked "N. E."â€”it was drawn on the District Bank of Londonâ€”I enclosed it in a letter addressed to Toler and received this letter from him enclosing another cheque for 4l. upon the same bank, dated January 1st. (This stated that he enclosed another cheque for 4l. in lieu of the one which has not been paid, and that he had overdrawn his account but would take care this one was paid.) It was passed through our bankers and returned dishonouredâ€”I communicated that fact to Toler and wrote to him repeatedly in respect of it; these five letters are some of the com
municationsâ€”a third cheque came, dated 26th January, for our presenta
tion, upon the same bankâ€”I presented it personally and it was returned to me dishonoured; one of the letters requested me to present it person
allyâ€”I have not received a penny on the 4l. cheque; I believed it to be a good one when I received it.

Cross-examined by Toler. I expect the letter was addressed to the firm, it was insideâ€”I never received a letter from you personally, but I can't swear whether I wrote one to youâ€”I got three cheques from you alto
gether; I can't say whether they were crossed or openâ€”the first cheque was returned to you, that I swear; I have not the letter book here, that would show itâ€”the last one was post datedâ€”we are filing County Court proceedings against you; I should think we proceeded against you on the last cheque, not the firstâ€”I gave the solicitors the cheques and instructed them to proceed against you civillyâ€”Detective Cousins called on me, but he did not use all the influence he could to make us join in the prosecu
tion against youâ€”he said nothing to influence usâ€”he asked if we had had any transactions with a man named Tasker Tolerâ€”he found our name by the books at your houseâ€”I did not write to you personally and sign "Frederick William Brett."
Re-examined. The proceedings at the County Court resulted in nothing.

JOHN POWELL (Policeman A 871). I formerly lived at 60, Sussex Street, Pimlicoâ€”Toler lodged there up to September last year, and then leftâ€”he told me he was a wholesale provision merchant in Bartholomew Closeâ€”on 3rd January Toler came to me with this cheque and asked me to cash it. (This was on the District Bank, and dated 2nd January. Payable to self or order, 3l. T. Tasker Toler.) He asked me if I would kindly cash It for him, and I went to a public-house and got it cashed and gave him the 3j. and he went awayâ€”shortly afterwards the publican sent for me

and I found he had got the cheque back marked "No effects," and I had to give him the money back and bear the lossâ€”I then saw Toler in his rooms and handed the cheque to himâ€”he said he would make it all right and would go and see the man who had cashed it for me, as he thought there was a mistake, there was money at the bank and it ought to have been marked "Not sufficient"â€”I have never been able to get the money, and I have had to part with it out of my earningsâ€”I did it to oblige him, as I thought he was an honest man, and I believed it was a genuine cheque and that there was money to meet it.

Cross-examined by Toler. I an not the landlord of the house; I was in charge of itâ€”Mrs. Powell was the housekeeperâ€”it was not any repre
sentations you made at that time that made me cash itâ€”you had been living there 10 or 11 monthsâ€”you have given me cheques before to cash and they have been all rightâ€”you represented that you were a person of noteâ€”I got the cheque cashed on the representations you made to me that you were worth moneyâ€”Mrs. Powell gave me the cheque and I went to the publican's and got it cashedâ€”I did not buy the cheque from him; I gave him the money because I was threatened with a prosecution, and he gave me the cheque back and I am the holder of itâ€”it was crossed.
Re-examined. I believed this was a genuine cheque, and that I should get the money when I went to the bank.
FREDERICK WILLIAM BRETT (Re-examined by Toler). I did not believe that last cheque was a genuine one.

By MR. POLAND. When I gave the change for the first cheque I thought it was genuine, and that it would be paid through the bankers, but having had it returned I thought the last one was not likely to be paid.

WILLIAM GARDINER . I am a grocer, at 25, Gillingham Street, Pim
licoâ€”in April, 1885, I became acquainted with Toler, who sold me small quantities of butter; he said he was a wholesale provision mer
chant, at 50, Bartholomew Close, and that the butter came from Castle
reaghâ€”I dealt with him till September, 1885, paying him from time to time as I had the goodsâ€”the next time I saw him was 19th December, 1885, when he came with Bryant, whom he introduced as a traveler for Stubbs's Agency, and recommended as a straightforward man whom he had known for six or seven yearsâ€”I agreed to subscribe 10s. 6d. to Stubbs's newspaper, and I afterwards received a receipt from Stubbsâ€”on 5th January, 1886, Toler called and purchased grocery to the amount of 6s. 6d., and in payment he wrote this cheque in my presence. (For 2l. 10s., dated 6th January, 1886, on the District Bank of London, and signed T. Tasker Toler.) I told him I had not got sufficient change, but he called again in the evening, and I then gave him 10s., and the balance, 1l. 14s., I gave to Bryant, who called next morning and brought this letter as authority to receive the money. (This was dated, 60, Sussex Street, and requested him to hand the balance to Bryant.) I paid the cheque into my bank, the London and County, and it was returned marked "No effects "â€”almost as soon as that occurred, Bryant came to see meâ€”I told him the cheque had been returned, and that there was nothing to meet it, and that I was going to apply to a Magistrate about itâ€”Bryant said, "Oh, don't do that, I will go and fetch Toler"â€”within three quarters of an hour they both came back togetherâ€”I said "This is a swindleâ€”they said "It seems like it"â€”then they talked me over in a soft-soapy

way, saying "It is all right, don't go to the Magistrate, we don't want you to do that, we will pay you; leave it a day or two"â€”I did so, and made several applications, but never got my moneyâ€”a suggestion was made that I should receive goods, but I said I did not want them, I wanted my moneyâ€”Bryant kept on calling from time to timeâ€”about the end of January I asked him where Toler was, he said he was somewhere about; and he said, "We have got some tea for you, you can hold it as security till we pay you"â€”I sent to Sussex Street for itâ€”he brought back a chest of small packets of tea, which is lying at my place un-openedâ€”I have written to Harrison and Co., from whom it came, and in consequence of what they said I have not opened itâ€”I did not see Toler again till he was in custodyâ€”Bryant used frequently to come about Stubbsâ€”about 22nd or 23rd February he asked me if I had any business for Stubbs, I said yes, and gave him 12s., with reference to Stubbs in connection with Beddingfield, a debtor of mineâ€”Bryant said "I will take it for you"â€”he took it and also some letters I had received from Stubbs's solicitors in reference to the amountâ€”I got no receipt for thatâ€”about fourteen days afterwards Bryant called again, and I paid him 13s. for Stubbs in the matter of Frost and Davisâ€”I received a letter from Stubbs asking me to pay itâ€”I afterwards heard from Stubbsâ€”when I parted with the money for this cheque, 2l. 10s., I believed it was a genuine one, and when I parted with the 12s. and 13s. I believed Bryant was authorised to receive it.

Cross-examined by Toler. I knew you about nine months before Decem
ber, 1885â€”I am not aware that you had transactions with me two years ago; you sold me no cheese thenâ€”I subscribed to Stubbs before thisâ€”you introduced Bryant to me on 19th Decemberâ€”I parted with the 12s. and 13s. to him through your recommending him to me as an honest, trustworthy manâ€”you said he was not so well educated as you were, but very honestâ€”Bryant contracted a debt of 3l. 16s. 9d. by your recommendationâ€”I did not see Cousens till I had applied to the Treasuryâ€”I attended at Westminster on each of the times that you were remandedâ€”you were finally discharged because Bryant was at largeâ€”the Magistrate did not discharge you and Bryant for this very thingâ€”the charge was dismissed until Bryant was arrestedâ€”I found out about Harrison and Co., Cousens did not prompt meâ€”the tea has never been paid forâ€”it was in the Press, and they wrote to me, and I wrote and told them how I had been served, and they replied in the same mannerâ€”I did not swear at Westminster I had my doubts about the chequeâ€”I took up the case on public grounds.

Cross-examined by Bryant. I swear Toler recommended you on Decem
ber 19, 1885, when I joined Stubbs's, and gave you the money for them.

HENRY OLNEY . I am in the employment of Messrs. Stubbs, mercan
tile agents, of 42, Gresham Street, known as the Trade Auxiliary Com
pany, Limitedâ€”on 14th December, 1885, Bryant entered their service, giving as one of his references the prisoner Toler. (Toler's reply to a letter asking for information was read. It stated he had known Bryant for fifteen years, and had always considered him as a persevering and pushing man of business, and that for collecting subscribers or anything akin to it he had few equals.) On 22nd February he was not in our service, having been dis
charged
â€”he did not account for the sums of 12s. and 13s. received from Gardiner.
Cross-examined by Toler. I knew nothing of you previous to this letterâ€”I did not know that you had an office similar to oursâ€”I did not hear of your receiving any money from subscribers.
Cross-examined by Bryant. You handed over 27s. about 18th December in favour of Gardnerâ€”I suppose he would have a receipt for that in the ordinary way.

JAMES AUSTIN . I am a tobacconist and newsagentâ€”in November last Toler owed me an account for newspapers, and brought me this chequeâ€”I gave him 1l. 6s. 6d., the difference between it and what he owed meâ€”within a day or two the cheque was returned marked "no effects"â€”I went to Toler at 60, Sussex Streetâ€”I said to him "The cheque has been returned to me"â€”he said he could not understand that, as there ought to have been money there to meet it, and he expected money would have been paid into the bank to meet itâ€”he afterwards gave me another cheque for the same amount, which I presentedâ€”it was returned to me marked "N. S."â€”I have never received the 1s. 6s. 6d.â€”when Toler gave me the first cheque and I gave him the difference I believed it was a genuine oneâ€”Toler introduced Bryant to me on one occasionâ€”he asked me to cash a cheque for himâ€”I did not do soâ€”the cheque was drawn on the Capital and Counties Bank I believe.

Cross-examined by Toler. I have had other transactions with you, during a short time, and you have paid meâ€”I sued you in the County Courtâ€”I cannot say that I then contemplated these proceedingsâ€”I have done this voluntarilyâ€”I have met Cousens on several occasionsâ€”he did not advise me to come here, and has not influenced me in any wayâ€”I did not know him personally before this caseâ€”I saw you were up at Westminster and came forward of my own accord.
Re-examined. I got judgment against the prisoner; he was to pay me 10s. a monthâ€”I did not get anything.

JOHN BOND . I keep the Foresters' Arms, 220, Vauxhall Bridge Roadâ€”on 11th February Toler and Bryant came to meâ€”I had known Bryant as a customer and I may have seen Toler before; I am not certainâ€”after some conversation on 11th February Bryant produced a cheque for 6l. 2s. 6d., drawn in favour of E. B. Parker, and signed Kempâ€”I afterwards returned the cheque to Bryant, who gave me this receipt for it, and I gave Bryant 6l. 2s. 6d. cash for itâ€”both prisoners were presentâ€”I expressed hesitation about cashing it, and Toler said he knew the drawer of the cheque, and it was right, I need not fearâ€”I tendered it at my bankers, but the endorsement was with an initial only, instead of a full Christian nameâ€”I pointed that out to Bryant; he hesitated, but Toler wrote a fresh endorsementâ€”it was not in Toler's name; I forget the nameâ€”I had given Bryant the cash previouslyâ€”I paid the cheque in on the Saturday, and on the Wednesday it was returned marked "No acct."â€”the day before it was returned Bryant called and gave me this cheque for 3l. 13s. 6d., which was post-dated 17th February, drawn on the District Bank of London in favour of self or order, and signed T. Tasker Toler; it was endorsed by Toler, Bryant, and myselfâ€”I gave Bryant 3l. 13s. 6d.â€”on the next day, the 17th, the first cheque came back to me, and that same evening or the next day Bryant calledâ€”I told him the first cheque had been returned dishonouredâ€”he said "If you will

let me have this cheque I will take it to Kemp; I think it is Chancery Lane, and I will either bring you a fresh cheque or the money," and that he was quite sure they were rightâ€”he pretended that it was a mystery to him why it had come backâ€”I gave him the cheque and he gave me this receiptâ€”on the 19th the second cheque which I had paid in came backâ€”I saw Bryant afterwards, and he told me I need not trouble, it would be all right, and that he would endeavour to get the moneyâ€”when I cashed the first cheque I believed it was genuine, and when I took the second I believed the first had passed through all right.

Cross-examined by Toler. Bryant introduced you to me; you were never in my house before to my knowledgeâ€”I did not know but what you were a genuine manâ€”Bryant offered to sell me coals, and an iron safe, and soonâ€”I might have parted with the money to Bryant on his own respon
sibility if you had not been with himâ€”the cheque was first returned because the endorsement was not right, and when you called two or three days afterwards you wrote a name which was sufficient for the bank to cash the chequeâ€”I did not know Gardiner before this case; I am intimate with him nowâ€”I was at Westminster when he prosecuted you, a good many timesâ€”I had a warrant out for Bryant, who had disappeared; not for you thenâ€”the case against you was dismissedâ€”you told me outside the Court I need not fear, I should have the moneyâ€”I did not, and I joined in the prosecution as soon as possibleâ€”the 3l. 13s. 6d. cheque was post-dated; you were not there, I think, when it was presentedâ€”I understood Bryant had taken the 6l. 2s. 6d. cheque from Gilbert Kemp, and went to him for the money or a fresh cheque to bring to me, and in the evening Kemp came to me saying he was not able to let me have the money then, but that some was coming to him very soon, and would I hold some parchments and leases he had in his bag till the money was paidâ€”I said "I don't want to have anything to do with the papers; if you are a genuine man in an honest business, living and carrying on business at such a place, I will take your word till the money comes to me to-morrow"â€”I did not see or examine the papersâ€”I had great doubts thenâ€”I did not know that Bryant did not know the drawer of the cheque, nor that you had given Bryant the cheque, nor that when you heard it was not paid you took Bryant to the drawerâ€”I afterwards saw Kemp at Westminsterâ€”he said he had paid Bryant the money, but I would have nothing to say to him.

Cross-examined by Bryant. I gave you the receipt on the condition that you brought me a fresh cheque or the money, which you said you would do as soon as possibleâ€”I looked to you for the moneyâ€”I said I would have nothing to do with Kemp's deeds.

Re-examined. After Bryant knew the cheque was returned he brought Kemp to me with a bag of papers, which, so far as I knew, were worth nothing to me; I did not want to investigate themâ€”he afterwards told me he had paid Bryant the money.

ARTHUR BENNETT . I am a cashier at the London and South-Western Bank, Camberwell Branchâ€”I produce a copy of James Kemp's account, which I have examined with the books; it is correctâ€”the account was opened in 1876, and closed on December 31st, 1883, because of irregu
larities, having to return cheques and that kind of thingâ€”I find in this returned-cheque book the entry of "15th February, 1886, cheque presented
I drawn by J, Kemp for 6l. 2s. 6d. in Palmer's favour"â€”I have made out I this copy of the cheque from that entry.
Cross-examined by Toler. I will swear it was Kemp's chequeâ€”we have no account in Palmer's name, and I never heard of there being one.

ELIJAH CASTLE . I am an oil and colour merchant, of 112, Acre Lane, Brixtonâ€”Monsieur Alfred Crepand, a customer, brought me this cheque for 3l. 3s., which is signed T. Tasker Toler, crossed "and Co.," and en
dorsed with my name and that of the payeeâ€”I gave him three guineas for itâ€”I paid it to a business house and received it back marked "N. S."â€”before I paid away that first one Crepand came and offered me a second cheque for 2l. 5s., drawn by Toler, and I gave him the money for itâ€”I did not seeeither of the prisonersâ€”I have not received the money from Crepand or either of the prisoners.

Cross-examined by Toler. You were unknown to me till I saw you at Westminsterâ€”the cheques are dated 26th and 30th Septemberâ€”I knew Crepand pretty well as a customer; he had a short time previously given me a cheque of yours which had been paidâ€”both these were returned marked "N. S."â€”I think only one was post-datedâ€”I think I kept them about 10 days after they arrived at maturityâ€”I am not aware that there was money to meet them when they arrived at maturityâ€”Crepand gave me your addressâ€”I believe my solicitor wrote to youâ€”I did not apply to you, I left it to him; they were unable to find youâ€”Cousens called on me after I had made an offer to assist in the prosecution, not before.

WALTER KEEN . I am a clerk in the principal office of the District Bank of London, 49, Oxford Streetâ€”I produce a copy of the account of Thomas Tasker Toler, which was opened on 15th September, 1885, with 6l., and closed on 12th February, 1886â€”on 6th January he was 6s. 9d. overdrawnâ€”on 21st January 1l. was paid in; nothing has been paid in sinceâ€”on 28th January 12s. 6d. was drawn out, leaving a balance of 9d., which was returned to him on 12th February with a notice that the account was closed on account of irregularities, so many returned chequesâ€”the total paid in altogether was 28l. 5s. 3d.â€”the largest balance at any time was 9l. 15s. 9d. on 24th September, but during that day 8l. 10s. was drawn outâ€”on 26th September there was 5s. 9d., and on 30th September 6d.â€”these cheques were presented, and marked as they appear, on account of there not being sufficient to meet them.

Cross-examined by Toler. There is no winding-up order against the bankâ€”I came to it some years agoâ€”you opened an account there in 1883 I believe, but it was dormant for a year or more with a debtor balance of 1s. 9d.; and on 15th September, 1885, you opened it a second time.
Re-examined. From September 15th to the time of closing the account we received thirty-two cheques, which were returned, there not being enough to meet them.

JOHN WILMOT . I am a numerical printer at 55 Bartholomew Close, and I am landlord of 52â€”in April, 1885, Toler took the warehouse and the basement of me there, and remained till December, 1885, but I lost sight of him before I found the place openâ€”I found in the shop two or three empty firkin casks of butter which stunk so badly that they must have been there a long timeâ€”he never paid me any rentâ€”he professed to trade as Tasker Toler, and Co.â€”that name was not written upâ€”I live close byâ€”no legitimate business was carried on, seriously the other way

â€”I could not get at himâ€”I watched the place to find him, and at last found him in a very ragged condition, for which he apologisedâ€”he was obtain
ing letters the whole time.

Cross-examined by Toler. I gave no evidence at Westminster; I come here to expose you for swindling me out of my rentâ€”I said if you would give me the keys and the possession I would let you off the rentâ€”you have had no end of letters from meâ€”the policeman called my attention that the basement door was undoneâ€”I did not tell you of it; I had other evidence of your character at that timeâ€”the post office autho
rities thought I was in the swindle with you, I suppose, and requested me to nail up the letter box; I did soâ€”the post-office refused to deliver letters, of which there were a large number from abroad, saying it was a swindleâ€”you offered to sell me butter cheapâ€”I saw some in your placeâ€”I had at least three promissory notes presented at my place and dis
honouredâ€”they were from merchants abroad.

WILLIAM COUSENS (Police Sergeant B). On 25th September I took Bryant at Readingâ€”I read the warrant to him; it was for conspiring with Toler to obtain 2l. 10s. from Gardiner with intent to defraud, and was dated 12th Mayâ€”he said nothingâ€”I said, "Did you hear what I said?"â€”he said, "Yes, I hear what you say"â€”on the way to London he said, "I was merely an agent or a manager for Toler"â€”on 29th September I took Toler at 60, Sussex Street, Pimlico, shortly after 10 p.m., on a warrant dated 28th September, charging him with obtaining, on or about 11th February, 2l. 10s. 6d. of John Bond by false pretencesâ€”I said, "I have a warrant now for your arrest for this case which we were investigating in the spring, I will read it to you"â€”he said, "You need not do that; if you take me out of this bedroom to-night you will endanger my life"â€”I said, "It is no good mincing matters, you will have to come"â€”he said, "Well, if I do I shall destroy some of these papers before I go," meaning papers that were on the tableâ€”he attempted to take up a newspaper which formed the table-cloth, with other papers on itâ€”I prevented him, and eventually got him into the street, where I read the warrant to him under a lamp-postâ€”he said, "I don't know what you mean; I don't know where Mr. Bond's house is; in fact, all these cases against me have been dismissed"â€”going along the road he said, "It was Bryant whom I met in Vauxhall Road; he took me into Mr. Bond's, the Foresters' Arms, and it was he who introduced me to Mr. Bond"â€”I said, "No doubt there will be several other charges preferred against you"â€”he said, "All right, do as you like"â€”I had charge of this case on the previous occasion, when he was summoned at the Westminster Police-court on Mr. Gardiner's charge onlyâ€”Bryant was also charged, but was not present, and could not be found, and the summons was dismissed in consequence of Bryant being at largeâ€”the matter extended from about April to Juneâ€”Toler applied for an adjournment of about three weeks to bring a witness from Franceâ€”the Magistrate did not dismiss the charge on account of its being the ground of a civil action.

Cross-examined by Toler. I have been in the force nearly 17 yearsâ€”the packet of papers given you last night were those you attempted to destroy and some which have come to me sinceâ€”the whole packet of letters related to swindles more or lessâ€”you asked me to stop in your room all night when I arrested you; I declinedâ€”you did not ask me to

do so that we might examine all the papersâ€”I found some County Court summonses in your roomâ€”I think I have been to all your trades people; I have been to a great many besides those who are here to-dayâ€”I went to Stewart, of Newgate Street, whom you cheated out of a bedstead; to a milk-shop in the Vauxhall Bridge Road, where you obtained provisions which you never paid forâ€”you paid no rent since February at the place you resided at, 60, Sussex Streetâ€”I have had complaints from Ireland and Copenhagen, where you obtained a lot of butterâ€”I knew Austin as a tradesman, and Powellâ€”Castle came to see me at the police-court; I did not influence him at allâ€”there were six remands at Westminster, I should think, at the outsideâ€”it was adjourned once or twice at your request, and about four times at mineâ€”you were discharged on the evidence of Longman, who was acquitted this session of uttering counterfeit coin, and because we could not find Bryantâ€”the Magistrate dismissed the summons, and gave you to understand that if we could find Bryant you would be proceeded againstâ€”Bryant was never there, he had abscondedâ€”I kept the warrant in my pocket, and arrested him after he was discharged from Readingâ€”I served him with a notice in Newgate to produce certain documents.

Cross-examined by Bryant. You told the Magistrate at Westminster Police-court that I was present at Reading when you were tried, and that I informed the Lord Chief Justice of all these cases, and I said it was false, for I was not at Readingâ€”I did not know where you were; we were looking for you at the time.

Re-examined. I did not give the Judge at Reading information when Bryant was convicted thereâ€”I first knew he was there when I heard he was undergoing sentence for fraud committed at Maidenheadâ€”Bryant never appeared at Westminster.
JOHN POWELL (Re-examined by the Jury). The cheques I paid were drawn by Tolerâ€”there were three or four I should think.
By Toler. I cashed the cheque two months after I bought it; I thought it was a dubious one.

p.hi: Toler, in his defence, reviewed the evidence at great length, and asserted that he had not obtained anything by fraud, and that Bryant was merely his agent and not a conspirator. Bryant stated that he had merely acted as messenger for Toler.

div1.p: ----ILOTT (Constable, Maidenhead). I was present when Bryant was tried before the Lord Chief Justice for obtaining money from a Maidenhead bakerâ€”he had three monthsâ€”it had nothing to do with thisâ€”the Lord Chief Justice said he gave him a short sentence as he saw there were other cases against him.

TOLERâ€”
GUILTY on the first, second, third, sixth, and twelfth Counts.

BRYANTâ€”
GUILTY on the third, fourth, fifth, and twelfth Counts.
They then

PLEADED GUILTY* to previous convictions, Toler in April, 1879, and Bryant in July, 1885.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude each.

38.
ANTOINE KALNOKY (32),
CHARLOTTE CUYPENS STORM (23), and
ALEXANDER ZAND (24)
, Unlawfully conspiring to obtain and obtaining money from divers persons, with intent to defraud.
MESSRS. MEAD and GOODRICH Prosecuted; MR. FULTON appeared for Kalnoky; and MR. ADDISON, Q.C., for Zand.

STORM.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

EDWARD HENRY (Interpreted). I keep the International Hotel, Coventry Streetâ€”on 14th September the two prisoners came there and took one room; they stayed till the 20th, and then paid me and leftâ€”during that time they were visited by Miss Storm at my hotelâ€”the prisoner Kalnoky was not staying there on 1st June.

CHARLOTTE CUYPENS STORM I am of Dutch birthâ€”in September I was in this country anxious to get employmentâ€”I understand French and Englishâ€”I saw this advertisement in the Daily Telegraph: "Young person wanted understanding French and English and knowing London. Apply between 4 and 5. A. R., 9, Arundel Street, W."â€”I went on the same day and found it to be the International Hotelâ€”I waited until other applicants had been seen, and then I was introduced to the two prisonersâ€”Zand asked me if I knew English; the con
versation was in French, and occasionally they spoke in Russian between themselvesâ€”Zand told me he had come to London with his friend to start a business, but he did not know English, and it was very difficult, and he wanted someone to act as interpreter and do English correspondenceâ€”I was engaged at 2l. 10s.; a monthâ€”Zand raised an objection to that amount at first, and spoke to Kalnoky, and then he turned to me again and said "You can have it"â€”it was arranged I should begin work next dayâ€”when I got there they told me it would be necessary for the business to have an office in the City, and I was to go and look for offices and interpret for them, but we only saw oneâ€”I then saw an advertisement of a furnished house, and went to Brixton and saw Mrs. Brittan, at 3, Tralawney Road, and it was arranged to take that house for four weeks at 6l.â€”Kalnoky gave the money to Zand, but I don't remember whether Zand gave it to Mrs. Brittanâ€”they then proposed that I should take up my abode with them, but I objected unless there was some female servant, and I asked Mrs. Brittan to obtain the services of a respectable old servant, and took up my quarters there on the Mondayâ€”on Tuesday, 20th September, we went to Messrs. Waterlow's, and found a gentleman in the shop who could speak French, and Zand spoke to him; Kalnoky remained in the cabâ€”we then went to Copperfield and Masson's, printers, of Newgate Streetâ€”Zand went in with me and asked Mr. Burgess if he could print circulars in French; he objected, but finally he said he would provided the proofs were correctedâ€”Zand went outside and came back with Kalnoky, and then 1l. deposit was paidâ€”they told me they had to write the manuscriptâ€”this (produced) is Zand's writingâ€”they took the manuscript to the printers themselves, and the printers sent the proofs, and the prisoners asked me to write a letter to the printers, which I didâ€”on 22nd or 23rd, while I was out, Zand went away to Paris; he said he was going to fetch his wife and childrenâ€”on Thursday, 7th October, I called at the printers and saw the circulars, and called again with Kalnoky on the 23rd to fetch themâ€”this (produced) is one of themâ€”we took them to the General Post Office Poste Restanteâ€”he had about fifty envelopes in his pocket ready addressed and stampedâ€”I had addressed about six of themâ€”a

great many letters had arrived at Brixton before this addressed "Soulk and Co."â€”he opened the envelopes and I put the circulars insideâ€”the printers asked me how many we required, so I turned to Zand, and he said 1,000, and if the business was successful 5,000â€”I and Kalnoky resided at Brixton until the end of the tenancy, and then he left for Paris, and I went to live at 6, Huntingdon Street, Barnsburyâ€”Kalnoky told me to go to the lodgings and get the letters re addressed from Brixton to Barnsburyâ€”he returned from Paris on 4th November, and he had no apartments, so I said "Leave your portmanteau in my room and get apartments and then send for it"â€”I then went out a few yards from the house and was arrestedâ€”during the time I lived there no one of the name of Soulk lived thereâ€”I was not allowed to see the proofs.

Cross-examined by MR. ADDISON. When the circulars were being printed Zand did not tell me about the system of getting moneyâ€”I never saw Zand again after he went awayâ€”during the time I was with them they always treated me like perfect gentlemen, and I trusted them; that was the impression I got from their conduct and way of lifeâ€”I don't know how many applied for this place, there were three waiting when I arrived, and two were speaking with them at the time, that is fiveâ€”I thought something had happened with them when Zand left, I felt there was something wrongâ€”he told me a long while afterwards that he had had a letter, and that his best friend, Zand, who he had known for five years, had also turned his back on himâ€”I never sent any letters to Zand in Paris, but they corresponded.
Re-examined. I think they corresponded together for about a fortnight after 18th September, and then he complained that Zand had turned his back upon him, and that he had no money left.
EMMA BRITTAN . I am the landlady of this house which was taken by the prisoners; I recollect them engaging itâ€”there was no other tenant, and no Mr. Soulk.

SARAH BRADY . I was servant at 3, Trelawney Road, when the prisoners were the tenants at Mrs. Brittan's houseâ€”I never saw a Mr. Soulk, but a number of letters came in that name, and I left them on the breakfast-table.

JOSEPH BURGESS I am manager of Copperfield and Masson's, printers, of Newgate Streetâ€”I executed an order for Soulk and Co., but after seeing the circular I communicated with the policeâ€”this is the manuscript (produced) which I received from Zand; he came with Kalnoky and gave me instructions by signs what to doâ€”this is the first proof, the name of May, Grove Road, West Hampstead, is on it; and this is the second proof, May, Grove Road, has been altered to 175, Station Roadâ€”I received the instructions from Miss Storm, but I received the order later onâ€”I received several post-cards, which I can produce if necessaryâ€”I printed 200 circulars and received 1l. 15s.
JOHN EGAN (City Detective) On 5th October I was with Detective Child in Brixton, and saw Kalnoky with Miss Storm leaving 3, Trelawney Road; and on 11th October I again saw them in company.

ROBERT CHILD (City Detective). On 4th November I was with Egan and saw Kalnoky and Miss Storm leave 6, Huntingdon Street, Barnsbury; I read the warrant to her, and she said "I have nothing to fear, I can clear myself; I was servant to them, and I can explain everything"â€”she said going along that she got acquainted with these people through

an advertisementâ€”I asked her to interpret the warrant to Kalnoky, she did so, and he asked me through her what was the charge; I told him conspiracy to defraud, and took him to the station and searched him, and found on him 10 sovereigns, a little silver, and a loaded revolverâ€”I then went to Storm's room, searched, and found this manuscript produced, and 150 of the circulars, and about 60 letters and post-cards from France and Belgium, addressed to Soulk and Co., 3, Trelawney Road, asking for par
ticulars as to the advertisements in the French and Belgium newspapersâ€”I have purchased the French and Belgian newspapers of 23rd, 24th, and 25th September, referred to in these letters, and the French Figaro of September 23rd, 24th, and 25thâ€”there are similar advertisements in the Belgian papersâ€”I found the corrected proofs which have been pro
duced by Mr. Burgessâ€”on 11th November Zand was brought to the police-office, Old Jewry, and Maloney interpreted the warrant to him at my request; he then expressed a wish to make a statement, and after I had cautioned him that what he said would be given in evidence against him, he made this statement, which I took down. (This gave a long account of his acquaintance with Kalnoky.) I found this receipt for 20 francs in Kalnoky's portmanteauâ€”since this prosecution has been set on foot I have received a letter addressed Soulk and Co.; it arrived to-day from the Brixton post-officeâ€”it contained 4l. from Comte Lascelles of Mar
seillesâ€”amongst the cards and letters from abroad was one which had come from that gentleman asking for a prospectus to be sentâ€”I have been to Hampstead and have looked through the post-office directory but have failed to find Station Road; there is no Station Road at West Hampstead.

Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. When I took Kalnoky he spoke to Miss Storm, and she said, "He wants to know what the charge is"â€”he then asked where we were going, and he was told to the police-stationâ€”as he was going along he asked me if any one had complained.
JOHN WATTS . I am an interpreterâ€”I have made translations of the different French documents in this case; they are correct.

WILLIAM GRAY . I am Inspector of the Dumbarton Constabulary, sta
tioned at Alexandria, which is about a mile from Balakâ€”there are about 27 houses there, and I am familiar with the persons living thereâ€”no one named M. Welk was living there on May 8 nor at any other time that I can discoverâ€”I searched the registers of the hotels there.

Cross-examined by MR. ADDISON. I don't know how many people there are thereâ€”I have been in the police-force 19 yearsâ€”I don't know how many persons in Balak use Beecham's pills or Pears' soapâ€”I never looked into any of the testimonials of those articles.

KALNOKIâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

ZANDâ€”
GUILTY
of conspiracy only. â€”
Four Days' Imprisonment.

39.
THOMAS HALEY was indicted
for the manslaughter of
John Preedy.
MR. POYNTER Prosecuted; MR. GILL. Defended.
CHARLES GOODALL (Police Sergeant). I know the locality where this
occurredâ€”I assisted in making this plan (produced); it is accurateâ€”on 18th October I attended the inquest and took the prisoner into custody; he said nothing.

CHARLES LUFFKINS . I live at 79, Beak Street, St. James'sâ€”I am superintendent of the road sweepers employed by St. James's Vestryâ€”on Saturday night or Sunday morning, 26th September, about a quarter past one, I was in Regent Street superintending the sweeping and removal of the dirt, near Argyll Placeâ€”I was conversing with Mr. Culverhouse, who contracts for the removalâ€”I saw a brougham approaching me very rapidly on the near side of the road from Oxford Circus; the driver was beating the horseâ€”as he passed me I saw him rise, and by the play of his arm he was still flogging the horseâ€”I did not witness the accident; the sweepers were out of my sight, but I knew where they would be, and I ran, keeping the brougham in view, until I heard screams and a great shouting, and then something seemed to impede my view, and on coming near Glasshouse Street, where I stopped running, I saw a number of cabs and the broughamâ€”I then went back and saw Preedy lying prostrate in the road, partially supported by two of the sweepersâ€”he was a very aged man, I should say over 70â€”he was quite insensible, and appeared to me to be dead; there was some blood across his foreheadâ€”it was a dry, clear night, no fog; there were gas lampsâ€”there is a refuge for foot passengers near where I first saw the brougham, but not near where Preedy was lyingâ€”there were two street sweeping machines some distance ahead, by Swan and Edgar's.

Cross-examined. The brougham passed the refuge on its proper sideâ€”the road was quite clear of traffic just at that spotâ€”the brougham was driving close to the kerb, in its proper positionâ€”it is wood pavementâ€”Regent Street is very much out of condition at that end, there are holes in the pavement; the channels are of very broad iron, about 18 inches wideâ€”the St. James's Vestry look after the street; the road was not muddy, it was very dryâ€”I know by the number of carts it was dry sweepings that were being taken upâ€”Preedy was very deaf and very stout, but active for his ageâ€”I was not walking down the street with Mr. Culverhouse; we were standing talkingâ€”I left him and ran.

WILLIAM COLLINS . I am a sweeper employed by St. James's Vestryâ€”on this Sunday morning I was among the sweepers in Regent Street, there were about seven or eight at our endâ€”we were going down Regent Street on the left hand side with our backs towards the trafficâ€”some were in the channel; I was in the road, four or five feet from the channelâ€”Beale was in front of me and Preedy farther in frontâ€”Smith was behind me, right in the channelâ€”I heard one of our men sing out "Look up"â€”I then turned to my left and saw a brougham coming along very fast, I should say from 12 to 13 miles an hour in my estimateâ€”a moment afterwards Smith was knocked down; this was about seven or eight yards from Beak Street going down towards Piccadilly Circusâ€”I escaped by jumping back farther into the roadâ€”I then saw the horse strike Preedy in the back; he had his broom in his right hand, and he like staggered forwardâ€”he seemed to be slightly recovering when the horse struck him again and he fell, and the horse trampled upon him and the brougham went over himâ€”I called out "Stop, stop; "the driver went on, he urged the horse, he stood up on his legs and whipped the horse,
and went away as fast as he couldâ€”I ran after him crying "Stop," and Beale was in front of me halloingâ€”it was stopped before I got up.

Cross-examined. This happened a few yards from Beak Streetâ€”any one walking out of Beak Street would have seen pretty well the whole thingâ€”the driver did not flog the horse all the way till he was stoppedâ€”I dare say he hit the horse six or seven times with the whip; it was gallopingâ€”it was over 30 yards from where the accident happened to where the brougham was stoppedâ€”I can't say that he was standing up all the way, he got in advance of meâ€”I have not seen the brougham here in the Court yardâ€”I did not see it stopped, it was stopped before I got to Glasshouse Streetâ€”the first thing I heard was "Look up;" that was from Youngâ€”I did not hear the driver call; I heard nothing approachâ€”when I turned the brougham was just on the point of striking Smith; it was between me and Smithâ€”I was between Smith and Preedy, farther out in the middle of the roadâ€”I saw the horse strike Smith in the backâ€”the first time it struck Preedy about the shoulder and the second time about the saddleâ€”the driver did not try to stop the horseâ€”I did not see it struck with a broomâ€”I said Beale threw his broom down on the ground and ran after the broughamâ€”Smith and Preedy had their backs to the brougham; neither of them turnedâ€”Smith's broom went on the pave
ment, Preedy's broom went down with himâ€”Preedy was rather deafâ€”I did not see the horse rear; it galloped awayâ€”I said before the Magis
trate "the horse did not rear up until the prisoner hit Him"â€”the wood pavement was not wet; it was pretty dry, a fine nightâ€”there were a number of Hansom cabs passing farther up.
Re-examined. I had not time to notice the pace of the horse before Smith was struck.

JOHN SMITH . I am one of the sweepers-employed by the parish of St. Jamesâ€”on this Sunday morning I was employed with the other sweepers in Regent Street; I was in the channel heaping up the dust for the carts to takeâ€”it was not very dry nor yet very wet; there had been a little sprinkling of rain for about ten minutesâ€”Preedy was working between me and the channel, about six or eight yards before meâ€”I got knocked down and ripped up the back, and then chucked on the pavementâ€”I do not recollect any more for some timeâ€”I felt the effects of it very much for a fortnight, and I sometimes feel it now.
Cross-examined. Preedy was rather deaf, more so than meâ€”I did not hit the horse with my broom, and I don't think any one else had a chance of doing soâ€”I don't know what became of my broom.

WILLIAM BEALE I was one of the sweepers; I was about the third man from the channel in front of Preedyâ€”I saw a one-horse brougham coming I should say between thirteen and fourteen miles an hourâ€”I did not observe the driver doing anythingâ€”the horse knocked Smith down first, and then Preedyâ€”I chucked down my broom and ran after the broughamâ€”before Preedy was struck there was no broom in such a position that the horse could be struck by itâ€”I saw the brougham stopped in about 30 yardsâ€”I should say it was about 8 yards from the corner of Beak Street that Preedy was struckâ€”I saw the carriage go over him.
Cross-examined. I saw the brougham from the time the accident happened until it was stoppedâ€”it was about 4 yards from me when I
first saw it, I was facing itâ€”I had no time to call outâ€”I heard nothingâ€”I did not see the driver flog the horse at all.

JAMES ANDERSON . I am a tailor, of 60, King Street, Regent Streetâ€”I was coming along Beak Street on this Sunday morning, and heard cries of "Stop him, stop him"â€”I ran into Regent Street and saw a brougham; it had passed Beak Street before I got up; I ran after it, and overtook it, and seized the horse by the bridleâ€”it could not have been going very fast, or I could not have stopped itâ€”the prisoner was driving, and he asked me what I meant by stopping his horseâ€”I said, "I don't know."

Cross-examined. He was not standing up and flogging the horse when I saw him, nor was he sitting down and flogging itâ€”he had turned Beak Street when I heard the cryâ€”I was on the south side of Beak Street before I began to runâ€”I had no difficulty whatever in stopping the horseâ€”the prisoner was sober when I saw him.

GEORGE JERVIS (Policeman C 33). On the morning of Sunday, 26th September, my attention was called to the deceased, and I directed his removal to the Middlesex Hospital in a Hansomâ€”I saw the horse and brougham at the corner of Regent's Place, between Beak Street and Glasshouse Streetâ€”the prisoner was there, and I took his name and address; he made no statement.

Cross-examined. His master was thereâ€”there was no complaint made of his driving furiouslyâ€”I saw the sweepers, none of them complained that he had driven furiously, if they had I should have done a little more, they said nothing to meâ€”I was not aware the man was so seriously injuredâ€”I saw Mr. Luffkins, he did not complain of the man having driven furiously, he did not speak to me that night.

ARTHUR EDWARD NEVINS . I am one of the house surgeons at the Middlesex Hospitalâ€”Preedy was brought in there on Sunday morningâ€”he was unable to walk, and in a semi-unconscious conditionâ€”he had received injuries from which he ultimately died on the morning of 14th Octoberâ€”amongst those injuries was a fracture of the skull, and some broken ribs, and a broken collar-bone, and a broken legâ€”there was also effusion on the brain from the crack in the skull; that would prevent him from giving any intelligible account; he was never more conscious than to ask for food and that kind of thing.
Cross-examined. He was 69 years of age, and was very deaf, we had to shout to him.

RICHARD WARNER . I am a theatrical agentâ€”the prisoner has driven me for eight or nine months, and is thoroughly steady and soberâ€”I never I allow him to drive me fast, if he did he wouldn't suit me again; I gave him particular orders to drive me slowly, as my health would not permit him to drive fastâ€”during all the time he has driven me he has shown himself a careful driverâ€”on this night I was in my brougham, and my attention was called by hearing somebody shoutâ€”at that time he was not driving more than seven or eight miles an hour at the very utmost, I do not think the horse could do moreâ€”I do not remember the brougham being stopped, he stopped it himselfâ€”I looked out of the window and said, "What is the matter?" and told him to stopâ€”he said, "I will as soon as I can," or words to that effectâ€”he stopped the horse within a second or two, and the horse was almost on its haunches, pulling it up so

quicklyâ€”it had been raining all the evening, and I noticed particularly that it was slippery; Regent Street is in a fearful stateâ€”it would be impossible for the prisoner to stand up on that brougham; the board is very narrow, and if he was driving fast he would lose his equilibriumâ€”he was sitting down when I looked outâ€”he stopped towards the lower part of Regent Streetâ€”I cannot speak as to how the accident happenedâ€”the prisoner is a hard-working, industrious young man, and supports his mother.

Cross-examined. I was inside the broughamâ€”I could not say whether he was flogging his horse or notâ€”Bayswater was my last halting-place before thisâ€”he had been out all the day, and the horse was naturally tiredâ€”I took the words "I will as soon as I can "to mean that the horse must have received some fright, and it being slippery he could not pull up.

By the COURT. I did not feel the carriage go over the manâ€”I inquired about the man at the time, and told them to take him to the hospital, but they said he had already goneâ€”I went to the hospital two or three days afterwards and inquired about himâ€”I was not asleep, I was just lying back in the broughamâ€”there was quite 10 minutes lost before the crowd came round and the policeman cameâ€”I do not know why the prisoner went so near the channel.
By MR. GILL. The cab belongs to a livery stableâ€”I believe they have made ample compensation.

WILLIAM CHARLES QUINN . The prisoner is in my employmentâ€”I always found him a very steady young fellow, and he has had young horses and old horses, and drives them very wellâ€”he is a kind-hearted man to his horses, I gave him a young horse once, and he came home and stayed with him all night because it was a bit queerâ€”this is not my broughamâ€”it is impossible, for a man to stand up on this brougham when it is going fast.
Cross-examined. A man might raise himself from his seat and flog the I horse, but he might fall off.

GEORGE JERVIS (Re-examined). The sweeper who I spoke to was Collinsâ€”I did not speak to Smith or the other manâ€”Smith was not taken to the hospitalâ€”I spoke to Mr. Warner, and got his name and addressâ€”that was after the man had gone to the hospitalâ€”he did not seem to be seriously injured; he could not speak.

WILLIAM COLLINS (Re-examined). A witness of the name of Brown saw the horse flogged as well as myselfâ€”I spoke to the inspector first, and told him the man had been run over and knocked down, and he told the constable to take our names and addressesâ€”I also told the inspector that I had seen the horse driven furiously, and that the man whipped the horse.

MR. CLOKE. I represent the firm of Dewsbury, job mastersâ€”this horse and brougham belonged to that firm, and the prisoner was in our employâ€”I believed him to be steady and sober in every respect, and I had every confidence in his drivingâ€”this horse and brougham had been out all the day, and I don't believe the horse could do 14 miles an hour without some exertionâ€”we have paid ample compensation to the widow, so that there is no claim of any kind pending.
Cross-examined. Our stables are at 172, York Road, near where Mr. Warner livesâ€”we supply him with a brougham at so much per monthâ€”
on this night the prisoner took Mr. Warner home, and then brought the brougham back home.

CHARLES GOODALL (Re-examined). I have made inquiries as to the prisoner's character, and find he is a very respectable young man, and keeps his motherâ€”his last employer bailed him out at the police-courtâ€”the brougham is in the yard, but I do not think the horse is the same; she has been laid up by a cracked heel. (The Jury here went and inspected the brougham.)

A. E. NAVINS (Re-examined). I did not think the man was seriously hurt when he came to the hospitalâ€”the continuance of the symptoms was the serious part of itâ€”he struggled when he was brought into the surgery, so that he was conscious thenâ€”the wound was a very small one.

CHARLES LUFFKINS (Re-examined). This was not the usual time for work to be going onâ€”it was a new order from the Vestry that we should begin at midnight; it had been going on from six weeks to two monthsâ€”we have given it over now.
NOT GUILTY .

40.
CHARLES WILLIAM SPOONER ,
Unlawfully, while em
ployed as clerk and servant to a certain trades union, making certain false entries in a cash-book, with intent to defraud.
MR. BESLEY Prosecuted; MR. LADBURY Defended.

p.hi: The case against the prisoner was entirely a question of bookkeeping, and the figures in question in some of the books were dictated to the defendant, and not copied by him.
suggested that it was rather a case of bad arithmetic than of fraud. The Jury concurring, found the defendant

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

41.
WILLIAM CHARLES SPOONER was again indicted
for em
bezzling certain sums, the property of his employer.
NOT GUILTY .

42.
HENRY KENT (36)
, Writing and publishing a libel concerning
Henry Rogers, to which he pleaded
NOT GUILTY, and a justification that it was for the public good.

During the opening speech of MR. METCALFE, for the prosecution, the RECORDER suggested that there was no possibility of the prisoner sustaining his plea; the prisoner then undertook to apologise to the prosecutor and he with-drew his plea, and withdrew the libel and expressed his regret, upon which the Jury found him

GUILTY .â€”
To enter into his own recognisances in 25l. to keep the peace for 12 months, and to pay the costs the Prosecution incurred by his plea of justification.

43.
DUNCAN CAMERON (61)
, Unlawfully selling in an open and public shop certain lewd books, indecent photographs, and other articles.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. RICHMOND Defended.

GUILTY .â€”
Two Years Hard Labour. The
RECODER and the Jury

p.hi: expressed their approbation of the conduct of the police, the Grand Jury having also made a presentment to the same effect.

div1.p:
44.
NACHEN SHAPIRA
, for wilful and corrupt perjury at the Thames Police-court.
MESSRS. POLAND and MEAD Prosecuted; MESSRS. K. FRITH and RICHMOND Defended.

ALFRED JAMES BAKER .
