I am a clerk in the office of the Clerk of the Peace for Middlesexâ€”I produce the original depositions in the case of the Queen against Marcus Shapira, who was committed for trial at the Middlesex Sessionsâ€”I produce the indictment which shows that a true bill was found, and that the prisoner was brought in not guilty.

DUNDAS JOHN ROBERTS WILLIAMS . I am Clerk to the Magistrate at the Thames Police-courtâ€”I produce an information laid against Marcus Shapira by Nachen Shapiraâ€”I dictated the information which I obtained directly from the prisoner to the assistant-clerk, who wrote it down, on 24th Septemberâ€”I am a German scholar; there was an interpreter there, but I could understand all he saidâ€”while taking it Marcus Shapira came into the office accompanied by a solicitor, who applied for a warrant against the present prisoner for threatsâ€”the prisoner and prosecutor began quarrelling directly they were together in the officeâ€”I told them to stand on one side and I finished taking the prisoner's infor
mationâ€”when it was written I read it to himâ€”I said, "I cannot under
stand what made you go down to a ship; why did not you show the coral in the street?"â€”he said "I don't know"â€”I gave him no warn
ing thenâ€”the information was put before Mr. Lushington, who granted this warrantâ€”Marcus Shapira was then taken into custody by the sergeant, and brought before the Magistrate, and the case was heard the same dayâ€”an interpreter was sworn and interpreted the evidence and I took down the deposition as interpreted to me; I know that what he said was a correct interpretationâ€”after it was written I read it in English to the interpreter sentence by sentence, and he interpreted it correctly to the prisonerâ€”the prisoner assented as it was read, and signed it in these Hebrew charactersâ€”then the present prosecutor was com
mitted for trial on that chargeâ€”Mr. Lushington had warned the prisoner in my presence.

p.hi:
The deposition containing the alleged perjury was put in. The assign
ments were put to the prosecutor in his evidence and denied by him.

div1.p:
Cross-examined. At the time I spoke to him about having these things shown to him on board ship, these people were wrangling together in the German dialectâ€”frequently when one Jew brings a charge against another I hear of a cross chargeâ€”the prisoner was the first to make a chargeâ€”I was not surprised to hear the cross-charge almost imme
diatelyâ€”the prisoner had been there about four minutes before the cross-charge was made, in the mean time the Magistrate had come on the Bench, he had been in the building about ten minutes, and I had been in to explain the circumstances to him, and ask him if he would grant a warrantâ€”except by their addresses I did not know the prisoner and

prosecutor lived in the same neighbourhoodâ€”it is a common thing for one to come and say, "I have heard you are going to make a charge against me," and then to wrangle as to which shall have their charge taken firstâ€”no charge has been instituted against Loevenvirth in the prisoner's presence to my knowledgeâ€”a charge of threats was made on 24th Septemberâ€”that charge has absolutely disappeared as far as the Thames Police-court is concerned.

MARCUS SHAPIRA (Interpreted). I live at 16, St. George's Street, St. George's-in-the-Eastâ€”I am an Austrian Poleâ€”I knew the prisoner as Nachen Shapiraâ€”I lived fourteen miles from him in Austria, and knew him long agoâ€”I was a coral merchant, and the prisoner knew that when he came to Englandâ€”I do not know when he came to Englandâ€”I came in May for the second time, but I came beforeâ€”when I came in May I knew the prisoner was in Londonâ€”he owed me 1,000 roubles, and I came to London to obtain itâ€”I then lodged at Loevenvirth's, 10, Hounds
ditch, where Engell also lodgedâ€”I saw Loevenvirth receive from Engell 1,500 Austrian florinsâ€”I received no money from him in Mayâ€”I asked him for it several times, he told me he had not got any at presentâ€”I returned to Gallicia, where I obtained this document. (This was an Austrian Warrant. MR. FRITH objected to its being read.) I returned to England with itâ€”it refers to the money which the prisoner owes meâ€”I then lodged with Isaac Lipschitz, at 16, St. George's Street, St. George's in the Eastâ€”Engell, who had lodged with me at Loevenvirth's, lodged there tooâ€”I saw the prisoner several times before the 22nd September, he was living at the same place as he had been at before I went awayâ€”I spoke to him about my claim several" timesâ€”I did not show him the warrant or refer to itâ€”he said "I cannot give you any at present, besides England is a free country"â€”on 14th September I was a witness against Loevenvirth at Guildhall in a matter between Engell and Loeven-virth; it was adjourned till the 28thâ€”on 22nd September, about 2 o'clock, I saw the prisoner at his house, and we then went out and walked about in Whitechapelâ€”I asked him for my money againâ€”I only asked him at that time to let me have some money to go home withâ€”he said "I cannot give you any, but I can get you some from Loevenvirth"â€”I told him I could not go away at once because I was a witness for Engellâ€”he said "You have already given your evidence, and you had better go away, or otherwise you will get into trouble if you stay here, as they have more money than you have"â€”he meant Loevenvirth and Stone (Whose name was mentioned in the proceedings at Guildhall) and othersâ€”the prisoner said Loevenvirth would give me the money to go home withâ€”it was arranged that I was to go home the same night, the 22ndâ€”we spoke about the amount, and I agreed to receive 3l. 10s.â€”he declined to give me the money altogether because he was afraid I would not go awayâ€”it was mentioned that the ticket from London to Hamburg would be 15s. and 6s. from Hamburg to Berlin, and from Berlin home about 2l.â€”I asked him to let me have the money to take my watch out of pawn; it was pawned for 10s.â€”he said he would send me about 250 florins when I reached home upon the 1,000 roubles that the prisoner owed meâ€”after that we went to the post-office, where the prisoner changed two sovereigns into two 10 Austrian florin notes and enclosed them in an envelope, which was addressed to "Marcus Shapira, Poste Restante, Berlin"â€”that was given to the lady clerk; it was registered, and a receipt given to the

prisonerâ€”from there we went and had something to eat, and then went on the pawnbroker's, where the prisoner took my watch out of pawn and gave it to meâ€”we then went to my lodging, that would be between 4 and 5 o'clockâ€”I packed my clothes in my portmanteauâ€”I saw Mr. Bergmann before doing so in the prisoner's presenceâ€”after packing my clothes the prisoner wanted me to go to the ship to take my luggage and to obtain a ticket from the captain, and I went with him in a little boat to the ship Vega lying in the Thamesâ€”I saw Rinken, the chief cook, and asked for the captain, but he was not on board, and I could not buy the ticketâ€”I gave my box with my clothes in it to the cook to take care ofâ€”I did not open it at all and show the prisonerâ€”I returned with him to the shore and went to Mr. Bergmann's, whom I saw and spoke to in the prisoner's presenceâ€”I told him what the prisoner had done about the moneyâ€”Bergmann gave me 51 marksâ€”the prisoner showed Bergmann this receipt for the registered letter, which Bergmann gave to meâ€”I went back to my lodgings, where I saw Engell and Lipschitz, and in con
sequence of what they said I refrained from going to Hamburg that nightâ€”next day I saw the prisoner and Loevenvirth together in St. George's Street about 7 o'clockâ€”Loevenvirth said to me" If you don't go away I will stab you"â€”the prisoner heard thatâ€”he wanted to call the police and have me arrestedâ€”then they both threatened me that I had swindled the prisoner out of 3l. 10s. for coralsâ€”that was the first time I heard anything about coralsâ€”I had brought up corals with me at allâ€”in consequence of the threats I went and saw a solicitor the following morning, and then went with him to the Thames Police-courtâ€”I was given into custody that day when I went to obtain a warrant for their threatsâ€”the charge was heardâ€”I was committed for trial, and kept in custody eight days awaiting trialâ€”on the trial I was acquittedâ€”I had no legal assistanceâ€”Counsel appeared for the prose
cutionâ€”I got back my box when the ship returned after about a couple of weeksâ€”I went with Lipschitz to lay an information at the police-court against the prisoner for this perjuryâ€”it is not true that on the 22nd September I asked the prisoner if he would buy any coral beads; I had noneâ€”the prisoner did not say "What sort of coral?"â€”I did not say "From Paris," nor did I say "Give me 3l. 10s. for the coral; it is worth 5l."â€”the prisoner did not say "Where is the coral?"â€”I did not say "At my lodging"â€”the prisoner did not say "Is it good coral?"â€”I did not say "You will see; give me 2l. at present, as I want to send to Berlin"â€”I did not say "I want more money to pay for my lodging, and then I can get my box"â€”I did not say "It is not nice to show you the coral in the street; come with me to the ship"â€”it is not true that I opened the box on the ship, nor that I said "Oh, I have made a mistake; I left the other box behind"â€”the box was not then empty, because all my effects were in itâ€”the prisoner did not ask me for the coralâ€”I did not say "You saw me send away the money to Berlin; I have no coral now; I will give you coral later on"â€”it is not true that the prisoner gave me the 3l. 10s. as he believed I had some coral.

Cross-examined. After I had given evidence against Loevenvirth, he was dischargedâ€”at home I deal in coral, but I have never done so except in Galliciaâ€”I have been living here on money I had, and now I get 15s. a week from the Treasury; I get nothing from Mr. Bergmannâ€”I did not ask a woman on 22nd September to buy coral from me, (Mrs.

Nationshon was called into Court.) I only saw that woman at Arbour Square Police-courtâ€”I have not threatened any of the prisoner's witnessesâ€”I do not know Zolinger. (Zolinger was called into Court.) He was a witness against meâ€”I did not meet him with Nachen Shapira in September in Church Laneâ€”I did not say to him "A woman told me your wife would like to have a necklace of corals, will you buy one? I will sell it a bargain; I will sell it for 3l. 10s., it is worth 5l."â€”I said nothing about the wife wanting a coral necklace in Zolinger's presenceâ€”the prisoner never said in Zolinger's presence "Can you show me corals?"â€”I did not say I had some at my lodgings, or "Come with me, and I will show them to you"â€”the prisoner went with me, but not for the coralsâ€”I did not say "Will you do me a favour? I want to send 2l. to Berlin; will you give me 2l. now, and I will give you the corals when you give me the balance"â€”Zolinger was not presentâ€”I did not go with the prisoner and Zolinger to a money-changer's office and change the money into Austrian moneyâ€”I know the money-changer's office; it is close to the post-office where the post-office orders were boughtâ€”I do not know Goldbergâ€”I think there was a man of that name at Arbour Squareâ€”nobody was at the post-office but I and the prisoner, and therefore the prisoner did not there say in Goldberg's presence "I give you 2l., and I will give you the rest of the money to come and give me the corals"â€”I did not say "Do not be afraid of me, come along with me"â€”I know Grosse; he is the prisoner's brother; his name is Shapiraâ€”he was not on board the ship; only we two were thereâ€”I did not hear someone on board the ship say to the prisoner "What are you doing here?"â€”the prisoner did not say "I have bought some corals, and this man is going to give them to me"â€”I did not say in the prisoner's presence and another person's after I had opened the box "Oh, I forgot the corals; come with we to my lodgings"â€”the prisoner did not say to the other person "Come with us"â€”after leaving the ship I went to my lodgings, and the prisoner stopped outside of his own accord; I did not say to him "Wait outside"â€”the lodging-house keeper did not come out and say to the prisoner "What do you want?"â€”I was not presentâ€”the prisoner did not say "I have got nothing to do with you; I have bought some corals of your lodger"â€”when I came out again the prisoner in Grosse's presence did not ask me again for coralsâ€”I did not say "I have not got any corals or money"â€”after I came out the prisoner did not begin to scream and make a noiseâ€”I did, because I had my luggage on the boat, and Engell and Lipschitz would not allow me to goâ€”I did not hit the prisoner's brother on the headâ€”I do not know Marks Veiskorn. (Called into Court.) I did not about the third week in September say "I am going home, and have come to bid you good-bye; I have sold corals to Nachen Shapira "â€”Veiskorn did not ask me how I had got the money to go homeâ€”I do not know Annie Veiskorn. (Called into Court.) Nothing of that sort occurred in her presence.
Re-examined. After I had given evidence at Guildhall on 24th September the matter was postponed for a fortnight.

BARBARA LOUISA JANE BULLMAN . I am assistant clerk at the Post
office, 66. High Street, Whitechapelâ€”on 22nd September the prosecutor came in between half-past 1 and 2 with another man whom I cannot identifyâ€”I don't think there was a third man with themâ€”one of the two handed me a letter addressed "Marcus Shapira, Berlin," which I

registeredâ€”I gave the receipt to one of them, and they leftâ€”afterwards they both came back, and the other man, not the prosecutor, spoke and made signs; I could not understand what he saidâ€”ultimately I showed him the back of the envelope where there was an addressâ€”I do not recollect what it was.

Cross-examined. My attention was not called to this till a long time afterâ€”it is a matter of everyday occurrence for people to send stamps and foreign money awayâ€”there might have been three people, but I cannot remember a thirdâ€”I know there were twoâ€”I am positive about the prosecutor.
Re-examined. I was at the police-court and my evidence was taken; Mr. Frith appeared thereâ€”I don't remember that he suggested a third man was there.

GEORGE HENRY ROBERTS . I am manager to Mr. Telfer, a pawnbroker, of 178, St. George's Street Eastâ€”on 22nd September in the evening a silver watch and chain was redeemed by the prosecutor and another manâ€”I think Lipschitz had pawned it for 10s.â€”I don't recognise the prisoner t allâ€”I cannot say who handed me the money.

REINHARDT RINKIN . I am chief cook on board the steamship Vega, which plies between London and Hamburgâ€”on 22nd September, towards the evening, the prisoner and prosecutor came on boardâ€”I saw no third manâ€”the prisoner asked me the price of the ticket, and I told him 16s., and he la 1 it ought to be 13s.â€”I then said, "I will see the steward, and then you can see by the ticket yourself"â€”the prosecutor had a small grey portmanteau and a boxâ€”he said he would go between decks on the journey, and asked if I would take care of the box for himâ€”I asked him whether there were objects of value in it, and he said "No"â€”I took care of it, and locked it in my roomâ€”the portmanteau was closed, but it appeared to me as if there was only a prayer-book and something that they put over their head in it, when I shook it, they were looseâ€”the two men went awayâ€”neither of them came on board to go to Hamburgâ€”10 days or a fortnight afterwards the prosecutor came and fetched the portmanteau on a Sundayâ€”Grosse was not with them when they cameâ€”it is not true that the box was opened in the prisoner's presence on board the shipâ€”they were only there a few minutesâ€”the prosecutor did not say, "I have made a mistake, I have left the other box behind."

Cross-examined. They came on board in the middle of the ship just opposite to meâ€”I only saw them when they appeared before the kitchenâ€”there were no passengers at all between decksâ€”there were not people there to see their friends offâ€”I would not swear to the face of every person on board that dayâ€”I did not see Grosse; I saw no one else but those twoâ€”they were in front of the kitchenâ€”it was twilight, and possibly Grosse may have been there and I may not have seen him.
Re-examined. I am positive there was no third man in their company.

THEODORE PASCH . I live at 4, Selway Road, Stratford, and am in the employ of the North Metropolitan Tramways Company as conductorâ€”on 23rd September, between 7 and 8 o'clock, I saw the prisoner and Loevenwirth in St. George's-in-the-East near Mr. Telfer'sâ€”the prosecutor was also there in the custody of a constableâ€”I said in the prisoner's hearing, "They have trumped up a false charge against the man you have; they want to get this man away from giving evidence at Guildhall; you can almost see what it is, it is a false charge"â€”the

constable then let him goâ€”then the prisoner and Loevenwirth began to threaten him in German and Edish, a mixture of Hebrew and German, and said, "If you don't go home before Engell's case comes on we will stab you"â€”Loevenwirth said that first, and the prisoner afterwardsâ€”then Loevenwirth began to try and get at the prosecutor, and I hit him from one side of the road to the other, and told him if he did not go away he would get himself into the wrong box.

Cross-examined. I am a Prussianâ€”I first made a statement about this matter last Tuesdayâ€”I told the authorities on Sunday I could give informationâ€”I went to the Thames Police-court to apply for a warrant for the arrest of the prisoner and Loevenwirth with the prosecutorâ€”I was with the prosecutor at Scotland Yard when he got a warrantâ€”I was sent there by the Austrian Consulâ€”I was an interpreter thenâ€”I hate had a large hotel at Tower Hill and another at East Smithfield; I gave up one 15 months ago, and the other latelyâ€”I had not time to make a statement before Tuesdayâ€”I was odd man then, I am in regular service now.

MARCUS SAMUEL BERGMANN . I am a missionary to the Jews at the East End of London, and live at Upton House, 222, Burdett Road, Bowâ€”according to appointment the prosecutor and prisoner came together to see me on 22nd September about 5 o'clockâ€”I said to the prosecutor, "I come to fulfil my promise; have you got what your friend has promised?"â€”the prisoner then took 15s. out of his pocket and showed it to me and said, "This will do for a ship's ticket to Hamburg"â€”I said to the prosecutor, "Have you any more?"â€”he said, pointing to his watch and chain, "The prisoner took these out of pledge for me"â€”I asked the prisoner, "Have you any more?" and then we went inside the mission-houseâ€”the prosecutor said the prisoner sent in a registered letter to Berlin, in the prosecutor's name, to the Poste Restante, 20 Austrian florins per notes, which would be for his travelling expenses from the German-Austrian frontier right to his homeâ€”the prisoner took out of his pocket a receipt, showing me what he stated was correctâ€”I looked at it, and saw it was addressed to Marcus Shapira, and I handed it to the prosecutor saying, "This will do for you"â€”the prisoner wanted to get possession of it; he said, "Yes, I sent him the 20 florins to Berlin"â€”they said they had been at the post-office together, and the prosecutor said he saw himself the 20 florins put in the letter, and nothing was writtenâ€”I put my hand on the prosecutor's shoulder and said to the prisoner, "What have you done to this poor man?"â€”the prisoner said, "I could not help myself, I was in Very great straits"â€”afterwards he said, "In about a fortnight's time I will send him 250 florins as part"â€”that would be when the prosecutor got homeâ€”I went out and changed 2l. 10s. into 51 marks German money, and returned with it in two paper bags, and gave it to the prosecutorâ€”he kissed my hands and expressed thanks, and so did the prisonerâ€”that was about 7 p.m.â€”the prisoner, after showing me the 15s. put it back in his pocket, but he said at the Mission House he had given it to the prosecutor in my presenceâ€”I sent them both away to go and get the ship's ticket previous to my giving him the 51 marks; I said, "Show it to me, and I will give you what I promised"â€”when they returned the prisoner, I think, said that the captain was not on board, and the ship would not leave till about 4 a.m.â€”the Mission House is 163, St. George's Streetâ€”

no coral was ever mentionedâ€”the 250 florins was to be sent in part payment of what the prosecutor said the prisoner owed himâ€”I went to Middlesex Sessions and gave evidenceâ€”I have been connected with this mission for 16 years.

Cross-examined. I was converted to Christianity 19 years agoâ€”I am not in charge but I have a part in this mission, which has been estab
lished for foreign sailorsâ€”I did not refuse to say who were the Committee and who paid me, at the police-courtâ€”I said I was paid by the London City Missionâ€”I do not pay the Jews who are in process of con
version to induce them to change their faithâ€”I give money out of my pocket; I have private meansâ€”the Society's funds are raised by volun
tary subscriptionsâ€”the prisoner is a Jew but not a strict Jewâ€”the prose
cutor is a strict Jew.
By the JURY. I afterwards gave the receipt to the prosecutor because I thought the prisoner would not want it.
Re-examined. I gave it to the prosecutor so that he could get the money in the letter abroad.

SIDNEY CHARLES HOLDER . I am a letter carrier attached to the Bethnal Green Post-officeâ€”on 12th October I delivered a registered letter from Berlin to the prisoner's daughter at 59, Three Colts Laneâ€”I brought a receipt, which she signed "M. Shapira"â€”I did not tell her what name to sign.

JANE SHAPIRA (Interpreted). On 12th October the postman brought a registered letter, and I wrote on the receipt "M. Shapira "as the post-man told meâ€”it was only an envelope with 20 florins in it; it had come back from Berlinâ€”I opened the letter in the room where my mother wasâ€”my father when he was in prison had told me to open any letter that came, and he said he expected a letter from Berlin; that he was the person who sent the money, and that he had written for and claimed the letter and asked for it to be sent to that address.
HENRY TOWELL . I am an officer of Guildhall Police-courtâ€”I produce he original depositions in the case of Engel against Loevenwirth.

SARAH NATIONSHON (Interpreted). I live at Osborne Street, White-chapelâ€”my husband is a traveller; he is not in Londonâ€”on a Sunday in September I met the prosecutor in Petticoat Lane; he asked me whether I wanted to purchase any corals and I said "No," I didn't want any, but that I knew a Mrs. Nachen Shapira, the prisoner's wife, of Three Colts Lane, who had a daughter who was going to get married, and she might want one.

Cross-examined. It was in the morning; no one else was presentâ€”I have seen the prosecutor several times since in the street, but have not spoken to himâ€”I next saw him two or three days after, and then two or three days after thatâ€”then several people told me he was in prisonâ€”I afterwards spoke to the prisoner several times, but never about thisâ€”I did not know he had purchased coral; I sent him there, he did not speak to me about the coralâ€”I heard the prisoner had purchased some coral and had not received it, and I went and saw the prisoner's wifeâ€”I was not at Middlesex Sessions.

HERMANN ZOLINGER . I live at Commercial Road, and am a travellerâ€”I was with the prisoner and we met the prosecutor in Church Lane on Wednesday, 22nd Septemberâ€”he said to the prisoner that he had some

corals to sell and that a woman had told him the prisoner wanted to buy someâ€”the prisoner said, "Yes, I want to buy some"â€”the prosecutor said "I have got some, and I am willing to sell them to you for 2l. 10s. although they are worth 4l."â€”the prisoner said he would buy itâ€”the prosecutor said the corals were at his lodgings, "Come along and we will go and look at them. I will go with you, but before I go I want,2l. because I want to send it to Germany "â€”they then went away togetherâ€”I did not see them go in the direction of the money changer's office, which is near thereâ€”I saw the prosecutor in Backchurch Lane next day with Engellâ€”I had no conversation with themâ€”I did not see them at the post-office.

Cross-examined. I did not see Goldberg that dayâ€”nothing was said in my presence about taking a watch out of pawnâ€”I was there till they went away, and I heard everything don't know that anything was said about taking a ship to go to Hamburgâ€”the money changer's is about 15 or 20 paces from where the conversation took placeâ€”I did not go there with them, nor did I see them go into or come out of itâ€”I do not know Davis. (Called into Court.) I did not tell him I would give him 1l. if he would come and swear that he heard the prosecutor offer to sell coral to the prisoner; it is not true.
Re-examined. After the first remand at Worship Street I offered to introduce the prisoner's wife to a solicitor.

AARON ARIAH GROSSE . I live at 190, Jubilee Street, Whitechapel, and am the prisoner's brotherâ€”one evening in September I went on board a ship with the prisoner and a countryman of mine who has gone homeâ€”while on board I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor thereâ€”I asked the prisoner "What are you doing here?"â€”he said 'I have purchased some corals from this man," pointing to the prosecutorâ€”I don t know if the prosecutor was near enough to hearâ€”he said nothingâ€”subsequently the prisoner said "Give me the corals," and then the prosecutor went to and opened the box, and said "I left the corals at the lodgings, come with me to the lodgings, and I will get them"â€”I went away from the ship alone, and waited on the shore till the prisoner and prosecutor came on shore, and then we all went to Mr. Lipschitz'sâ€”as we were waiting outside Lipschitz came and said "If you give me another 23s. I will bring you out the corals"â€”the prisoner said "I have no business with, send me out the man from whom I have purchased the coralsâ€”the prosecutor came out, and they had a dispute, and I said to my brother "Let us go home, and I will see about it tomorrow"â€”we then went homeâ€”before doing so there was a crowd, and some screamingâ€”Lips
chitz was making the outcryâ€”I was not struck on the headâ€”the prose
cutor has not threatened me at all.

Cross-examined. I did not go in the same boat with the prosecutor and the prisoner to the shipâ€”I was, there when the others arrivedâ€”the four men heard the conversation, and were present when the box was openedâ€”all four were there; it was between decksâ€”I went away first from the ship with the boy that brought the box for my countrymanâ€”I left him thereâ€”I did not see what became of the box after it was openedâ€”when the prisoner and prosecutor came back to the shore they had left the box on the ship; I don't know why they did soâ€”they said they only came back for the box of corals that was left at the lodgingsâ€”they arranged to leave the box on board the ship, come back, and fetch it with
the coralsâ€”I heard that on the shipâ€”I don't know about the cookâ€”they did not say with whom they were going to leave the box, and I don't know whom they left it with.
Re-examined. I left the prisoner and prosecutor on the boat talkingâ€”I saw the box open on board.

MARKS VEISKORN . I am a cigarette maker, of Lesley Streetâ€”the prosecutor came to see me in September, and told me he had some corals to sellâ€”he complained that he wanted to go home, but had no money to pay for the journeyâ€”he came again and complained of the same thingâ€”I met him in the street, and he said good-bye as he was going homeâ€”I said "Where did you get the money from?"â€”he said "I have sold some corals to Nachen Shapira."
Cross-examined. That conversation was in September.

ANNIE VEISKORN . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”I remember the prosecutor saying good-bye to my husband in the streetâ€”my husband asked him where he got the money from, and he said he had sold some corals to Shapira.
Cross-examined. I don't remember the dateâ€”he did not say how much he had sold the coral for, or whether he had the money.

GUILTY .â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

45.
HENRY HALLEY,
FREDERICK WILLIAM LEWIS , and
RICHARD CASTLE (20),
Stealing a case of cigars, value 180l., the property of
Edwin Fardell and others, the masters of Castle. Second Count, receiving the same.

CASTLE
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. GOODRICH Prosecuted; MESSRS. POLAND and FULTON Defended.

RICHARD CASTLE . I have pleaded guilty to this theft of a case of cigarsâ€”on 1st September I was a carman in the employ of Fardell and Co., contractors, of The Crescent, Minoriesâ€”on the morning of that day I received instructions to take a Yarmouth cart to the London and North-Western Railway at Aldgate, and fetch a case of cigars, and then take it to the London and St. Katherine's Dock Companyâ€”I went there and signed the receipt in the ordinary way, left the station about o'clock, and went from there to Hoxton, and stopped at the top of Ivy Lane; Davis was with me thenâ€”I had met him before I went for the cigars to Aldgate; I went home to my breakfast before I went there, and I then met Davis, and asked him if he would come for a ride, and he got into the cart and went to the London and North-Western Railway, at Aldgate, with meâ€”I went to the Unicorn public-house, at the top of Ivy Lane, and from there I went to the Camel public-house in Philip Street, Kingsland Road; that is in the immediate neighbourhood of the other public-houseâ€”I there had drink at Davis's expense; it was then about a quarter to 12â€”Halley, whom I knew, came into the public-house, and we drank together, Halley payingâ€”he called me outside and said "What have you in the case?"â€”I said "They are cigars"â€”the cart with the case was then outside the public-houseâ€”he asked me to show him the shipping-notes, those I had got from Mr. Fardell's officeâ€”I showed them to him; he told me to get up in the cart and he, Davis, and I jumped up

and drove awayâ€”I drove a little way and then I asked Halley to take the reins, while I put my coat onâ€”we drove to the Loggerheads, at the back of Shoreditch Church; we reached there about half-past 12â€”Halley went inside, leaving Davis and me outsideâ€”he came back with Lewis, the landlord of the houseâ€”they came up to the cart and looked at the case, and then went away for about 10 minutes, and then they came backâ€”Halley asked me for the notes, which he gave to Lewis, and after another five minutes Halley asked me to fetch the case insideâ€”I got it on my back and Halley helped me take it into the Three Loggerheads into a little tap-room on the leftâ€”we went in by the bar entranceâ€”I put the case on a table, and then Halley opened it with a hammer and chiselâ€”Halley looked inside, and I went to do so, but the prisoners told me to go away, and said there were cigarettes insideâ€”Halley told me to go away for three or four hours, and Lewis gave him 2s. to give meâ€”Lewis said in the presence of Halley and his potman that they would get the case burnt and put the cigarettes in ginger-beer bottlesâ€”Lewis's pot
man was there all the time. (Pettitt was called into Court.) That is the man; he came into the little room when we took the case there, and I believe he burnt the case, though I did not see itâ€”I went outside and had a drink with the 2s. that had been given meâ€”I had had a drop of gin before thatâ€”then, about half-past 1 o'clock, I and Davis got up in the cart and drove away to the Cambridge Heath Road, where we put the nose-bag on the pony and came away, leaving the cart with a case in it in one of the turnings thereâ€”I never left Davis all the afternoonâ€”at a quarter to 5 o'clock we were in the Unicorn, at Hoxton, having come there from the Loggerheads at 4 o'clockâ€”we went back to the Loggerheads at half-past 5, where I saw Lewis behind the bar, and Halley came in just as I didâ€”Halley gave me a sovereign; we were both just inside the public-house, and Lewis behind the bar, where Davis was having a drinkâ€”Halley said "Will you give me five shil
lings to give Mr. Lewis, because he said he could take a cab and fetch a man to buy some of the stuff, the cigars"â€”I gave five shillings to Halley and he gave it to Lewis, who went out and came back in about half an hourâ€”I, Halley, and Davis stayed in the house during the half hourâ€”Lewis came back in a pony trap with another man, and then Halley told me to go away for a couple of hoursâ€”I did not go away, but stayed in the bar with Davis for about three hoursâ€”Halley and Lewis went insideâ€”about 7 o'clock Halley came into the bar, and asked me and Davis to go for a walk with himâ€”we went as far as the Kings-land Road together, and then Halley gave me 9l. in a public-house in the Kingsland Road, at the corner of a yard by a police stationâ€”we had drink there which Halley paid for, and then he gave me 9l. in sovereigns in the bar of the houseâ€”he said "Give me a bit for the man that fetched me to you"â€”I gave him 10s. out of the 9l., one of which I changed for drink, and he said that was not enoughâ€”I gave him no moreâ€”I did not return to my employmentâ€”on 3rd November I was taken into custodyâ€”the story I have told to-day is true in all respectsâ€”before I left the Loggerheads, Lewis told me to give his barman Pettitt a bit of silver for burning the case, and I gave him half-a-crownâ€”that was the last occasion of my being at Lewis's that night.
Cross-examined. I have known Davis about eight months; I don't go with him much; he is not a friend of mineâ€”I met him on 1st September

by accident, and told him I was going to the railway station to get a box of cigars, and he then got up and went with meâ€”the case of cigars weighed about 254 lb.; I did not weigh itâ€”I had been at Mr. Fardell's about seven monthsâ€”the case came down by crane into the cart at Aldgateâ€”Davis saw it loweredâ€”I knew it was a case of cigars; it was described on the orderâ€”I know Andrews; he is not a friend of mineâ€”he went to fetch Halley; I did not know he had gone for him before he went to Halleyâ€”I saw him standing outside the Unicorn that day talking to Davisâ€”I don't know if he is a friend of Davis'sâ€”I knew him before from being in the Unicornâ€”the first thing I did, having got the cigars into the cart, was that I said to Davis "Do you know where to sell these cigars?"â€”we did not make up our minds to sell them before we got to Hoxton, but after we got the cigars, I and Davis agreed to take them and sell them somewhereâ€”I did not know at that time where to take them toâ€”I made the proposition to sell them by saying "Do you know where to sell these cigars?"â€”he said "I will soon find somebody"â€”I only said it as a lark at first; I did not mean it at firstâ€”Davis took it in earnest, and said "I can soon find some one"â€”I said I did not know nothing about it at firstâ€”Davis did not lead me into itâ€”Andrews was not examined before the Magistrateâ€”he did not get into the cart with us; he went away, and came back in about a quarter of an hour with Halleyâ€”we were then at the Camelâ€”it was a pony in the cart, and the cart had Mr. Fardell's name and address on the outsideâ€”it was about half-past 12 when we got to the Loggerheads firstâ€”Davis held my hat while I and Halley carried the case inâ€”it was pretty heavy, and took two men to lift itâ€”it was opened then and there in the tap-room in broad daylight between 12 and 1â€”I saw plenty of people aboutâ€”there were not any in the bar of the public-houseâ€”Davis did not come into the tap-roomâ€”I believe it was the tap-roomâ€”I had spoken to Halley before at the top of Barton Court in Hoxtonâ€”I did not know he was in the service of Lewis's father at the Duke of Gloucester for yearsâ€”he said they would get some one to burn the case out of the wayâ€”up to this time I had received no money, and nothing had been said about moneyâ€”I handed over the case without making any arrangement as to what I was to get, and Davis the sameâ€”I had one other case in the cart: a case of perfumery spiritsâ€”I and Davis aban
doned the cart and the property in Cambridge Heath Roadâ€”we had been at the Loggerheads about an hour and a half, and the cart had been waiting outside the whole time; I had put the nosebag on the horseâ€”after abandoning the cart I went to Davis's house in Ivy Laneâ€”I got the sovereign about half past fiveâ€”I am sure I was at the Logger-heads from about half past five to sevenâ€”I cannot tell the exact time, I believe it was from half past five to sevenâ€”when I got the sovereign nothing was said as to what I was to have in additionâ€”I cannot give the name of the public house where I received the 9l., it is the first public house by the police station, on the left hand side in the Kings-land Road, by the corner of a yardâ€”I changed a sovereign there in the presence of Halley and Davisâ€”I was at Fardell's before for about eighteen months, and then I went on a schooner round the coastâ€”before that I was at a job in Commercial Street, going about with a barrow, taking goods out; it was an honest jobâ€”I once stole 7s. 6d. from my master's shop; I was then at Anderson's, a tarpaulin placeâ€”that was about

two years ago, it was the first time I stoleâ€”I was sent to prison for three months for stealing the moneyâ€”I did not know Davis then I am sure of thatâ€”that is the only time I have been convictedâ€”I live at home; I have got a brother seventeen or eighteenâ€”I am twentyâ€”I believe he is at home, I don't knowâ€”he was at home in September, and in employmentâ€”I believe he has been in trouble for gambling, only for that; that is all I knowâ€”this is the first time I have been examinedâ€”I pleaded guilty and offered to give evidenceâ€”I don't know if I expect to get a little off by giving evidenceâ€”my brother did not get six months for fraud, I am sure of thatâ€”Davis is in no employmentâ€”he is a coster-monger.

CHARLES EDWIN FARDELL I am a contractor, in the Minories, of the firm of Fardell and Co.â€”Castle was in my employment at the beginning of Septemberâ€”on 1st September he was sent out with a Yarmouth cart and a pony to fetch a case of cigars from the Aldgate Railway Stationâ€”he should have taken it to East Smithfield, the St. Katherine's Dock Station, and he had also to fetch a case of perfumeryâ€”he did not return to my premisesâ€”that night a cart was brought home by some strange boy who had found it in the streetâ€”on 11th September, in company with Harding, I went to Hoxton, where I saw Davis, and heard him make a statementâ€”I was present when Halley was arrestedâ€”I heard Davis's statement read to him in the streetâ€”Halley said he knew nothing about it, and "I don't know what you are talking about"â€”a house was men
tioned down at the Coal Arches, Columbia Marketâ€”Davis had described the position of the house to meâ€”I did not know which it was, and when that was read to Halley he said "Yes, that is the Loggerheads, my governor's son's house"â€”I know the Duke of Gloucester is kept by Lewis's father.

Cross-examined. Nothing was said about the sign of the public house in the statement, and Halley identified it by saying "Yes, that is the public house kept by my governor's son," that is the prisoner Lewisâ€”until that time I had not heard of the name of the public houseâ€”Halley said "I don't know nothing about it," and also, "I don't understand it"â€”the police searched the Loggerheads from top to bottom; that was about two months afterwards; nothing was foundâ€”that was the only house searched to my knowledge.
Re-examined. The search was the day Lewis was arrested, at about four a.m., in the present monthâ€”the value of the cigars was 180l.

CHARLES DAVIS . I am a costermonger, of 34, Ivy Lane, Hoxtonâ€”I know Castleâ€”I saw him on Wednesday, 1st September, about 9 o'clock in Hoxtonâ€”I rode in his cart to Aldersgate Street railway station to fetch a case, and a case of cigars came downâ€”there was another small case in the cartâ€”he said he was going to drive home to get some money for dinner, and he drove to the Unicorn public-house, Hoxtonâ€”he then want to get his money, and I saw him again at 11 o'clock at the Unicorn, opposite Ivy Lane, and he said "Do you know where to sell this case of cigars?"â€”I said "No, and I don't want to know"â€”we went into the Unicorn and had two or three drinks, and then left there and went to the Camel public-house in Philip Street and had a drink; that was about 12 o'clockâ€”Halley came in there about five minutes past 12 while we were drinking, and then Castle had a drink with him and with me, and they went outside together, I remained inside; they came back again and

drank up their drink, and then both jumped up in the cartâ€”Castle called me, and said "Come for a drive," and I got up and we drove to the Three Loggerheads at the back of Columbia Marketâ€”Halley went in there, and remained two or three minutes, and then came out with Lewis; I had been standing by the pony during that time, and Castle was in the cartâ€”Lewis looked at the case of cigars, and then Castle gave him a piece of paper, but I did not hear what was saidâ€”Lewis then walked up to the corner of the turning, and stood there a few minutes, and then went into his public-houseâ€”Halley said "All right" and Castle carried the case of cigars into the Three Loggerheads, and put them in a little room on the left hand side as you go inâ€”Castle then came out and put on his hat, and then I went with him into the bar, and we had a drink together; I didn't see Lewis there thenâ€”then Castle told me that Halley had told him to come back in two or three hours' time, and we two left in the cart, and drove to a public-house at the top of Columbia Marketâ€”this was about 2 o'clock; I then left Castle, and did not see him again till a little before 5, when I saw him outside the Unicorn public-house in Hoxtonâ€”we left there, and went round to the Three Logger-heads and saw Halley, and he and Castle had a conversation which I did not hearâ€”I then saw him call Castle out and give him a sovereign, and I saw Castle change the sovereign afterwardsâ€”we stopped there till about half-past 6, and then Halley and I and Castle went to the first public-house past the police-station in the Kingsland Road, I do not know the name of itâ€”we all three had drink there, and then Halley called Castle away from me as we stood at the bar and gave him some money; I heard the jingle of money passing into his hand, and Castle told me it was 9l.â€”we left together about ten minutes to 7, and then separatedâ€”I saw Castle again that night about 8 o'clock outside the Variety Theatre in Pitfield Street; we had a drink, and then I leftâ€”I met him again about 9 o'clock at the corner of James Street, at a beer shop; we had a drink together, and I borrowed 6s. 6d., of him to go to market.

Cross-examined by MR. POLAND I was taken in custody by Harding, I believe, on Saturday, 11th Septemberâ€”I was formally remanded in custody till Monday, the 20th, and I was then charged with Halley at the Mansion House and we were both dischargedâ€”when I was taken in custody I told the officer all about thisâ€”I did not say "I see I am in for penal servitude , and I will tell; "I merely said "I am in for it, and I will tell you," I did not mention penal servitudeâ€”I told him "About o'clock last Wednesday week I saw Dick Castle in Hoxton, with one of Fardell's carts with two cases in it"â€”I was excited thenâ€”I was after-wards taken as a witness, and I then said when examined on oath, "On Wednesday, 1st September, I saw the prisoner Castle; he was then driving a pony and Yarmouth cart in Ivy Lane; there were two cases in the cart; that was eleven o'clock; he said to me 'Will you come for a ride,' &c.?"â€”I did not say a word before the Magistrate that I had gone to Aldgate to fetch the case; I didn't think of thatâ€”it was after I had heard Castle's statement before the Magistrate, in which he said that I was with him, that I first mentioned itâ€”I didn't think it was necessary to tell I was with him when he got the caseâ€”Castle first spoke in the cart about selling these cigars, he said "Do you know where you can sell this case of cigars?" and pointed to the case in the cartâ€”I didn't know at that time that he intended to steal it and make

money of it, but when he asked me that I did, there was no mistake about what he meantâ€”I didn't want to have anything to do with itâ€”I didn't know where he had to deliver it, but I knew he had to deliver it to the ownerâ€”I did not say "I will soon find some one"â€”I did not find anyoneâ€”I didn't look for anybodyâ€”I know a man named Andrews, I didn't find him or look for himâ€”I saw him in the bar, but he is no friend of mine; I don't know what work he does, I have known him a good while by seeing himâ€”I said before the Magistrate "Castle told me Halley had paid him 1l., it was then I suspected something"â€”I didn't suspect anything before that, because I saw him give Mr. Lewis a piece of paper, and I thought that was a note for the goods, and that he was going to deliver them to himâ€”the cart was waiting outside the Three Loggerheads three quarters of a hour altogetherâ€”Halley followed Castle in with the case of cigarsâ€”I only borrowed the 6s. 6d., I did not get any new clothes, I was then just as I am nowâ€”I had not got new clothes on when I was taken in custody; if the officer says "I noticed Davis had new boots and a hat and coat "it is untrue; it is a mistake, that is what I told him Castle had on.
Re-examined. Castle took the case in and Halley walked behindâ€”I left Castle about two o'clockâ€”we were parted about an hour; he came down to my place for me.

ROBERT YEOMAN . I live at 10, Philip Street, Kingsland Roadâ€”on 1st September I was potman at the Camel public-house, Philip Street, and saw Davis come in with Halley and Castle, about eleven o'clock as near as I can say; they had a drink, tout I can't say who paid for itâ€”they were in the house about five minutes, and then walked outside to
gether and got up into a small cart in which there were two or three cases, and drove away towards Kingsland Road.

Cross-examined. I saw the cart drive upâ€”I said before the Magistrate "The two prisoners and another were in the cart"â€”there were only two in the dock then, Castle was arrested in Novemberâ€”Davis was in the habit of coming to that public-house, but not Castleâ€”I do not know a man named Andrewsâ€”Castle, Davis, and Halley all came in togetherâ€”I noticed the cart draw up, and saw the cases after they got out of the cart, and before they came into the public houseâ€”I was cleaning the windows from the inside at the timeâ€”I did not go outside.

Re-examined. I noticed the trap stop at the door, and I saw Davis, Castle, and Halley in itâ€”I noticed them as they came in the barâ€”there were not other customers in the bar while they were there, to my recol
lection; it is a very dull house of a morningâ€”I am certain about these three men.

WILLIAM HARDING (City Detective). On 11th September, about 4.30 p.m., I went with Detective Hughes and Mr. Fardell, to Ivy Lane, Hoxton, and saw Davis, who made a statement to us, after which Murphy brought Halley to me in custody in the streetâ€”I said to him, "I am an officer of the City Police, do you know that man?" pointing to Davisâ€”he said "Yes"â€”I said "l am making inquiries respecting a large robbery of cigars from Messrs. Fardell's, and that man has made a statement seriously compromising you in the matter if it is true; he states that about eleven o'clock on the morning of the 1st he saw Dick Castle in one of Fardell's pony carts in St. James's Road, at the top of

Ivy Lane, Hoxton; he had two cases in the cart, and he said to him, "Do you know where I can sell a case of cigars?" he said "No, and I don't want to," he then went with me to the Duke of Gloucester, and Halley came down, and we all went to the Camel public house, Philip Street, Hoxton, where we had a drink, and then drove to a public house at the back of Columbia Market;" Halley said, "I know that is my governor's son's house, the Loggerheads; Dick and Halley took the case into the house; I had half a pint of beer, for which Halley paid; we afterwards met about four o'clock in the afternoon at a public house near Kingsland Police-station, and there Tod gave Castle 10l., he paid me 2s. he owed me, and gave me 4s. 6d. besides"â€”Tod is Halleyâ€”Davis said "It is the first time I have done anything of the sort, and I am very sorry for what I have done"â€”they were both taken to the Mansion House and were dischargedâ€”Davis had a new pair of boots on, and a tidy coat; he looked respectable for a man of his class.

Cross-examined. At the station Halley said, "I know nothing about it; I don't understand it"â€”I cannot be mistaken about Davis saying to me, "I see I am in for penal servitude , and I will tell"â€”Mr. Fardell was presentâ€”he did not say "I see I am in for it and I will tell you;" he said. "I see I am in for penal servitude"â€”Davis and Halley were both arrested on the 11th, Davis firstâ€”they were taken before a Magis
trate and formally remanded to the Monday week, and from the 11th I knew the name of the public-house where it was said the case had been taken; I went there that nightâ€”it is Lewis's father's house and Lewis has the licenceâ€”his father keeps the Duke of Gloucester, and has been there 16 or 17 yearsâ€”Halley has been potman at the Duke of Gloucester for some years; it is a mile or a mile and a half from the Camelâ€”on 20th September, when Halley and Davis were in custody, I was examined and so was Mr. Yeoman, and Halley and Davis were both dischargedâ€”I can
not say that I searched the Loggerheads, but Lewis offered me every facility for doing soâ€”I looked round the bottom part of the house for the case.
Re-examined. I had no search warrantâ€”I went there to make inquiries.

GEORGE NEWMAN (Policeman). On 3rd November, at 8 p.m., I took Castle in Hoxton, and Halley at 11 o'clock the same nightâ€”I told him the charge was stealing and receiving cigars, the property of Mr. Fardellâ€”he made no replyâ€”I went to the Loggerheads at 12 o'clock but Lewis was not at homeâ€”I waited till a quarter to 3 a.m., when he came home, and I told him I should have to take him in custody for stealing and receiving a case of cigars, the property of Mr. Fardellâ€”he said, "I am very sorry to hear that."

GEORGE BENJAMIN PARSONS . I live at 141, Old Bethnal Green Roadâ€”on 1st September, about 7.30, I found a pony and cart in St. Jude Street; a lot of children were with it and a boy had been left with it, but he said he was not going to mind it all the timeâ€”I saw Fardell's name on the cart and drove it there.

MR. POLAND submitted that there was no corroboration of the evidence of the accomplices, and therefore there was no case to go to the Jury. MR. GOODRICH contended that although Davis was a tainted witness he was not in any peril, and therefore his evidence ought to go to the Jury. The COMMON SERJEANT con
sidered there was no case to go to the Jury as to LEWIS.
NOT GUILTY .

WILLIAM PETTITT . I live at 282, Wick Road, Hackney Wickâ€”on Sep
tember 1st I was potman and barman at Mr. Lewis's, but am not there nowâ€”I have just come out of hospital with rheumatic feverâ€”on Septem
ber 1st a man named George Andrews (not Sam) was repairing the beer engineâ€”I believe he is hereâ€”I opened the house at 7 a.m. and continued on duty in the bar till between 12 and 1â€”I went up to my dinner between 2 and 3â€”I did not see Mr. Fardell's van outside the house for two hoursâ€”I did not see Castle and Davisâ€”it is not true that while I was there Castle and Halley carried in a heavy case and broke it open in my pre
sence, nor did I afterwards burn the case nor did I get 2s. 6d. for doing soâ€”there is a little tap-room thereâ€”I did not see Mr. Lewis that day; he was not in the bar at 12 o'clock.

Cross-examined. I went there at 7 a.m. and was in the bar till between 12 and 1â€”my work was sweeping up, and finishing; it was away from the bar; I was a little over an hour doing thatâ€”I then went to my dinnerâ€”I went into the London Hospital a month ago last Tuesday, and I was there last Thursday week when a policeman came to see me, and Mr. Fardell; they told me they had come to make inquiries with regard to the burning of the caseâ€”I did not tell them that my memory was so bad, having suffered so much that I was unable to recollect anything about itâ€”I told Mr. Fardell that my memory failed meâ€”he and the gentleman sitting on his left asked me if I saw them pass through the bar to Mr. Lewis, and I said "No," my memory failed meâ€”I went downstairs into the doctor's room to speak to Mr. Fardell, who said that a statement had been made incriminating me, and that I was said to be the person who burnt the caseâ€”I did not tell him that my memory failed me and that I recollected nothing about it.
Re-examined. I am quite sure that no case was burnt.

FREDERICK WILLIAM LEWIS . I am 24 years of ageâ€”I have held the licence of the Three Loggerheads, Virginia Street, Bethnal Green, for five yearsâ€”my father is the landlord of the Duke of Gloucester, and the Three Loggerheads is also his, but I manage itâ€”on 1st September I did not leave my bedroom till about a quarter to one, having been out the previous evening to a swimming entertainment, when I was in the water for three hours, off and on, and I was tiredâ€”I went down about 1.30 and left the house two or three minutes before two o'clock, and went to the Spread Eagle and did not come back till 12 o'clockâ€”I have heard the story about Mr. Fardell's cart coming there and the case being brought into the taproom in my presenceâ€”that is untrueâ€”I know of no cigars being brought there or of the case being burntâ€”my wife was at home attending to the bar; she is hereâ€”I did not see George Andrews, a pewter worker, in the bar, but I had ordered him the day before to come.

Cross-examined. I do not know the prisoner Castle; I never saw him till he was in the dock at the Mansion House, nor Davis eitherâ€”I do not know Castle's mother; she did not come to see me subsequent to this charge. (Mrs. Castle was here brought into Court.) I have seen her about this Court since I have been here this weekâ€”she did not come and see me and bring me this piece of paper (produced) from her son, nor did she tell me her son was in trouble for this affair and that I must assist her; that is utterly falseâ€”I did not say "You must go to Halley about it,
because it is his affair"â€”I have not seen her except at the Mansion House and hereâ€”she has been pointed out to me.

CAROLINE LEWIS . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”I assist in the barâ€”I accompanied my husband to this swimming entertainment, and on the next day, 1st September, he did not get up till nearly 1 o'clockâ€”I was serving up to that time, and a man named Andrews was repairing the bar engineâ€”Pettitt was also thereâ€”my husband did not come down into the bar at all up to 1 o'clockâ€”no van of Mr. Fardell's came there that day to my knowledge, nor was any case broken by Halley and Castleâ€”no case was put into the little parlour at the side and broken upâ€”my husband went out about five minutes to 2 and returned very late, it might have been 12.30.

JOHN CRESSWELL . I live at 80, St. John Street Road, and am traveler for Meyer and Son, mineral water dealers, of Clerkenwellâ€”I have supplied mineral water to the Three Loggerheads for five or six yearsâ€”I went there on 1st September from 12 to half-past 1, and inquired for Mr. Lewis; I could not see him, but I saw Mrs. Lewisâ€”I did not; deliver any goods, but I collected some bottlesâ€”I left about a quarter to 1â€”I saw a pewterer doing some work in the barâ€”I saw nothing of Fardell's cart outside, nor did I see Halley there, nor a cigar case brought into the houseâ€”I went into the tap-room; my bottles were kept there, packed readyâ€”it is about 16 feet long by 10.
Cross-examined. The tap-room is the first bar from Columbia Market entrance, 'and the first door on the left after you get into the bar.

JACOB LEWIS . My son keeps the Three Loggerherds; I keep the Duke of Gloucesterâ€”I have been a licensed holder 19 yearsâ€”I have known Halley 17 to 18 years, and he has been my potman 14 years off and onâ€”he is a thoroughly respectable manâ€”his duty in the morning was cleaning up the place, cleaning the pots, and at times assisting me in the cellarâ€”he was with me in the bar on 1st Septemberâ€”I had had a stock of beer in the day before, and we had to overthrow it to prevent it from working overâ€”we were doing that from 25 minutes to a quarter to 12â€”Halley then went and finished his pots, and brought them into the barâ€”he went to toner at a quarter to 1; I drew his dinner beer for himâ€”he lives 200 yards from my houseâ€”my house is about three-quarters of a mile from the Camel, and the Camel is about a mile and a quarter from the Three Loggerheadsâ€”I had occasion to go out that day; I returned at 3 o'clock, and Halley was there thenâ€”he remained till 5, when he went home to wash and dressâ€”he returned at 6.30, and remained till we closed the house at 12.30.
Cross-examined. I am the father of the defendant who has been acquittedâ€”I live in Hoxton, half a mile from my public-house, and am in the habit of going home at mid-day, generally before dinner.
By the COURT. I live on my licensed premises and dine there, but I went away at a quarter or 10 minutes to 1, and was away till 3.

JAMES CLARK . I am a box manufacturer, next door to the Duke of Gloucesterâ€”on 1st September I was sending out some special goods, loading a cart outside my door, and saw Halley thereâ€”some of the water from the trap which he was washing came in contact with my goods, and spoilt one or two of them.
CHARLES BATES . I keep the Spread Eagle, Kingsland Roadâ€”on 1st September Mr. William Lewis and Mr. Tapps came to my house just after
2 o'clock; I had just had my dinnerâ€”Lewis stayed till just after 6â€”we were playing at skittles.
Cross-examined. It was not Lewis and the prisoner who were at my house, it was Lewis and Mr. Tappsâ€”Halley received a good character.

MARGARET CASTLE . I am a widow, and mother of the prisoner Castleâ€”I live at 97, St. John Street Road, Hoxtonâ€”I heard of my son's being in trouble on the evening of the day the case was missing, and when he was taken in custody in November Mr. Fardell came and told meâ€”I went and saw him in the cells at the Mansion Houseâ€”he sent me a piece of paper when he was away after that, and in consequence of that I went on Mr. Lewis at the Three Loggerheads on a Saturday morningâ€”I can't tell you the date; I should suppose it was about five weeks ago; it was before my son was charged at the Mansion House, and while he was away from homeâ€”I went four times that day but could not see Mr. Lewisâ€”I saw him about 10 o'clock on Saturday night behind the barâ€”I said "Can I speak to you for a moment?"â€”he said "I have a gentle
man just come"â€”I said "Will you take this letter and read it, please? it is from my son"â€”he took the letter, and in a few minutes afterwards he called me out in the street, and said "I can't help you in your trouble"â€”I said "It is not my trouble; I should think it was your own; my son is banished from my home without anything to eat, and without anything to get work, and what was he to do?"â€”he said "I can't help it," and gave me the letter and went in, and when my son came home he went to him, and I went after the ladâ€”that was about 22nd October.
By the COURT. I handed him the paper the first time I went.

HALLEYâ€”
GUILTY â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour
CASTLEâ€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

46.
WILLIAM OLDFIELD (24)
, Feloniously stealing a pair of boots, the goods of
Samuel John Kitchener.

SAMUEL JOHN KITCHENER (The younger). I live with my father at 22, Rathbone Street, Canning Town, where he keeps a boot-shopâ€”on Lord Mayor's day I was in the shop in the morningâ€”the prisoner took a pair of boots from the outside of the shop and ran round the corner of St. Lawrence Streetâ€”he did not pay for them.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. It was at dinner time.

SAMUEL JOHN KITCHENER I am a boot maker, at 22, Rathbone Street, Canning Townâ€”on Lord Mayor's day, about half-past 1 o'clock, I saw the prisoner outside my shop, and shortly after I missed a pair of boots which had been hanging on my doorpost; their value was 6s. 6d.
Cross-examined. I did not say I saw you running away with the bootsâ€”I saw you three minutes before the boots were missed.
ELLEN JACKSON . I am the wife of Thomas Jackson, of Peter Street, Canning Townâ€”on 9th November I saw the prisoner take the boots from the side of the doorâ€”I was turning the corner when he knocked
up against me; he put them under his left arm when he had taken them down, and he ran down Lawrence Streetâ€”it was half-past 1â€”the Lord Mayor's show did not pass down Peter Street.

CHARLES FOULKES (Policeman K 571). On 11th November, about 10 p.m., I went to 8, Montescue Street, where I found the prisoner underâ€”a bed, covered over with a lot of old ragsâ€”I told him I should take him into custody for stealing a pair of boots from 22, Rathbone Streetâ€”he said "What boots? I know nothing about it, I was at the Lord Mayor's Show on Tuesday"â€”on the way to the station he said "And if I did I would not tell you; when I come out I will do some
thing to be locked up for."
GUILTY .

He then PLEDED GUILTY to a conviction of felony on 23rd July, 1886,â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

47.
WILLIAM SMITH (23)
PLEADED GUILTY **
to stealing a purse and 1l. 3s. 5 1/2 d. from the person of
Mary Peddie, after a conviction of felony in April, 1885.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour. And

48.
JOHN PEARCE (18)
to stealing a bay gelding of
Charles Cree.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Six Months' Hard Labour. There was another indictment against the prisoner.

49.
ALBERT STANLEY (24) and
WILLIAM BRATTON
, Stealing a can, a bunch of keys, and 3l. 1s., the goods and money of
C. H. Moseley.

EMMA PARKER . I am a barmaid to Mr. Moseley, who keeps the Golden Anchor public-house, East Greenwichâ€”on 29th October, soon after 5 in the morning, the prisoners came in, Bratton first and Stanley about a minute afterâ€”they had some refreshmentâ€”Stanley went out first, and then Bratton jumped over the bar and took a quart can containing 2l. 16s. in silver and 5s. in bronze, and ran outâ€”I went after him and tried to catch him, but could notâ€”I had seen one of them before about four years agoâ€”they were in the house together the night beforeâ€”the same evening I went to the station, and saw the prisoners with seven others, and identified them.

Cross-examined by Stanley. You asked me the time, and if the clock was right, and you said you were going to catch the train at half-past 5 across the waterâ€”you had a few minutes' conversation with me.

Cross-examined by Bratton. I did not identify you at first, you kept your head down, but as you were following the others out, you turned sideways, and I picked you outâ€”I am perfectly sure of you, I could pick you out of thousands.

JOSEPH DALEY . I am potman to the prosecutorâ€”on the evening of 28th October, about 6 or 7 o'clock, I saw the prisoners in the bar together as I was going to light my lampâ€”I went to the station and picked them out.
WILLIAM DRAIN (Policeman RR 43). On 29th October I was on Maze
Hill, Greenwich, about 5 minutes to 6 a.m., and saw the prisoners coming down the hill, going in a direct line to the prosecutor's house.
Cross-examined by Stanley. I am quite sure about the time, it was just getting daylightâ€”you passed close by me.

SAMUEL CORNWALL (Policeman RR 24). On 29th October, about 6.20 p.m., I saw Bratton in Trafalgar Roadâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said, All right, I was not there"â€”at the station he was placed among seven othersâ€”Parker did not recognise him at first, but when he was leaving behind the other she said, "That is the man that stole the money."

ISABELLA BRATTON . I am the prisoner's mother; he lives with meâ€”on 29th October he was at home; he did not go out till between 10 and 11 in the morning; he was at home and in bed at the time the robbery was committed; he was in bed when I got up at 10 minutes to 7â€”he got up about 9 o'clockâ€”he slept in the same roomâ€”there was no one else in the house.

FREDERICK FERRIS . I am a labourerâ€”I have known Bratton a number of years; we work together at Silvertownâ€”on Friday morning, 29th October, about 6 o'clock, I was coming down Maze Hill with Stanley, and was with him till 10 o'clock, when he was apprehendedâ€”I do not know anything of Bratton's movements that morningâ€”on the Thursday night I was in the British Queen about 6.30â€”Bratton and a man named Ransom came in about half-past 7.
NOT GUILTY .

50.
ALBERT STANLEY was again indicted
for breaking and entering the shop of
Charles Hydon, and stealing 2001b. weight of cheese, bacon, and butter. Second Count, for receiving the same.

CHARLES WHITEHEAD . I am manager to Charles Hydon and others, cheesemongers, of 16, Hatfield Buildings, Greenwichâ€”on 27th October I closed the premises at 10.30; there was nobody thereâ€”I returned at 7.20 next morning, and found the premises had been broken open by forcing the back window on the ground floorâ€”I missed some cheese, butter, and bacon worth 47s., and 3s. in bronzeâ€”these two pieces of bacon (produced) formed part of that which was stolenâ€”I know it by the brand mark.

ELIZABETH STANLEY . I live at 10, East Place, Greenwichâ€”I am the prisoner's motherâ€”he lives with meâ€”on 28th October I came down about 7 in the morningâ€”I found the prisoner asleep in a chair in the kitchen, dressedâ€”I saw this bacon on the tableâ€”when he awoke I asked him where it came fromâ€”he said he had brought it in, it was all right, and asked me to cook him some for his breakfast, which I did, for him and his wifeâ€”I gave it to my daughter to take to one of the neighbours, and the police met her and brought her backâ€”I told the police that I had bought it; the prisoner being my son I told that untruth, which I was very sorry for afterwardsâ€”I was charged with the unlawful possession, but was discharged.

WILLIAM ALFORD (Policeman R 51). I met the prisoner's wife with this piece of baconâ€”the prisoner was in custody at the time on the previous chargeâ€”I told him of this chargeâ€”he said, "You won't hurt me for breaking in"â€”on the morning of the 28th, about 5.30, I met the prisoner in company with two other men in Woolwich Road, about
130 yards from the prosecutor's houseâ€”I did not notice that they had anything with them.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence alleged that the things were given to him in a sack, and that he knew nothing of the robbery.

div1.p:
GUILTY
on the second Count. â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

51.
HENRY MARTIN
PLEADED GUILTY
to feloniously marrying
Elizabeth Peddie, his wife being then alive.â€”
Two Days' Imprisonment.

52.
JOHN LUCAS (57) was indicted
for divers misdemeanours under the Bankruptcy Act, and also under the Debtors Act.

MESSRS. BESLEY and LEWENEST Prosecuted; MR. COCK Defended. The defendant's examination in bankruptcy having been read, the RECORDER during the progress of the case, more than once intimated that there was no case to go to the Jury, and ultimately directed them to find a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

53.
ELLEN VAUGHAN,
Feloniously and by force taking away
Annie Reed, the younger, aged under 14, with intent to deprive her father of her possession. Second Count, with intent to steal certain articles of clothing.

ANNIE REED . I live at 37, Upper East Street, Greenwich, and am the wife of Thomas Reed, labourerâ€”on 21st July I was confined of this female childâ€”Mrs. Underhill nursed meâ€”on the Friday before Tuesday, 17th September, I was coming down Park Street carrying the child, a basket, and bread in an apronâ€”I met the prisoner, whom I had never seen before to my knowledge; she helped me along to where I lived, with the breadâ€”she said she lived with Wallace, and was in trouble because he had left her, and she was likely to become a motherâ€”when I was about to say good-night she said she would be very thankful if anyone would write a letter for herâ€”I told her I would if she would come on Monday, and I told her if I was not at home to come upstairs and waitâ€”on the following Monday she came, and I arranged for her to come the next nightâ€”she came about 3 o'clock, and remained till nearly 4 o'clock I suppose, and then said she must go to put her children to bedâ€”she came back in about an hour and a half, and we walked up the Trafalgar Road together as far as the Union and back againâ€”I carried my baby, which was in long clothesâ€”a little after 9 we got back to my street doorâ€”I said I must go upstairs and put some coals on the fireâ€”she said "I will hold the baby"â€”I said "Do so," and handed it to her in a large white apron which I threw over its headâ€”I was upstairs about five minutes, and when I came down the prisoner and the baby were goneâ€”she had seen me suckle the childâ€”the baby had on this bodice when the prisoner took it away, and other articles of clothingâ€”I gave information at the police-station within half an hourâ€”on 9th October I went with Howell to 17, Ann Place, Charlton Parkâ€”I went to the door by myself and knockedâ€”it was opened by a Mr. Vaughan, who lived upstairsâ€”the prisoner came to the parlour door with the baby in her armsâ€”I called the sergeant, and told him that was the woman that took my childâ€”after the prisoner said she did not know me nor my baby I went into the prisoner's room; she showed me the babyâ€”the mark on its nose had got very pale

â€”I failed to identify the baby at firstâ€”Vaughan threatened to throw me out of the house and charge me with defamation of characterâ€”the baby had a mark on its nose, and also on its eyeâ€”there was a bit of a disturb
ance, and I and Howell came awayâ€”I saw the child again at Westcomb Park Station on the following Sunday evening, and I and others then identified itâ€”this is itâ€”I and Howell went back to the house to see if we could discover any articles of clothing of my baby, and this bodice, which I identify, was given to me by Mrs. Hennessy.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You had every appearance of becoming a mother.
By the COURT I see the mark on the baby's nose now.

AMELIA UNDERHILL . I live at 3, Clerk's Buildings, Greenwich, and am John Underhill's wifeâ€”I attended Mrs. Reed in her confinement on 21st July, and was with her and her baby for a fortnight and three daysâ€”on Sunday, 10th October, I went with Mr. and Mrs. Reed to the police-station, where I saw and identified the baby as Mrs. Reed's by the marks on its face, and every feature was impressed on my memory, and more so since the child was stolenâ€”it is the child that has just gone out of Courtâ€”I was certain the instant I saw it that it was Mrs. Reed's.

ANNIE QUINNAL . I live at 1, Delafield Road, Charlton, and am the prisoner's daughterâ€”I am 13â€”three years ago my mother fetched me from Maidstone to London, where I lived with her and Vaughan t 17, Ann's Placeâ€”I remember coming home from service on a Tuesday night about 7 o'clock, about a month agoâ€”my mother was out; I went out with two other girls, and came in again; I then found my mother half-dressed walking about the room, and the baby lying on the bed with a gown onâ€”the shutters were up, and the gas lightedâ€”I don't know the timeâ€”there was a pan of water thereâ€”no one else was thereâ€”Mrs. White came in that same morningâ€”the next two or three mornings my mother got up and swept the rooms and then got back into bed and washed the babyâ€”on 9th October I was coming home down Church Lane and there saw Vaughan and Howellâ€”it was in the eveningâ€”I afterwards went home; my mother was not there; the baby wasâ€”my mother afterwards came in.
Cross-examined. You were not sitting on the side of the bed when I came inâ€”you moved from the bed, and asked me what I thought of the babyâ€”I don't remember you then sending me out on an errand.

EMMA HORN . I live at 17, Ann Place, Charlton; the same place as the prisonerâ€”I am the wife of William Hornâ€”the prisoner told me six or seven months ago that she was pregnant, and about July she said she was about to be confinedâ€”she never asked me to give her any helpâ€”I was the only woman lodging in the same houseâ€”I remember on a Tuesday, about six weeks ago, the prisoner going out and coming back about 5.30; she took her clothes off, and asked me if I was going down to the little shopâ€”I said "Yes"â€”she asked me to get her a little water
cressâ€”I brought it to herâ€”she got the young man's teaâ€”she was out after tea, I believeâ€”I did not see her again that eveningâ€”I did not know of the prisoner having been confined of a childâ€”I saw her in bed next day, and she had then got a baby with herâ€”I told her she was artful not to have called meâ€”she said it was no good, as I was rather fidgety about the houseâ€”I said I would have done the best for herâ€”she said Mrs. O'Malley had been to her.
By the COURT. She told me it was her babyâ€”I did not know Mrs. O'Malley.

ELIZABETH WHITE . I live at 2, Ann Street, Charlton, and am marriedâ€”I have known the prisoner about two yearsâ€”she told me about two months ago she expected to be confined; she was then living at this address with Vaughanâ€”on 21st September I went to 17, Ann Street about half-past 10 p.m.; Mr. Vaughan fetched meâ€”I saw the prisoner in bed with the baby which has been in Court, lying by her sideâ€”I asked her whether she had had a midwifeâ€”she said she had had Mrs. O'Malley, and that she had been and gone before I got thereâ€”Vaughan came for me about 10 minutes to 10 p.m.â€”I did not touch the childâ€”she told me Mrs. O'Malley had taken her washing away to do.

ELIZABETH O'MALLEY . I am a midwife, living at 21, Ogilvy Street, Woolwichâ€”I have known the prisoner about three years living in Woolwichâ€”I met her in the street eight or nine months ago, and I next saw her on 9th October between 7 and 7.30â€”I was standing outside my daughter's house, and the prisoner came looking for meâ€”I did not recognise her for the momentâ€”she said she wanted me to do a favour for herâ€”I asked her what it wasâ€”she said she was confined three weeks ago, and she then moved me down a bit from where I was stand
ing, and said she had no one with her when the baby was born, and she told her husband I had attended herâ€”she asked me whether I would oblige her by saying soâ€”she said there was another person claiming the babyâ€”she said if I would tell her husband that he would call on me that night, and that she would pay me anything I asked; she did not mind if it was 10l.â€”I said I would do nothing of the sortâ€”I did not attend her on 21st September, or on any other day in her confinement.
MARGARET HENESSEY . I live at 37, Upper East Street, Greenwich, and am landlady to the prosecutrixâ€”I gave this bodice to Mrs. Reed's baby just a little time after it was born.

RICHARD HOWELL (Police Sergeant R). Information had been given to the police, and on 9th October I went with Mrs. Reed to 17, Ann's Placeâ€”she went to the door and saw the prisoner with the baby on her armâ€”I went into the back parlour, and there were present there the prisoner, Vaughan, the baby, Mrs. Reed, Mrs. Horn, and myselfâ€”I said to Mrs. Reed "Carefully examine that child and see if it is yours"â€”she did, but she could not identify itâ€”the prisoner called Mrs. Reed a wicked, bad woman, and said "It is my child," and that she could prove itâ€”there was great confusion; the prosecutrix was, very excitedâ€”I asked the prisoner when and where she had been confinedâ€”she said a fortnight last Tuesday, and that she could prove it by a number of persons, Mrs. O'Malley, who was the midwife, and Mrs. White, who nursed her, and a number of others, and she asserted it was her childâ€”I left with Mrs. Reedâ€”I went back to the house about 6 o'clock that eveningâ€”I saw her and Vaughan thenâ€”I said to the prisoner "You will have to take me to your midwife"â€”she said "All right"â€”Vaughan said "I will make her go; this has begun to open my eyes"â€”I, the prisoner, and Vaughan walked as far as Church Lane, when she said to Vaughan "George, I must go and tell Annie to mind the baby; she has left the house, and we must have her to mind the baby; I won't be long"â€”she wentâ€”we waited there about a quarter of an hourâ€”she did not comeâ€”then we saw Annie Quinnalâ€”we made further inquiries, and went on to

Mrs. White's, 10, York Street, and afterwards returned to 17, Ann's Placeâ€”the prisoner was outâ€”we waited for about 10 minutes; she returned; it was about a quarter to 8â€”it was a quarter-past 6 when she had left usâ€”it is about 1 1/2 miles from Church Lane to where Mrs. 0'Malley livesâ€”I told her I should take her into custodyâ€”she said "What for?"â€”I said "For stealing Mrs. Reed's child"â€”she said "It is my child"â€”I took her to the station, where I asked her to tell me the name and address of her midwifeâ€”she said "Mrs. Smith, 11, God
frey Street, Woolwich"â€”I went there; no such person as Mrs. Smith lives thereâ€”I told her that when I returned to the station; she made no replyâ€”I was present on the day afterwards when Mr. and Mrs. Reed and Mrs. Underhill identified the childâ€”I found this bodice in a cup
board in the front room in the prisoner's lodgingâ€”I showed it to the prisoner; she made no replyâ€”when I searched her lodging I also found this card, with the entry of a child which was entered in a benefit society, dated 4th Octoberâ€”I also produce a certificate from Dr. Frederick Cooper, the agent of the society, who is illâ€”information was given about the loss of the child on 21st September.

p.hi: The prisoner in her statement before the Magistrate and in her defence said that she was confined on 21st September, and that the child was hers, and that Mrs. Smith, who said she lived at 1 l., Godfrey Street, had attended her.

div1.p:
GUILTY.
There was another indictment against the prisoner, for bigamy. â€”
Judgment respited.

54.
JAMES WATTS (20) and
JAMES QUINLAN (26)
, Feloniously stealing 1l. 4s., the money of
Edward Francis Hoyle.

MR. CLUER Prosecuted; MR. GEOGHEGAN defended Quinlan. SUSAN HOYLE.
