I am a greengrocer and fruiterer, at 172, Barclay Roadâ€”on 19th October, between 5 and 6 p.m., I saw Quinlan near my shopâ€”he asked me for some cabbages which were outside the doorâ€”I went outside, leaving nobody in the shopâ€”he selected two, and then requested me to sell him 1 1/2 dozen; I agreed; he began to pack them into a boxâ€”I said I could not wait, and as I went into my shop to get a basket I met Waits coming outâ€”I had not seen him go inâ€”he said "I want some pears"â€”seeing Quinlan run away, I thought something was wrongâ€”Waits pushed past me and ran away in the direction of Malpas Road, the same way as the other had runâ€”I found everything gone out of my till except 6d. and a few coppersâ€”there had been 25s. beforeâ€”on the 20th I saw Quinlan at the station with 25 men; I picked him out without hesitationâ€”I went to the station again and identified Waits from a number of menâ€”Quinlan was standing outside my shop for five or six minutes before being served, and not a second afterwards he asked me about the cabbagesâ€”I was serving a lady with pears and saw him looking through the window.
Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. I was serving a lady from Malpas Road, when Quinlan was outside the shop, and my attention was taken up with her.
GEORGE WILLIAM BRIDLE I live at Forge Cottages, Brockleyâ€”on 19th October, about 5 o'clock, I was in Malpas Road with some other boys, and saw the prisoners runningâ€”Waits said "Don't stop me, you

fool"â€”Quinlan ran behind a carriage and jumped into French's coster
monger's borrow, who was driving quicklyâ€”on the 20th I picked out the prisoners from about 13 others as the men I had seen running, the evening beforeâ€”I know they are the twoâ€”Waits was dressed in a grey suit, and Quinlan in a grey suit with a long brown overcoat when I first saw themâ€”they were dressed differently at the police-station.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. There are no shops open in the Malpas Roadâ€”it was about 5 o'clock and getting darkâ€”I picked out French as the man into whose cart they jumpedâ€”the Magistrate dis
charged himâ€”I was as certain about him as about these.

EDWIN MARK . I am a bootmaker at 168, Brockley Roadâ€”on 19th October I passed Mrs. Hoyle's shop several timesâ€”I saw Waits loitering about there on the pavementâ€”subsequently I heard a cry of "Stop them"â€”I ran up from my workshop and saw two men going down Malpas Road; I followed, but could not overtake them; I did not see their facesâ€”as they ran down Malpas Road one of the men jumped into a cartâ€”on the morning of the 20th I was taken to Brockley Police-station, where I recognised Waits among 18 to 20 menâ€”I have no doubt he is the man who was loitering about.

HELENOR MORRIS . On 20th October I was taken to Brockley Station, where I identified the two prisonersâ€”I had seen Waits the day before standing outside Mrs. Hoyle's shop about 5 o'clockâ€”I have no doubt about himâ€”I cannot swear to Quinlan.
Cross-examined by Waits. I knew you directly I went into the room at Greenwich.

JOHN EDWARD JACKSON . I live at 13, Foxwell Street, Brockleyâ€”on the evening of 19th October I was in Malpas Road, and saw two young men running, and one got into French's cart, and the other ran over the brickfieldsâ€”I knew French beforeâ€”I cannot identify either of the two menâ€”one of the men running said "Don't stop me, you fool."

WILLIAM RUSSELL . I live at 10, Foxwell Street, and was with Jackson and other boys, and saw two young men running down Malpas, Roadâ€”I don't recognise either of themâ€”one got behind a carriage and got into French's cart.

FREDERICK BUNTING (Policeman P 357). I arrested Quinlan on the evening of the 19th and told him the chargeâ€”he said "All right, old fellow, I shall have to go"â€”going to the station he said "I suppose someone gave you the tip"â€”Mrs. Hoyle identified him from a number of othersâ€”he made no answer to the chargeâ€”French was charged with being concerned with themâ€”the Magistrate dismissed him.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. Mrs. Hoyle came to the station about 5.20, and she picked them out about 9 o'clock next day, after she had been at the station about a quarter of an hour, from among 13 or 14â€”I can't say they all resembled the description I had of Quinlanâ€”French was discharged, owing to evidence being given to his good characterâ€”he is an associate of the prisonersâ€”I know nothing against him.
Re-examined. Mrs. Hoyle had no doubt about Waits.
HUGH WALMSLEY (Policeman P 315). On 20th October I arrested Waits outside Greenwich Police-courtâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said, "Who told you? You must have heard what I said to that femaleâ€”I
took him to Brockley station; he was placed with about 15 other men and Mr. and Mrs. Hoyle and Mark identified him.

p.hi: Witnesses for the Defence of Waits.

div1.p: GEORGE FRENCH . I did not see either of the prisoners on 19th October at Brockley.
Cross-examined. I was driving my grandfather's cartâ€”some one jumped in as I went down Malpas Road; I did not stop.
MRS. MITCHELL. Waits has the same clothes on now as he had when he went out of my house on the 19th.

WAITSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

QUINLANâ€”
GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in June, 1885, in the name of James Edwards.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

55.
THOMAS JOHN BARNETT (45)
, Unlawfully obtaining 28l. from
Samuel Ebor Dunton by false pretences, with intent to defraud.
MR. GEOGHEGAN Prosecuted; MR. WEBSTER Defended.

GEORGE DUNTON . I am manager at the Globe public-house, Royal Hill, Greenwich, of which my brother, Samuel Ebor Dunton, is ownerâ€”last year my brother owned three houses at Leyton; I acted as agent for him in procuring a loan in December, 1885â€”the prisoner said he could get itâ€”when next I saw him he said he had got one from the Liberator Building Society, and on the same occasion he told me he was going to give Mr. Runtz 25l., and 3l. to the solicitors, Bonnor, Wright, and Thompsonâ€”he furnished me in my brother's presence with an account on the day the money was paid by the Liberator Building Society, 6th Januaryâ€”my brother repaid him the money the same night that the account was shownâ€”when he showed it he said the 3l. had been paid to the solicitors to carry it out expeditiously, and 25l. for Runtz to pass the other two houses.

Cross-examined. I was introduced to the prisoner about October and had some business with him; no money passed thenâ€”I superintended the matter for the ingoing partyâ€”the houses at Leyton were finished about Januaryâ€”the prisoner did a small portion towards finishing those houses on his own account, not by instructions; he superintended the finishing of themâ€”the loan was for finishing themâ€”he was to have five per cent, commission on the loan, and he was paid 15l. on his own account to get it done quicklyâ€”15l. included his commission and expensesâ€”when he first went down to these houses he paid for some of the goods which were supplied down there, locks, etc.; he did that on his own accountâ€”he stated to me that he went down to see if they were finishedâ€”the prisoner called several times, and I paid him different sums on various occasions for what he had paid tradesmenâ€”I gave him a cheque for 9l., which was dishonoured; I had a reason for stopping it at the bankâ€”that was about four months agoâ€”I did not pay him 19l. by a bill; he had various bills and I held one for 20l. for himâ€”I signed my brother's name by authorityâ€”a 20l. bill was not paid; I was summoned for that afterwardsâ€”I did not hear my brother say at the police-court, "I heard my brother accepted a bill for 19l. and I stopped it directly I heard of it"â€”I always sign my brother's name to bills and things connected with the businessâ€”I manage his business; he has been living at Readingâ€”previous to going to the prisoner I applied to other people for a loan on these houses, and then the prisoner called and said he could get them doneâ€”the houses

were finished at the latter end of January; two were not quite finishedâ€”Mr. Runtz is the Liberator Society's surveyor; the fees were to be paid him for surveying the houseâ€”the prisoner showed me the counterfoil of the cheque in the cheque book of the District Bank of London to show me that he had paid the money to Mr. Runtz; I think it was a brown cheque bookâ€”that was January 6thâ€”he then told me he had paid it, so I took it to have been paid before 6th Januaryâ€”a cheque of mine was dishonoured by the District Bank; it has since been settledâ€”they agreed to take so much per month in part payment; that was a month or two months backâ€”I had money enough at the bank to meet the 9l. cheque which I stopped.

Re-examined. This is the account in the prisoner's writingâ€”25l. is charged for the surveyor, and 3l. for the solicitorsâ€”a counterfoil is missing from the cheque-book; they go from 743 to 745â€”on 745 is written "Mr. Craven," and under that "Bonner, Wright, and Thompson"â€”that is the name of the solicitors, and there is 3l. changed into 46l.

SAMUEL EBOR DUNTON . I keep the Globe Hotel, Greenwichâ€”the last witness is my manager, and acted for me in procuring the loan on some housesâ€”on 6th January I and my brother met the prisoner at Cannon Street Station; my brother asked him what the surveyor's fees were; he told me he had paid 25l. on the evening of that day, and showed me the counterfoil of a cheque which purported to be 25l. paid to Mr. Runtz, the architectâ€”he said he had given 3l. to the solicitors of the Liberator Society for getting it off expeditiouslyâ€”I just saw this account at that time which the prisoner gave me; my brother said it was rightâ€”in that account there is 25l. for the surveyor, and 3l. for the solicitorsâ€”I paid the prisoner that money because he told me it had been paid, and my brother said it was correctâ€”the prisoner came to me at Reading after the summons was taken out, and asked me if I remembered anything about this caseâ€”I said "Certainly;" he said "Before I would have this case go on I would give you 3l. or 4l."

Cross-examined. I first met the prisoner on 6th Januaryâ€”I had had no communication with him about finishing the houses, I left all that to my brotherâ€”if the prisoner had told me 3l. was to be paid to the solicitors I would have paid itâ€”my brother said the account was rightâ€”I don't know if my brother paid him various sums for getting goods for the houseâ€”I heard afterwards about the bill for 19l., and paid for itâ€”my brother signs for meâ€”I took up this bill because my brother told me he had signed it.
Re-examined. My brother is my London managerâ€”I understood the 25l. had been actually paid.
By MR. WEBSTER. I understood it was for surveyor's fees for passing the three housesâ€”although there was only a loan on one, he said the others were to pass in a week or two.
By MR. GEOGHEGAN. The 25l. had nothing to do with the prisoner's surveyorship.

ARTHUR LEGG . I am a builder, of Claremontâ€”I was present at the interview between the prisoner and the Duntonsâ€”the prisoner produced a cheque-book, and read out a counterfoil in it, and said he had paid Mr. Runtz, the surveyor, 25l.â€”this is the sort of cheque-book.

Cross-examined. This was at the commencement of Januaryâ€”the pri
soner introduced me to the Capital and Counties Bankâ€”they closed my

account there because I stopped a cheque for 3l. payable to the prisoner, which he promised to meet and did notâ€”I have not given him as reference more than three or four timesâ€”he has been my reference since the stopping of the cheque, because he had some bills of mine which he discounted, and he stuck to the moneyâ€”I did not trade as Lawson and Johnson; I was interested in them, and had a little capital investedâ€”it turned out a failureâ€”I was not made bankruptâ€”I and the prisoner have had lots of money transactions togetherâ€”I cannot say if I had 5l. from him after 6th January; probably it was for money I had lent him; I am certain it was not for commissionâ€”I went to Mr. Wills, a solicitor, with the prisonerâ€”he wrote a letter, but it had nothing to do with this.

ERNEST AUGUSTUS RUNTZ . I live at 22, Moorgate Streetâ€”my partner is surveyor to the Liberator Building Societyâ€”I surveyed Mr. Dunton's house at Leyton in December, and reported it to my partner as favour
able, subject to certain thingsâ€”no sum of 25l. was ever paid to meâ€”all fees are paid to the Society; they don't come through our hands, but we render our account to the Society, who pays us.

THOMAS HERBERT CRAVEN . I live at Inchman, Stamford Hill, and am managing clerk to Wright, Bonner, and Wright, solicitorsâ€”in January the title of the firm was Bonnor, Wright, Thompson, and Co.â€”I have only seen the prisoner once or twiceâ€”I did not receive 3l. from him for putting the matter throughâ€”I had a cheque for ground rent after the completion of the houses.
Cross-examined. I received the ground rent on 12th January.
GEORGE DUNTON (Re-examined). The prisoner gave me receipts and hills at times from the tradesmen when I gave him money, and he paid them.

GUILTY .â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

56.
JAMES JOHNSON (26)
, Embezzling 12s. and 6s. received by him for
James Allen Cowood, his master.

MR. TAYLOR Prosecuted; MR. MOYSES Defended. GEORGE MILLS. I live at 99, High Street, Deptford, and am manager to the prosecutorâ€”the prisoner entered our employment in April last in Londonâ€”I had a right to require from him a statement of everything he soldâ€”I discharged him on October 16thâ€”the terms when the prisoner was engaged was that he was to have a week's notice, but our principal afterwards had a list of rules drawn upâ€”I gave the prisoner a copyâ€”one of them was that no notice was given or required, and with a proviso that if any man did not like the rules it was equivalent to accepting seven days' noticeâ€”as no one said anything we supposed they accepted themâ€”the prisoner was paid his wages, 24s. a week, at 12 o'clock the day he was discharged, which was at midnight on 16th October, when we closed the businessâ€”I then asked the prisoner if he had received any money on account of boxesâ€”he said he had notâ€”I never received from him 6s. or 12s. received by him from the sale of bacon boxes.

Cross-examined. The notice was published on 16th September, a few weeks before the date of the charge against the prisonerâ€”I don't think any of the men expressed dissatisfaction at it; the prisoner did notâ€”the prisoner had been in Cowood's employ some years before in Cumberlandâ€”the prisoner came to London with his wife and familyâ€”we had notices thenâ€”I swear the prisoner has not told me that he meant to stick to the
money in lieu of noticeâ€”he said so to Miss Gilbert, the cashier, and I believe to the policeman who arrested him.
Re-examined. The prisoner was in the prosecutor's employ before; he was discharged several times.

ALFRED STEWARD . I live at John Payne Street, Greenwich, and am a cowman in Mr. Murray's employmentâ€”I took every week what bacon boxes there were at the prosecutor's establishmentâ€”on 4th October I paid the prisoner 6s. and on the 16th 12s. for bacon boxesâ€”he gave me no receipt.

ANNIE GILBERT . I live at 57, Czar Street, Deptford, and have been cashier to the prosecutorâ€”on 16th October the prisoner said to me "I have got the bâ€”'s money for the bacon boxes, and I mean to stick to it"â€”that was after 12 o'clock at night.

Cross-examined. He said nothing about being entitled to stick to itâ€”it was after his discharge, at which he seemed annoyed; he was soberâ€”he came up to me and said so just as he came out of the shopâ€”Mr. Mills had asked him before, about 11 o'clock, in my presence, if he had any money for boxes, and he said "No"â€”then he was discharged, and afterwards he came and told me he had the money, and meant to stick to itâ€”I did not speak to him firstâ€”it was outside the shop door, after 12 o'clock at night; he was not dismissed till 12 o'clock.
Re-examined. I did not connect it with what I had heard before till the Monday morning when Mills spoke about it, and I told him what the prisoner had said.

JOSEPH COWOOD . I live at 44, St. Knollys Road, New Cross, and am head partner of this firm, the Cumberland Curing Companyâ€”the prisoner had been there about three years and a half at the date of his dischargeâ€”it had been a continuous serviceâ€”he had always been paid his wages, but several times I had to discharge him for drunkenness and other faults.

FRANCIS SHAVE (Detective R). On 18th October I saw the prisoner, and told him I was a police officer, and should arrest him for embezzling money the property of the Cumberland Curing Company, his late em
ployersâ€”he said "Yes, I have got it, they owe me a week's money"â€”I took him to the stationâ€”I found on him 9s. 9d.

GEORGE MILLS (Re-examined by MR. MOYSES.) Before I discharged the prisoner I had seen his wife, and said something about my intention to discharge himâ€”after that I saw him at work, and it was after that we had the conversation about the money.
ALFRED STEWART (Re-examined by the COURT). I took 12 boxes on the 4th, and 24 on the 16thâ€”I take all the boxesâ€”as the dozens come I take them away and pay for them.
NOT GUILTY .

57.
JAMES WALSH
, for the manslaughter of
William Skeel.
WILLIAM MULCAHY . I live at 17, Ewer Street, Southwarkâ€”on 29th

May I was drinking in company with the prisonerâ€”he went to sleep on a doorstep next to our lodging houseâ€”I was inside the lodging houseâ€”he came to the door and called me outâ€”he said "I'll take some ha'pence of you"â€”I said "What ha'pence?"â€”he said "I'll give you ha'pence"â€”he chucked this brick at me (produced)â€”I bobbed my head out of the wayâ€”the brick was in the gutterâ€”the prisoner was drunkâ€”he was rather drunk when he woke up, he did not know what he was doing.
Cross-examined by Prisoner. You lost your ha'pence and accused me of taking themâ€”I do not know that you meant to hit me or the child, but you flung the brick.

GEORGE SKEEL . I live in Ewer Street, Southwark, with the prisonerâ€”I manage the lodging houseâ€”on 29th May I heard my boy William, two years and a half old, cryâ€”I went to see what was the matterâ€”I found the child lying on the pavement about a yard from the doorâ€”he was bleeding from the headâ€”I saw the prisoner running awayâ€”I ran after him, I could not catch himâ€”when I returned the child had been taken to the hospitalâ€”I have been at this house about nine monthsâ€”the prisoner was a well-conducted manâ€”he got his living by selling papers.

JOSEPH GEORGE HARSANT . I am consulting surgeon at the Victoria Chest Hospitalâ€”I was house surgeon at Guy'sâ€”I saw the little boy about four days after his admission to Guy'sâ€”he was suffering from the effects of a depressed fracture on the right side of the foreheadâ€”it must have been caused by a heavy blowâ€”the bones of a child's head are comparatively soft, a light blow would break themâ€”this child died from the result of the blow on 15th July.

STEPHEN LEACH (Policeman). I apprehended the prisoner last Satur
day night in Coventry Street, Haymarketâ€”I told him I should take him into custody on a charge of manslaughter of William Skeelâ€”he said "I know all about it, I am very glad it has come to this; what I have done I am sorry for, and shall have to suffer for it"â€”this brick was brought up at the Coroner's inquiry by the witness Skeel.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "On Saturday, 29th May, I was drinking with Mulcahy and another, and I went to sleep on the doorstep, and I awoke and found Mulcahy's hand in my pocket, and I took up a piece of brick and flung it at him, and it hit the poor little fellow, and I am very sorry."

p.hi:
The prisoner, in his defence, stated that he and others staying at the lodging-house were the worse for drink; one man asked him for money for a break
fast; he gave him a shilling and that was the last thing he remembered till the man awoke him by putting his hand into his pocket. He only intended to frighten the man, and had no intention of doing harm to anyone, it was a pure accident.

div1.p:
GUILTY.â€” Recommended to mercy. â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

58.
WILLIAM TODMAN (28) and
MARGARET TODMAN (30)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Charles Wightman, and stealing two chemises and other articles, his property.
ANNIE WIGHTMAN . I am the wife of Charles Wightman, of 11, Carlisle

Place, Hythe Road, Eghamâ€”on the night of 8th November I went to bed leaving the house all safely shut upâ€”I left a bundle of clothes on the sofa in the parlourâ€”in the morning my husband got up first; he called to me to come down; I went down and found the kitchen window open and the bundle was goneâ€”after that, in the course of the day, I went out, and in the street I met the male prisoner on Staines Bridge; it was about 11.30 in the morning, and he had a bundle under his arm and was going into a pawnbroker'sâ€”I recognised the bundle, it was part of the same that had been on the sofa in my roomâ€”I followed the prisoner into the pawnbroker's, and he offered the things in pledgeâ€”I went into the next compartment and waited till Mr. Fern, the pawn-broker, spokeâ€”the prisoner asked 2s. on the things, and I said "Don't take them in, for they were stolen out of my house between last night and this morning"â€”the prisoner was there at the timeâ€”the pawn-broker gave the things to me, and told me to follow the prisoner out and give him in charge, and I did soâ€”these things (produced) are mine, and are what were in my bundleâ€”the prisoner did not say anything to me with respect to the things.

GEORGE FERN . I am a pawnbroker, of Stainesâ€”on the morning of 9th November these articles were offered to me in pledge by the male prisonerâ€”after hearing the last witness's statement I refused taking them and gave the things up to her.

HENRY COLLIS . I am an inspector of the Surrey Constabularyâ€”on 9th November, at 12 at noon, I received the male prisoner in custodyâ€”he was charged with burglariously entering the dwelling-house of Charles Wightman, at Egham, on the morning of the 9th, and stealing There from the articles in questionâ€”I cautioned himâ€”he said "I did not steal the articles, they were given to me by a woman at Frog's Island, who I did not know; she asked me to take them to Staines and pawn them; I was to obtain 1s., 6d. for them"â€”from further inquiry I went to the house of Mr. Bailey, a marine store dealer, at Frog's Island, and there found one sheet, one box-cover, one chemise, and a pair of drawers, which the female prisoner had pawnedâ€”the prosecutrix iden
tified them as part of the property she lost on that night.

MARK TRUSLER . I am a policeman, stationed at Eghamâ€”on the 9th November I apprehended the female prisonerâ€”I charged her with burglariously entering the dwelling-house of Mr. Wightman, and stealing the articles mentioned in the chargeâ€”I cautioned herâ€”she said "I sold some things to Mrs. Bailey this morning, but they were my own things"â€”she afterwards said "A woman gave them to me to sell, and I sold them"â€”a woman named Elizabeth Jackson was in custody at that timeâ€”she has been discharged.

SARAH BAILEY . I keep a marine store at Frog's Island, Stainesâ€”my husband has lost the use of his limbsâ€”on 9th November the female prisoner came in with these articlesâ€”she said she was very hard up for a bit of bread, and would I buy themâ€”I asked her what she wanted for themâ€”she said 1s. 2d., and I gave it to herâ€”being poor people's articles I thought they belonged to herâ€”I afterwards gave them up to the police.

The Prisoners' Statements before the Magistrate. William Todman says: "I went to Mrs. Franklin's at 8.30 a.m. yesterday morning. Jackson was there with a bundle, and asked me to pawn some of the clothes. I

went down, and Mrs. Wightman saw me as I went into the shop." Margaret Todman says: "Yesterday morning Elizabeth Jackson gave me the clothes to sell. I asked her if they belonged to her. She said they did, or she would not have let me sell them, and I went and sold them for her."
ANNIE WIGHTMAN (Re-examined.) I don't know Elizabeth Jackson at all.

WILLIAM TODMANâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.

MARGARET TODMANâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

59.
GEORGE BERNARD HARVEY DREW (42)
PLEADED GUILTY
to embezzling orders for the payment of 141l. 12s., 168l. 5s., 141l. 12s., and 187l. 10s.; also orders for 150l., 71l. 5s., and 91l. 15s. also orders for 150l., 187l. 10s., and 330s., of
Alfred Lafour and others, his masters.â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude,
and to pay the costs of the prosecution.

60.
SAMUEL ATTWELL (26)
to committing an act of gross indecency with
Charles Martin in a public place.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Two Months' Hard Labour. And

61.
GEORGE ANDREWS (49)
to forging and uttering a cheque for 8l. 10s., with intent to defraud, after a conviction of felony in November, 1880, at this Court, in the name of
William Harcourt.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Three Months' Hard Labour.

62.
GEORGE RINTUL
, Unlawfully publishing a defamatory libel concerning
Sarah Gollifer.

MR. GEOGHEGAN, for the prisoner', submitted that there must be a special intention charged in the indictment, which ought to have set out that the libel tended to provoke a breach of the peace. The RECORDER considered this objection fatal, and directed a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

63.
JOHN ADAMS (28)
, Feloniously having counterfeit coin in his possession, with intent to utter it.

MATTHEW CHICK (Policeman M 225). On 25th October I was with Beale in Union Street, Borough, about 5.45â€”we were in plain clothesâ€”I saw the prisoner standing under a lamp rubbing something between his finger and thumbâ€”he went into the Albion public-house, and came out and looked roundâ€”I went under the same lampâ€”he then leaned against a fence at the corner of Bath Terraceâ€”we went across to him, and I said, "What is that you had rubbing in your fingers and thumb just now?"â€”he said, "Nothing; what do you think?"â€”I said, "We are two police constables, and we are going to seeâ€”I seized his left hand, and he immediately put both his hands in his pocketsâ€”I seized his left, and Beale his rightâ€”after a desperate struggle I got his left hand out of his pocket, opened it, and found this parcel containing six counterfeit shillings separately wrapped in paperâ€”Beale took something from his right hand which I did not see, and said, "This is a bad shilling"â€”he said, "Why don't you go across to the paper shop and get the other man?"â€”I had not seen any man with himâ€”we took him to the paper shop, but there was no man thereâ€”on the road to the station he said, "A man whom I do not know gave me this parcel, told me to hold it, and said it was a parcel for my missis"â€”he gave his correct address at

the station, and next day he said, "I have got two men who can prove that you and your pal, "meaning Beale, "were in the Crown public-house yesterday, between 11 and 12 o'clock, and saw you give a man a half-crown, and you told him to go and buy this money and put it on me"â€”that is not trueâ€”I said nothing to that.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I have not got up the case for you.

WILLIAM BEALE (Policeman M 326). I was with Chick, in plain clothes, and saw the prisoner rubbing something under a lampâ€”he went into the Albion, and came out and went under the lamp againâ€”I crossed over to him, and saw something bright in his handâ€”we both laid hold of him, and Chick took a packet from his left hand while I took a shilling from his right and put it in my mouth and said, "This is a bad shilling"â€”he was very violent and said, "Why don't you take the other man?"â€”I said, "Where is he?"â€”he said, "Over at the paper shop"â€”we took the prisoner there; the shopkeeper examined his till, but found no bad moneyâ€”I said, "Has a man been here lately?"â€”he said, "I think not"â€”the prisoner was taken to the station, where I found a good sixpence on himâ€”I went back to the fence where he had been standing and picked up another bad shilling with teeth marks on it, and wrapped in paperâ€”that was where the struggle took placeâ€”it is not true that I was at the Crown the day before and got bad money and put it on the prisonerâ€”I have not been into the Crown for yearsâ€”I knew the prisoner previously.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These six shillings are counterfeit, so is this one in yellow paperâ€”this one found by the fence is also bad, and from the same mould as one of the sixâ€”counterfeit coins are rubbed over with lamp black to give them a tone, and paper is put between them to keep them from rubbing, and the lamp black is rubbed off before they are uttered.

JOHN O'DEE (Police Inspector). In consequence of a communication received from the prisoner, Sergeant Harvey and I went to Holloway Prison on 12th November, where he was waiting his trialâ€”he made this statementâ€”I took it down and he signed it. (This stated that a man named Rowley, who had had twelve months' imprisonment for uttering counterfeit coin, gave him the packet to hold, when he was pounced upon by the constables, who had brought the bad coin and put it on him.)

GUILTY .â€”He then PLEAED GUILTY** to a conviction at this Court in April, 1883, of having counterfeit coin in his possession.â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

64.
THOMAS OVERSHOTT (22)
, Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession, with intent to utter it.

FREDERICK GRAY (Detective L). On 29th October, about 8.45 p.m., I was in Waterloo Road, and saw the prisoner and another man go into the Crown public-house; I looked in, and they were having a conversa
tion with a man I knewâ€”they came out, and the man left the prisoner and went into Kennington Roadâ€”I spoke to Sergeant Boswell, missed the other man in the crowd, and came back to the prisoner, who was within a foot or two of where I left him, and said "What are you doing here?"â€”he said "Waiting for a friend?"â€”I said "Where has that other man gone?"â€”he said "Across the road"â€”we took him to the

station, searched him, and in his left waistcoat pocket I found this packet containing three counterfeit florins wrapped up in newspaper, singly round eachâ€”I said "Have you got any more?"â€”he said "No"â€”I said "Where did you get these from?"â€”he said "That man gave them to me that left me"â€”I said "Do you know his name or where he lives?"â€”he said "No"â€”I said "Where did he go?"â€”he said "Across the road with another one"â€”I know that he went aloneâ€”the prisoner was charged, and made no reply; he gave his name and address.

MR. FRANCIS BOSWELL (Police Sergeant L). I was with Gray and saw the prisoner and another manâ€”I watched the prisoner till Gray, who went utter the other man, came backâ€”I then took hold of him and took him to the station, where three florins were taken from himâ€”I have heard Gray's evidence; it is correct.
WILLIAM JOHNWEBSTER . These three florins are bad, and two are from one mould.

p.hi: The prisoner in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence, said that a man came up to him with a packet and, said "Put this in your pocket and wait till I come back"

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€ â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

65.
WILLIAM MAY (28) and
THOMAS ARCHIBALD ALEX
ANDER
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

rs.hi: The Jury being unable to agree, were discharged without a verdict, and the ease postponed till next Session.

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 13TH, 1886.
